00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
This is a photograph I found lying in a gutter in New York City

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
about 10 years ago.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
On the front, you can see the tattered black-and-white photo of a woman's face,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and on the back it says, "To Judy, the girl with the Bill Bailey voice.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
Have fun in whatever you do."

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
And I really loved this idea of the partial glimpse into somebody's life.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
As opposed to knowing the whole story, just knowing a little bit of the story,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
and then letting your own mind fill in the rest.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
And that idea of a partial glimpse is something

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
that will come back in a lot of the work I'll be showing later today.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
So, around this time I was studying computer science at Princeton University,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and I noticed that it was suddenly possible

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
to collect these sorts of personal artifacts,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
not just from street corners, but also from the Internet.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.958
And that suddenly, people, en masse, were leaving scores and scores

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:18.958
of digital footprints online that told stories of their private lives.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:22.958
Blog posts, photographs, thoughts, feelings, opinions,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
all of these things were being expressed by people online,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
and leaving behind trails.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
So, I started to write computer programs

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
that study very, very large sets of these online footprints.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
One such project is about a year and a half old.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
It's called "We Feel Fine."

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
This is a project that scans the world's newly posted blog entries

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
every two or three minutes, searching for occurrences of the phrases

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
"I feel" and "I am feeling." And when it finds one of those phrases,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
it grabs the full sentence up to the period

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and also tries to identify demographic information about the author.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
So, their gender, their age, their geographic location

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
and what the weather conditions were like when they wrote that sentence.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
It collects about 20,000 such sentences a day

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
and it's been running for about a year and a half,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
having collected over 10 and a half million feelings now.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
This is, then, how they're presented.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
These dots here represent some of the English-speaking world's

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
feelings from the last few hours,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
each dot being a single sentence stated by a single blogger.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
And the color of each dot corresponds to the type of feeling inside,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
so the bright ones are happy, and the dark ones are sad.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And the diameter of each dot corresponds

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
to the length of the sentence inside.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
So the small ones are short, and the bigger ones are longer.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
"I feel fine with the body I'm in, there'll be no easy excuse

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:33.958
for why I still feel uncomfortable being close to my boyfriend,"

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
from a twenty-two-year-old in Japan.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
"I got this on some trading locally,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
but really don't feel like screwing with wiring and crap."

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
Also, some of the feelings contain photographs in the blog posts.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And when that happens, these montage compositions are automatically created,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
which consist of the sentence and images being combined.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And any of these can be opened up to reveal the sentence inside.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:59.958
"I feel good."

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
"I feel rough now, and I probably gained 100,000 pounds,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:06.958
but it was worth it."

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
"I love how they were able to preserve most in everything

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
that makes you feel close to nature -- butterflies,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:16.958
man-made forests, limestone caves and hey, even a huge python."

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
So the next movement is called mobs.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
This provides a slightly more statistical look at things.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
This is showing the world's most common feelings overall right now,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
dominated by better, then bad, then good, then guilty, and so on.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Weather causes the feelings to assume the physical traits

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
of the weather they represent. So the sunny ones swirl around,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
the cloudy ones float along, the rainy ones fall down,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
and the snowy ones flutter to the ground.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:42.958
You can also stop a raindrop and open the feeling inside.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
Finally, location causes the feelings to move to their spots

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
on a world map, giving you a sense of their geographic distribution.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
So I'll show you now some of my favorite montages from "We Feel Fine."

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
These are the images that are automatically constructed.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
"I feel like I'm diagonally parked in a parallel universe."

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
(Laughter)

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
"I've kissed numerous other boys and it hasn't felt good,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
the kisses felt messy and wrong,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:08.958
but kissing Lucas feels beautiful and almost spiritual."

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
"I can feel my cancer grow."

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
"I feel pretty."

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
"I feel skinny, but I'm not."

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
"I'm 23, and a recovering meth and heroin addict,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
and feel absolutely blessed to still be alive."

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
"I can't wait to see them racing for the first time at Daytona next month,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
because I feel the need for speed."

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
(Laughter)

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:31.958
"I feel sassy."

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
"I feel so sexy in this new wig."

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
As you can see, "We Feel Fine" collects

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
very, very small-scale personal stories.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
Sometimes, stories as short as two or three words.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
So, really even challenging the notion

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
of what can be considered a story.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
And recently, I've become interested in diving much more deeply into a single story.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
And that's led me to doing some work with the physical world,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:52.958
not with the Internet,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and only using the Internet at the very last moment, as a presentation medium.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:57.958
So these are some newer projects that

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
actually aren't even launched publicly yet.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
The first such one is called "The Whale Hunt."

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
Last May, I spent nine days living up in Barrow, Alaska,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
the northernmost settlement in the United States,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
with a family of Inupiat Eskimos,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
documenting their annual spring whale hunt.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
This is the whaling camp here, we're about six miles from shore,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
camping on five and a half feet of thick, frozen pack ice.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And that water that you see there is the open lead,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
and through that lead, bowhead whales migrate north each springtime.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
And the Eskimo community basically camps out on the edge of the ice here,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
waits for a whale to come close enough to attack. And when it does,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
it throws a harpoon at it, and then hauls the whale up

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
under the ice, and cuts it up.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
And that would provide the community's food supply for a long time.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
So I went up there, and I lived with these guys

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
out in their whaling camp here, and photographed the entire experience,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
beginning with the taxi ride to Newark airport in New York,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
and ending with the butchering of the second whale, seven and a half days later.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
I photographed that entire experience at five-minute intervals.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
So every five minutes, I took a photograph.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
When I was awake, with the camera around my neck.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
When I was sleeping, with a tripod and a timer.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
And then in moments of high adrenaline,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
like when something exciting was happening,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
I would up that photographic frequency to as many as

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
37 photographs in five minutes.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
So what this created was a photographic heartbeat

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
that sped up and slowed down, more or less matching

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
the changing pace of my own heartbeat.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
That was the first concept here.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
The second concept was to use this experience to think about

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
the fundamental components of any story.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
What are the things that make up a story?

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
So, stories have characters. Stories have concepts.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Stories take place in a certain area. They have contexts.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
They have colors. What do they look like?

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
They have time. When did it take place? Dates -- when did it occur?

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
And in the case of the whale hunt, also this idea of an excitement level.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
The thing about stories, though, in most of the existing mediums

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
that we're accustomed to -- things like novels, radio,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
photographs, movies, even lectures like this one --

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
we're very accustomed to this idea of the narrator or the camera position,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
some kind of omniscient, external body

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
through whose eyes you see the story.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
We're very used to this.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
But if you think about real life, it's not like that at all.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
I mean, in real life, things are much more nuanced and complex,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
and there's all of these overlapping stories

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
intersecting and touching each other.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
And so I thought it would be interesting to build a framework

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
to surface those types of stories. So, in the case of "The Whale Hunt,"

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
how could we extract something like the story of Simeon and Crawford,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
involving the concepts of wildlife, tools and blood, taking place on the Arctic Ocean,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
dominated by the color red, happening around 10 a.m. on May 3,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
with an excitement level of high?

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
So, how to extract this order of narrative from this larger story?

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.958
I built a web interface for viewing "The Whale Hunt" that attempts to do just this.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
So these are all 3,214 pictures taken up there.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
This is my studio in Brooklyn. This is the Arctic Ocean,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and the butchering of the second whale, seven days later.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
You can start to see some of the story here, told by color.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
So this red strip signifies the color of the wallpaper

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
in the basement apartment where I was staying.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And things go white as we move out onto the Arctic Ocean.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
Introduction of red down here, when whales are being cut up.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
You can see a timeline, showing you the exciting moments throughout the story.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
These are organized chronologically.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
Wheel provides a slightly more playful version of the same,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
so these are also all the photographs organized chronologically.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And any of these can be clicked,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
and then the narrative is entered at that position.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
So here I am sleeping on the airplane heading up to Alaska.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
That's "Moby Dick."

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
This is the food we ate.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
This is in the Patkotak's family living room

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
in their house in Barrow. The boxed wine they served us.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
Cigarette break outside -- I don't smoke.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
This is a really exciting sequence of me sleeping.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
This is out at whale camp, on the Arctic Ocean.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
This graph that I'm clicking down here is meant to be

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
reminiscent of a medical heartbeat graph,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:42.958
showing the exciting moments of adrenaline.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
This is the ice starting to freeze over. The snow fence they built.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
And so what I'll show you now is the ability to pull out sub-stories.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So, here you see the cast. These are all of the people in "The Whale Hunt"

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and the two whales that were killed down here.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
And we could do something as arbitrary as, say,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:02.958
extract the story of Rony, involving the concepts of blood

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and whales and tools, taking place on the Arctic Ocean,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
at Ahkivgaq camp, with the heartbeat level of fast.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And now we've whittled down that whole story

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
to just 29 matching photographs,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
and then we can enter the narrative at that position.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
And you can see Rony cutting up the whale here.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
These whales are about 40 feet long,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and weighing over 40 tons. And they provide the food source

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
for the community for much of the year.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Skipping ahead a bit more here, this is Rony on the whale carcass.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
They use no chainsaws or anything; it's entirely just blades,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
and an incredibly efficient process.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
This is the guys on the rope, pulling open the carcass.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
This is the muktuk, or the blubber, all lined up for community distribution.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
It's baleen. Moving on.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
So what I'm going to tell you about next

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
is a very new thing. It's not even a project yet.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
So, just yesterday, I flew in here from Singapore, and before that,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
I was spending two weeks in Bhutan, the small Himalayan kingdom

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
nestled between Tibet and India.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And I was doing a project there about happiness,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
interviewing a lot of local people.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:13.958
So Bhutan has this really wacky thing where they base

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
most of their high-level governmental decisions around the concept

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.958
of gross national happiness instead of gross domestic product,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and they've been doing this since the '70s.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And it leads to just a completely different value system.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
It's an incredibly non-materialistic culture,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
where people don't have a lot, but they're incredibly happy.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
So I went around and I talked to people about some of these ideas.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
So, I did a number of things. I asked people a number of set questions,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and took a number of set photographs,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and interviewed them with audio, and also took pictures.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
I would start by asking people to rate their happiness

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
between one and 10, which is kind of inherently absurd.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And then when they answered, I would inflate that number of balloons

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and give them that number of balloons to hold.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So, you have some really happy person holding 10 balloons,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
and some really sad soul holding one balloon.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
But you know, even holding one balloon is like, kind of happy.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
(Laughter)

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And then I would ask them a number of questions like

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
what was the happiest day in their life, what makes them happy.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
And then finally, I would ask them to make a wish.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
And when they made a wish, I would write their wish

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
onto one of the balloons and take a picture of them holding it.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
So I'm going to show you now just a few brief snippets

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
of some of the interviews that I did, some of the people I spoke with.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
This is an 11-year-old student.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
He was playing cops and robbers with his friends, running around town,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and they all had plastic toy guns.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
His wish was to become a police officer.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
He was getting started early. Those were his hands.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
I took pictures of everybody's hands,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
because I think you can often tell a lot about somebody

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
from how their hands look. I took a portrait of everybody,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
and asked everybody to make a funny face.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
A 17-year-old student. Her wish was to have been born a boy.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
She thinks that women have a pretty tough go of things in Bhutan,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
and it's a lot easier if you're a boy.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
A 28-year-old cell phone shop owner.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
If you knew what Paro looked like, you'd understand

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:05.958
how amazing it is that there's a cell phone shop there.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
He wanted to help poor people.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
A 53-year-old farmer. She was chaffing wheat,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and that pile of wheat behind her

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
had taken her about a week to make.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:25.958
She wanted to keep farming until she dies.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
You can really start to see the stories told by the hands here.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
She was wearing this silver ring that had the word "love" engraved on it,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
and she'd found it in the road somewhere.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
A 16-year-old quarry worker.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
This guy was breaking rocks with a hammer in the hot sunlight,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
but he just wanted to spend his life as a farmer.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
A 21-year-old monk. He was very happy.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
He wanted to live a long life at the monastery.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
He had this amazing series of hairs growing out of a mole on the left side of his face,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
which I'm told is very good luck.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
He was kind of too shy to make a funny face.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:21.958
A 16-year-old student.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
She wanted to become an independent woman.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:24.958
I asked her about that, and she said she meant

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
that she doesn't want to be married,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
because, in her opinion, when you get married in Bhutan as a woman,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
your chances to live an independent life kind of end,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
and so she had no interest in that.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
A 24-year-old truck driver.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
There are these terrifyingly huge Indian trucks

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:48.958
that come careening around one-lane roads with two-lane traffic,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
with 3,000-foot drop-offs right next to the road,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and he was driving one of these trucks.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
But all he wanted was to just live a comfortable life, like other people.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
A 24-year-old road sweeper. I caught her on her lunch break.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
She'd built a little fire to keep warm, right next to the road.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Her wish was to marry someone with a car.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
She wanted a change in her life.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
She lives in a little worker's camp right next to the road,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
and she wanted a different lot on things.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
An 81-year-old itinerant farmer.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
I saw this guy on the side of the road,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
and he actually doesn't have a home.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
He travels from farm to farm each day trying to find work,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:40.958
and then he tries to sleep at whatever farm he gets work at.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
So his wish was to come with me, so that he had somewhere to live.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
He had this amazing knife that he pulled out of his gho

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
and started brandishing when I asked him to make a funny face.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
It was all good-natured.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:03.958
A 10-year-old.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
He wanted to join a school and learn to read,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
but his parents didn't have enough money to send him to school.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
He was eating this orange, sugary candy

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
that he kept dipping his fingers into,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
and since there was so much saliva on his hands,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
this orange paste started to form on his palms.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
(Laughter)

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
A 37-year-old road worker.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:32.958
One of the more touchy political subjects in Bhutan

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
is the use of Indian cheap labor

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
that they import from India to build the roads,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
and then they send these people home once the roads are built.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
So these guys were in a worker's gang

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
mixing up asphalt one morning on the side of the highway.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
His wish was to make some money and open a store.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.958
A 75-year-old farmer. She was selling oranges on the side of the road.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
I asked her about her wish, and she said,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
"You know, maybe I'll live, maybe I'll die, but I don't have a wish."

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
She was chewing betel nut, which caused her teeth

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
over the years to turn very red.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Finally, this is a 26-year-old nun I spoke to.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
Her wish was to make a pilgrimage to Tibet.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
I asked her how long she planned to live in the nunnery and she said,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
"Well, you know, of course, it's impermanent,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:31.958
but my plan is to live here until I'm 30, and then enter a hermitage."

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:36.958
And I said, "You mean, like a cave?" And she said, "Yeah, like a cave."

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
And I said, "Wow, and how long will you live in the cave?"

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
And she said, "Well, you know,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:45.958
I think I'd kind of like to live my whole life in the cave."

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
I just thought that was amazing. I mean, she spoke in a way --

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
with amazing English, and amazing humor, and amazing laughter --

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
that made her seem like somebody I could have bumped into

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
on the streets of New York, or in Vermont, where I'm from.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
But here she had been living in a nunnery for the last seven years.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.958
I asked her a little bit more about the cave

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:05.958
and what she planned would happen once she went there, you know.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
What if she saw the truth after just one year,

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
what would she do for the next 35 years in her life?

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
And this is what she said.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:16.958
Woman: I think I'm going to stay for 35. Maybe -- maybe I'll die.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
Jonathan Harris: Maybe you'll die? Woman: Yes.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
JH: 10 years? Woman: Yes, yes. JH: 10 years, that's a long time.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
Woman: Yes, not maybe one, 10 years, maybe I can die

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
within one year, or something like that.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
JH: Are you hoping to?

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
Woman: Ah, because you know, it's impermanent.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:36.958
JH: Yeah, but -- yeah, OK. Do you hope --

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:39.958
would you prefer to live in the cave for 40 years,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
or to live for one year?

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:45.958
Woman: But I prefer for maybe 40 to 50.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:46.958
JH: 40 to 50? Yeah.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:49.958
Woman: Yes. From then, I'm going to the heaven.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:54.958
JH: Well, I wish you the best of luck with it.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:55.958
Woman: Thank you.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
JH: I hope it's everything that you hope it will be.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:00.958
So thank you again, so much.

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
Woman: You're most welcome.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:04.958
JH: So if you caught that, she said she hoped to die

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
when she was around 40. That was enough life for her.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
So, the last thing we did, very quickly,

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
is I took all those wish balloons -- there were 117 interviews,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:16.958
117 wishes -- and I brought them up to a place called Dochula,

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:20.958
which is a mountain pass in Bhutan, at 10,300 feet,

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:23.958
one of the more sacred places in Bhutan.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
And up there, there are thousands of prayer flags

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
that people have spread out over the years.

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.958
And we re-inflated all of the balloons, put them up on a string,

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:32.958
and hung them up there among the prayer flags.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:34.958
And they're actually still flying up there today.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:37.958
So if any of you have any Bhutan travel plans in the near future,

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:40.958
you can go check these out. Here are some images from that.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:45.958
We said a Buddhist prayer so that all these wishes could come true.

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:57.958
You can start to see some familiar balloons here.

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:02.958
"To make some money and to open a store" was the Indian road worker.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:12.958
Thanks very much.

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:15.958
(Applause)

title: A tour of modern architecture
transcript: To be new at TED — it's like being the last high-school virgin. (Laughter) You know that all of the cool people are — they're doing it. And you're on the outside, you're at home. You're like the Raspyni Brothers, where you've got your balls in cold water. And — (Laughter) — you just play with your fingers all day. And then you get invited. And you're on the inside, and it's everything you hoped it would be. It's exciting and there's music playing all of the time and then suddenly it's over. And it's only taken five minutes. And you want to go back and do it again. But I really appreciate being here. And thank you, Chris, and also, thank you, Deborah Patton, for making this possible.So anyway, today we'll talk about architecture a little bit, within the subject of creation and optimism. And if you put creation and optimism together, you've got two choices that you can talk about. You can talk about creationism — which I think wouldn't go down well with this audience, at least not from a view where you were a proponent of it — or you can talk about optimisations, spelled the British way, with an S, instead of a Z. And I think that's what I'd like to talk about today. But any kind of conversation about architecture — which is, in fact, what you were just talking about, what was going on here, setting up TED, small-scale architecture — at the present time can't really happen without a conversation about this, the World Trade Center, and what's been going on there, what it means to us.Because if architecture is what I believe it to be, which is the built form of our cultural ambitions, what do you do when presented with an opportunity to rectify a situation that represents somebody else's cultural ambitions relative to us? And our own opportunity to make something new there? This has been a really galvanizing issue for a long time. I think that the World Trade Center in, rather an unfortunate way, brought architecture into focus in a way that I don't think people had thought of in a long time, and made it a subject for common conversation. I don't remember, in my 20-year career of practicing and writing about architecture, a time when five people sat me down at a table and asked me very serious questions about zoning, fire exiting, safety concerns and whether carpet burns. These are just not things we talked about very often. And yet, now, it's talked about all the time. At the point where you can weaponize your buildings, you have to suddenly think about architecture in a very different way. And so now we're going to think about architecture in a very different way, we're going to think about it like this.How many of you saw USA Today, today? There it is. Looks like that. There's the World Trade Center site, on the front cover. They've made a selection. They've chosen a project by Daniel Libeskind, the enfant terrible of the moment of architecture. Child-prodigy piano player, he started on the squeezebox, and moved to a little more serious issue, a bigger instrument, and now to an even larger instrument, upon which to work his particular brand of deconstructivist magic, as you see here. He was one of six people who were invited to participate in this competition, after six previous firms struck out with things that were so stupid and banal that even the city of New York was forced to go, "Oh, I'm really sorry, we screwed up." Right. Can we do this again from the top, except use some people with a vague hint of talent, instead of just six utter boobs like we brought in last time, real estate hacks of the kind who usually plan our cities. Let's bring in some real architects for a change. And so we got this, or we had a choice of that. Oh, stop clapping.(Laughter)It's too late. That is gone. This was a scheme by a team called THINK, a New York-based team, and then there was that one, which was the Libeskind scheme. This one, this is going to be the new World Trade Center: a giant hole in the ground with big buildings falling into it. Now, I don't know what you think, but I think this is a pretty stupid decision, because what you've done is just made a permanent memorial to destruction by making it look like the destruction is going to continue forever. But that's what we're going to do. But I want you to think about these things in terms of a kind of ongoing struggle that American architecture represents, and that these two things talk about very specifically. And that is the wild divergence in how we choose our architects, in trying to decide whether we want architecture from the kind of technocratic solution to everything — that there is a large, technical answer that can solve all problems, be they social, be they physical, be they chemical — or something that's more of a romantic solution.Now, I don't mean romantic as in, this is a nice place to take someone on a date. I mean romantic in the sense of, there are things larger and grander than us. So, in the American tradition, the difference between the technocratic and the romantic, would be the difference between Thomas Jefferson's Cartesian grids spreading across the United States, that gives us basically the whole shape of every western state in the United States, as a really, truly, technocratic solution, a bowing to the — in Jefferson's time — current, popular philosophy of rationalism. Or the way we went to describe that later: manifest destiny. Now, which would you rather be? A grid, or manifest destiny? Manifest destiny.(Laughter)It's a big deal. It sounds big, it sounds important, it sounds solid. It sounds American. Ballsy, serious, male. And that kind of fight has gone on back and forth in architecture all the time. I mean, it goes on in our private lives, too, every single day. We all want to go out and buy an Audi TT, don't we? Everyone here must own one, or at least they craved one the moment they saw one. And then they hopped in it, turned the little electronic key, rather than the real key, zipped home on their new superhighway, and drove straight into a garage that looks like a Tudor castle.(Laughter)Why? Why? Why do you want to do that? Why do we all want to do that? I even owned a Tudor thing once myself.(Laughter)It's in our nature to go ricocheting back and forth between this technocratic solution and a larger, sort of more romantic image of where we are. So we're going to go straight into this. Can I have the lights off for a moment? I'm going to talk about two architects very, very briefly that represent the current split, architecturally, between these two traditions of a technocratic or technological solution and a romantic solution. And these are two of the top architectural practices in the United States today. One very young, one a little more mature. This is the work of a firm called SHoP, and what you're seeing here, is their isometric drawings of what will be a large-scale camera obscura in a public park. Does everybody know what a camera obscura is? Yeah, it's one of those giant camera lenses that takes a picture of the outside world — it's sort of a little movie, without any moving parts — and projects it on a page, and you can see the world outside you as you walk around it.This is just the outline of it, and you can see, does it look like a regular building? No. It's actually non-orthogonal: it's not up and down, square, rectangular, anything like that, that you'd see in a normal shape of a building. The computer revolution, the technocratic, technological revolution, has allowed us to jettison normal-shaped buildings, traditionally shaped buildings, in favor of non-orthogonal buildings such as this. What's interesting about it is not the shape. What's interesting about it is how it's made. How it's made. A brand-new way to put buildings together, something called mass customization. No, it is not an oxymoron. What makes the building expensive, in the traditional sense, is making individual parts custom, that you can't do over and over again. That's why we all live in developer houses. They all want to save money by building the same thing 500 times. That's because it's cheaper.Mass customization works by an architect feeding into a computer, a program that says, manufacture these parts. The computer then talks to a machine — a computer-operated machine, a cad-cam machine — that can make a zillion different changes, at a moment's notice, because the computer is just a machine. It doesn't care. It's manufacturing the parts. It doesn't see any excess cost. It doesn't spend any extra time. It's not a laborer — it's simply an electronic lathe, so the parts can all be cut at the same time. Meanwhile, instead of sending someone working drawings, which are those huge sets of blueprints that you've seen your whole life, what the architect can do is send a set of assembly instructions, like you used to get when you were a child, when you bought little models that said, "Bolt A to B, and C to D." And so what the builder will get is every single individual part that has been custom manufactured off-site and delivered on a truck to the site, to that builder, and a set of these instruction manuals. Just simple "Bolt A to B" and they will be able to put them together. Here's the little drawing that tells them how that works — and that's what will happen in the end.You're underneath it, looking up into the lens of the camera obscura. Lest you think this is all fiction, lest you think this is all fantasy, or romance, these same architects were asked to produce something for the central courtyard of PS1, which is a museum in Brooklyn, New York, as part of their young architects summer series. And they said, well, it's summer, what do you do? In the summer, you go to the beach. And when you go to the beach, what do you get? You get sand dunes. So let's make architectural sand dunes and a beach cabana. So they went out and they modeled a computer model of a sand dune. They took photographs, they fed the photographs into their computer program, and that computer program shaped a sand dune and then took that sand dune shape and turned it into — at their instructions, using standard software with slight modifications — a set of instructions for pieces of wood. And those are the pieces of wood. Those are the instructions. These are the pieces, and here's a little of that blown up.What you can see is there's about six different colors, and each color represents a type of wood to be cut, a piece of wood to be cut. All of which were delivered by flat bed, on a truck, and hand assembled in 48 hours by a team of eight people, only one of whom had ever seen the plans before. Only one of whom had ever seen the plans before. And here comes dune-scape, coming up out of the courtyard, and there it is fully built. There are only 16 different pieces of wood, only 16 different assembly parts here. Looks like a beautiful piano sounding board on the inside. It has its own built-in swimming pool, very, very cool. It's a great place for parties — it was, it was only up for six weeks. It's got little dressing rooms and cabanas, where lots of interesting things went on, all summer long.Now, lest you think that this is only for the light at heart, or just temporary installations, this is the same firm working at the World Trade Center, replacing the bridge that used to go across West Street, that very important pedestrian connection between the city of New York and the redevelopment of the West Side. They were asked to design, replace that bridge in six weeks, building it, including all of the parts, manufactured. And they were able to do it. That was their design, using that same computer modeling system and only five or six really different kinds of parts, a couple of struts, like this, some exterior cladding material and a very simple framing system that was all manufactured off-site and delivered by truck. They were able to create that. They were able to create something wonderful. They're now building a 16-story building on the side of New York, using the same technology. Here we're going to walk across the bridge at night. It's self-lit, you don't need any overhead lighting, so the neighbors don't complain about metal-halide lighting in their face. Here it is going across. And there, down the other side, and you get the same kind of grandeur.Now, let me show you, quickly, the opposite, if I may. Woo, pretty, huh. This is the other side of the coin. This is the work of David Rockwell from New York City, whose work you can see out here today. The current king of the romantics, who approaches his work in a very different fashion. It's not to create a technological solution, it's to seduce you into something that you can do, into something that will please you, something that will lift your spirits, something that will make you feel as if are in another world — such as his Nobu restaurant in New York, which is supposed to take you from the clutter of New York City to the simplicity of Japan and the elegance of Japanese tradition. "When it's all said and done, it's got to look like seaweed," said the owner. Or his restaurant, Pod, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.I want you to know the room you're looking at is stark white. Every single surface of this restaurant is white. The reason it has so much color is that it changes using lighting. It's all about sensuality. It's all about transforming. Watch this — I'm not touching any buttons, ladies and gentlemen. This is happening by itself. It transforms through the magic of lighting. It's all about sensuality. It's all about touch. Rosa Mexicano restaurant, where he transports us to the shores of Acapulco, up on the Upper West Side, with this wall of cliff divers who — there you go, like that. Let's see it one more time. Okay, just to make sure that you've enjoyed it. And finally, it's about comfort, it's about making you feel good in places that you wouldn't have felt good before. It's about bringing nature to the inside.In the Guardian Tower of New York, converted to a W Union Square — I'm sorry I'm rushing — where we had to bring in the best horticulturists in the world to make sure that the interior of this dragged the garden space of the court garden of the Union Square into the building itself. It's about stimulation. This is a wine-buying experience simplified by color and taste. Fizzy, fresh, soft, luscious, juicy, smooth, big and sweet wines, all explained to you by color and texture on the wall. And finally, it's about entertainment, as in his headquarters for the Cirque du Soleil, Orlando, Florida, where you're asked to enter the Greek theater, look under the tent and join the magic world of Cirque du Soleil. And I think I'll probably leave it at that. Thank you very much.
