for perhaps billions of years

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
before it enters the telescope or your eye.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Now, how do we deduce where the galaxy is?

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
Well, we deduce it by the direction that the ray is traveling

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
as it enters our eye, right?

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
We say, the ray of light came this way;

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
the galaxy must be there, OK.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Now, suppose I put in the middle a cluster of galaxies --

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and don't forget the dark matter, OK.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:05.958
Now, if we consider a different ray of light, one going off like this,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
we now need to take into account

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
what Einstein predicted when he developed general relativity.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
And that was that the gravitational field, due to mass,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
will deflect not only the trajectory of particles,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
but will deflect light itself.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
So this light ray will not continue in a straight line,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:27.958
but would rather bend and could end up going into our eye.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Where will this observer see the galaxy?

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
You can respond. Up, right?

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
We extrapolate backwards and say the galaxy is up here.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:38.958
Is there any other ray of light

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
that could make into the observer's eye from that galaxy?

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Yes, great. I see people going down like this.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
So a ray of light could go down, be bent

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
up into the observer's eye,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
and the observer sees a ray of light here.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
Now, take into account the fact that we live in

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
a three-dimensional universe, OK,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
a three-dimensional space.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
Are there any other rays of light that could make it into the eye?

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:05.958
Yes! The rays would lie on a -- I'd like to see -- yeah, on a cone.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
So there's a whole ray of light -- rays of light on a cone --

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
that will all be bent by that cluster

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and make it into the observer's eye.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:17.958
If there is a cone of light coming into my eye, what do I see?

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
A circle, a ring. It's called an Einstein ring. Einstein predicted that, OK.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Now, it will only be a perfect ring if the source, the deflector

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and the eyeball, in this case, are all in a perfectly straight line.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
If they're slightly skewed, we'll see a different image.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Now, you can do an experiment tonight over the reception, OK,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
to figure out what that image will look like.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Because it turns out that there is a kind of lens that we can devise,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
that has the right shape to produce this kind of effect.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
We call this gravitational lensing.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
And so, this is your instrument, OK.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:53.958
(Laughter).

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
But ignore the top part.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
It's the base that I want you to concentrate, OK.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
So, actually, at home, whenever we break a wineglass,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
I save the bottom, take it over to the machine shop.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
We shave it off, and I have a little gravitational lens, OK.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
So it's got the right shape to produce the lensing.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
And so the next thing you need to do in your experiment

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
is grab a napkin. I grabbed a piece of graph paper -- I'm a physicist. (Laughter)

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So, a napkin. Draw a little model galaxy in the middle.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And now put the lens over the galaxy,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and what you'll find is that you'll see a ring, an Einstein ring.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Now, move the base off to the side,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and the ring will split up into arcs, OK.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And you can put it on top of any image.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:34.958
On the graph paper, you can see

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
how all the lines on the graph paper have been distorted.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
And again, this is a kind of an accurate model

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
of what happens with the gravitational lensing.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
OK, so the question is: do we see this in the sky?

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
Do we see arcs in the sky when we look at, say, a cluster of galaxies?

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
And the answer is yes.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And so, here's an image from the Hubble Space Telescope.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
Many of the images you are seeing

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
are earlier from the Hubble Space Telescope.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
Well, first of all, for the golden shape galaxies --

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
those are the galaxies in the cluster.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
They're the ones that are embedded in that sea of dark matter

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
that are causing the bending of the light

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
to cause these optical illusions, or mirages, practically,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
of the background galaxies.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So the streaks that you see, all these streaks,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
are actually distorted images of galaxies that are much further away.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
So what we can do, then, is based on how much distortion

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
we see in those images, we can calculate how much mass

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
there must be in this cluster.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
And it's an enormous amount of mass.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And also, you can tell by eye, by looking at this,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that these arcs are not centered on individual galaxies.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
They are centered on some more spread out structure,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
and that is the dark matter

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
in which the cluster is embedded, OK.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
So this is the closest you can get to kind of seeing

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
at least the effects of the dark matter with your naked eye.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
OK, so, a quick review then, to see that you're following.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
So the evidence that we have

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
that a quarter of the universe is dark matter --

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
this gravitationally attracting stuff --

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
is that galaxies, the speed with which stars orbiting galaxies

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is much too large; it must be embedded in dark matter.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
The speed with which galaxies within clusters are orbiting is much too large;

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
it must be embedded in dark matter.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
And we see these gravitational lensing effects, these distortions

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
that say that, again, clusters are embedded in dark matter.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
OK. So now, let's turn to dark energy.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
So to understand the evidence for dark energy, we need to discuss something

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
that Stephen Hawking referred to in the previous session.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And that is the fact that space itself is expanding.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:42.958
So if we imagine a section of our infinite universe --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and so I've put down four spiral galaxies, OK --

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and imagine that you put down a set of tape measures,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
so every line on here corresponds to a tape measure,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
horizontal or vertical, for measuring where things are.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
If you could do this, what you would find

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
that with each passing day, each passing year,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
each passing billions of years, OK,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
the distance between galaxies is getting greater.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:07.958
And it's not because galaxies are moving

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
away from each other through space.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
They're not necessarily moving through space.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
They're moving away from each other

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
because space itself is getting bigger, OK.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:21.958
That's what the expansion of the universe or space means.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
So they're moving further apart.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
Now, what Stephen Hawking mentioned, as well,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:33.958
is that after the Big Bang, space expanded at a very rapid rate.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:37.958
But because gravitationally attracting matter

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
is embedded in this space,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
it tends to slow down the expansion of the space, OK.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
So the expansion slows down with time.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
So, in the last century, OK, people debated

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:54.958
about whether this expansion of space would continue forever;

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
whether it would slow down, you know,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
will be slowing down, but continue forever;

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:03.958
slow down and stop, asymptotically stop;

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
or slow down, stop, and then reverse, so it starts to contract again.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
So a little over a decade ago,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:15.958
two groups of physicists and astronomers

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
set out to measure the rate at which

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
the expansion of space was slowing down, OK.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
By how much less is it expanding today,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
compared to, say, a couple of billion years ago?

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:31.958
The startling answer to this question, OK, from these experiments,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
was that space is expanding at a faster rate today

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
than it was a few billion years ago, OK.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
So the expansion of space is actually speeding up.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
This was a completely surprising result.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:50.958
There is no persuasive theoretical argument for why this should happen, OK.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
No one was predicting ahead of time this is what's going to be found.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
It was the opposite of what was expected.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
So we need something to be able to explain that.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Now it turns out, in the mathematics,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
you can put it in as a term that's an energy,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:05.958
but it's a completely different type of energy

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
from anything we've ever seen before.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
We call it dark energy,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
and it has this effect of causing space to expand.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
But we don't have a good motivation

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
for putting it in there at this point, OK.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
So it's really unexplained as to why we need to put it in.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Now, so at this point, then, what I want to really emphasize to you,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
is that, first of all, dark matter and dark energy

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
are completely different things, OK.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
There are really two mysteries out there as to what makes up most of the universe,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and they have very different effects.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Dark matter, because it gravitationally attracts,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
it tends to encourage the growth of structure, OK.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
So clusters of galaxies will tend to form,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
because of all this gravitational attraction.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Dark energy, on the other hand,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
is putting more and more space between the galaxies,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
makes it, the gravitational attraction between them decrease,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
and so it impedes the growth of structure.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
So by looking at things like clusters of galaxies,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
and how they -- their number density,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
how many there are as a function of time --

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
we can learn about how dark matter and dark energy

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
compete against each other in structure forming.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
In terms of dark matter, I said that we don't have any,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:21.958
you know, really persuasive argument for dark energy.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Do we have anything for dark matter? And the answer is yes.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
We have well-motivated candidates for the dark matter.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Now, what do I mean by well motivated?

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.958
I mean that we have mathematically consistent theories

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
that were actually introduced

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
to explain a completely different phenomenon, OK,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
things that I haven't even talked about,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
that each predict the existence

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
of a very weakly interacting, new particle.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So, this is exactly what you want in physics:

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
where a prediction comes out of a mathematically consistent theory

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
that was actually developed for something else.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
But we don't know if either of those

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
are actually the dark matter candidate, OK.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
One or both, who knows? Or it could be something completely different.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Now, we look for these dark matter particles

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
because, after all, they are here in the room, OK,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and they didn't come in the door.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
They just pass through anything.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
They can come through the building, through the Earth --

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
they're so non-interacting.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
So one way to look for them is to build detectors

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:24.958
that are extremely sensitive to a dark matter particle coming through and bumping it.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
So a crystal that will ring if that happens.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
So one of my colleagues up the road and his collaborators

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
have built such a detector.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
And they've put it deep down in an iron mine in Minnesota,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
OK, deep under the ground, and in fact, in the last couple of days

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
announced the most sensitive results so far.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
They haven't seen anything, OK, but it puts limits on what the mass

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
and the interaction strength of these dark matter particles are.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
There's going to be a satellite telescope launched later this year

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and it will look towards the middle of the galaxy,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
to see if we can see dark matter particles annihilating

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
and producing gamma rays that could be detected with this.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
The Large Hadron Collider, a particle physics accelerator,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
that we'll be turning on later this year.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
It is possible that dark matter particles might be produced

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
at the Large Hadron Collider.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:11.958
Now, because they are so non-interactive,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
they will actually escape the detector,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
so their signature will be missing energy, OK.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Now, unfortunately, there is a lot of new physics

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
whose signature could be missing energy,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
so it will be hard to tell the difference.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:29.958
And finally, for future endeavors, there are telescopes being designed

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:33.958
specifically to address the questions of dark matter and dark energy --

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
ground-based telescopes, and there are three space-based telescopes

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
that are in competition right now

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
to be launched to investigate dark matter and dark energy.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
So in terms of the big questions:

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
what is dark matter? What is dark energy?

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
The big questions facing physics.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
And I'm sure you have lots of questions,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
which I very much look forward to addressing

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
over the next 72 hours, while I'm here. Thank you.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
(Applause)

title: A family tree for humanity
transcript: Jambo, bonjour, zdravstvujtye, dayo: these are a few of the languages that I've spoken little bits of over the course of the last six weeks, as I've been to 17 countries I think I'm up to, on this crazy tour I've been doing, checking out various aspects of the project that we're doing. And I'm going to tell you a little bit about later on. And visiting some pretty incredible places, places like Mongolia, Cambodia, New Guinea, South Africa, Tanzania twice — I was here a month ago.And the opportunity to make a whirlwind tour of the world like that is utterly amazing, for lots of reasons. You see some incredible stuff. And you get to make these spot comparisons between people all around the globe. And the thing that you really take away from that, the kind of surface thing that you take away from it, is not that we're all one, although I'm going to tell you about that, but rather how different we are. There is so much diversity around the globe. 6,000 different languages spoken by six and a half billion people, all different colors, shapes, sizes. You walk down the street in any big city, you travel like that, and you are amazed at the diversity in the human species.How do we explain that diversity? Well, that's what I'm going to talk about today, is how we're using the tools of genetics, population genetics in particular, to tell us how we generated this diversity, and how long it took. Now, the problem of human diversity, like all big scientific questions — how do you explain something like that — can be broken down into sub-questions. And you can ferret away at those little sub-questions.First one is really a question of origins. Do we all share a common origin, in fact? And given that we do — and that's the assumption everybody, I think, in this room would make — when was that? When did we originate as a species? How long have we been divergent from each other?And the second question is related, but slightly different. If we do spring from a common source, how did we come to occupy every corner of the globe, and in the process generate all of this diversity, the different ways of life, the different appearances, the different languages around the world?Well, the question of origins, as with so many other questions in biology, seems to have been answered by Darwin over a century ago. In "The Descent of Man," he wrote, "In each great region of the world, the living mammals are closely related to the extinct species of the same region. It's therefore probable that Africa was formerly inhabited by extinct apes closely allied to the gorilla and chimpanzee, and as these two species are now man's nearest allies, it's somewhat more probable that our early progenitors lived on the African continent than elsewhere."So we're done, we can go home — finished the origin question. Well, not quite. Because Darwin was talking about our distant ancestry, our common ancestry with apes. And it is quite clear that apes originated on the African continent. Around 23 million years ago, they appear in the fossil record. Africa was actually disconnected from the other landmasses at that time, due to the vagaries of plate tectonics, floating around the Indian Ocean. Bumped into Eurasia around 16 million years ago, and then we had the first African exodus, as we call it. The apes that left at that time ended up in Southeast Asia, became the gibbons and the orangutans. And the ones that stayed on in Africa evolved into the gorillas, the chimpanzees and us. So, yes, if you're talking about our common ancestry with apes, it's very clear, by looking at the fossil record, we started off here.But that's not really the question I'm asking. I'm asking about our human ancestry, things that we would recognize as being like us if they were sitting here in the room. If they were peering over your shoulder, you wouldn't leap back, like that. What about our human ancestry? Because if we go far enough back, we share a common ancestry with every living thing on Earth. DNA ties us all together, so we share ancestry with barracuda and bacteria and mushrooms, if you go far enough back — over a billion years. What we're asking about though is human ancestry. How do we study that?Well, historically, it has been studied using the science of paleoanthropology. Digging things up out of the ground, and largely on the basis of morphology — the way things are shaped, often skull shape — saying, "This looks a little bit more like us than that, so this must be my ancestor. This must be who I'm directly descended from."The field of paleoanthropology, I'll argue, gives us lots of fascinating possibilities about our ancestry, but it doesn't give us the probabilities that we really want as scientists. What do I mean by that? You're looking at a great example here. These are three extinct species of hominids, potential human ancestors. All dug up just west of here in Olduvai Gorge, by the Leakey family. And they're all dating to roughly the same time. From left to right, we've got Homo erectus, Homo habilis, and Australopithecus — now called Paranthropus boisei, the robust australopithecine. Three extinct species, same place, same time. That means that not all three could be my direct ancestor. Which one of these guys am I actually related to? Possibilities about our ancestry, but not the probabilities that we're really looking for.Well, a different approach has been to look at morphology in humans using the only data that people really had at hand until quite recently — again, largely skull shape. The first person to do this systematically was Linnaeus, Carl von Linne, a Swedish botanist, who in the eighteenth century took it upon himself to categorize every living organism on the planet. You think you've got a tough job? And he did a pretty good job. He categorized about 12,000 species in "Systema Naturae." He actually coined the term Homo sapiens — it means wise man in Latin. But looking around the world at the diversity of humans, he said, "Well, you know, we seem to come in discreet sub-species or categories." And he talked about Africans and Americans and Asians and Europeans, and a blatantly racist category he termed "Monstrosus," which basically included all the people he didn't like, including imaginary folk like elves.It's easy to dismiss this as the perhaps well-intentioned but ultimately benighted musings of an eighteenth century scientist working in the pre-Darwinian era. Except, if you had taken physical anthropology as recently as 20 or 30 years ago, in many cases you would have learned basically that same classification of humanity. Human races that according to physical anthropologists of 30, 40 years ago — Carlton Coon is the best example — had been diverging from each other — this was in the post-Darwinian era — for over a million years, since the time of Homo erectus. But based on what data? Very little. Very little. Morphology and a lot of guesswork.Well, what I'm going to talk about today, what I'm going to talk about now is a new approach to this problem. Instead of going out and guessing about our ancestry, digging things up out of the ground, possible ancestors, and saying it on the basis of morphology — which we still don't completely understand, we don't know the genetic causes underlying this morphological variation —what we need to do is turn the problem on its head. Because what we're really asking is a genealogical problem, or a genealogical question. What we're trying to do is construct a family tree for everybody alive today. And as any genealogist will tell you — anybody have a member of the family, or maybe you have tried to construct a family tree, trace back in time? You start in the present, with relationships you're certain about. You and your siblings, you have a parent in common. You and your cousins share a grandparent in common. You gradually trace further and further back into the past, adding these ever more distant relationships. But eventually, no matter how good you are at digging up the church records, and all that stuff, you hit what the genealogists call a brick wall. A point beyond which you don't know anything else about your ancestors, and you enter this dark and mysterious realm we call history that we have to feel our way through with whispered guidance.Who were these people who came before? We have no written record. Well, actually, we do. Written in our DNA, in our genetic code — we have a historical document that takes us back in time to the very earliest days of our species. And that's what we study.Now, a quick primer on DNA. I suspect that not everybody in the audience is a geneticist. It is a very long, linear molecule, a coded version of how to make another copy of you. It's your blueprint. It's composed of four subunits: A, C, G and T, we call them. And it's the sequence of those subunits that defines that blueprint. How long is it? Well, it's billions of these subunits in length. A haploid genome — we actually have two copies of all of our chromosomes — a haploid genome is around 3.2 billion nucleotides in length. And the whole thing, if you add it all together, is over six billion nucleotides long. If you take all the DNA out of one cell in your body, and stretch it end to end, it's around two meters long. If you take all the DNA out of every cell in your body, and you stretch it end to end, it would reach from here to the moon and back, thousands of times. It's a lot of information.And so when you're copying this DNA molecule to pass it on, it's a pretty tough job. Imagine the longest book you can think of, "War and Peace." Now multiply it by 100. And imagine copying that by hand. And you're working away until late at night, and you're very, very careful, and you're drinking coffee and you're paying attention, but, occasionally, when you're copying this by hand, you're going to make a little typo, a spelling mistake — substitute an I for an E, or a C for a T.Same thing happens to our DNA as it's being passed on through the generations. It doesn't happen very often. We have a proofreading mechanism built in. But when it does happen, and these changes get transmitted down through the generations, they become markers of descent. If you share a marker with someone, it means you share an ancestor at some point in the past, the person who first had that change in their DNA. And it's by looking at the pattern of genetic variation, the pattern of these markers in people all over the world, and assessing the relative ages when they occurred throughout our history, that we've been able to construct a family tree for everybody alive today.These are two pieces of DNA that we use quite widely in our work. Mitochondrial DNA, tracing a purely maternal line of descent. You get your mtDNA from your mother, and your mother's mother, all the way back to the very first woman. The Y chromosome, the piece of DNA that makes men men, traces a purely paternal line of descent. Everybody in this room, everybody in the world, falls into a lineage somewhere on these trees. Now, even though these are simplified versions of the real trees, they're still kind of complicated, so let's simplify them. Turn them on their sides, combine them so that they look like a tree with the root at the bottom and the branches going up. What's the take-home message?Well, the thing that jumps out at you first is that the deepest lineages in our family trees are found within Africa, among Africans. That means that Africans have been accumulating this mutational diversity for longer. And what that means is that we originated in Africa. It's written in our DNA. Every piece of DNA we look at has greater diversity within Africa than outside of Africa. And at some point in the past, a sub-group of Africans left the African continent to go out and populate the rest of the world.Now, how recently do we share this ancestry? Was it millions of years ago, which we might suspect by looking at all this incredible variation around the world? No, the DNA tells a story that's very clear. Within the last 200,000 years, we all share an ancestor, a single person — Mitochondrial Eve, you might have heard about her — in Africa, an African woman who gave rise to all the mitochondrial diversity in the world today.But what's even more amazing is that if you look at the Y-chromosome side, the male side of the story, the Y-chromosome Adam only lived around 60,000 years ago. That's only about 2,000 human generations, the blink of an eye in an evolutionary sense. That tells us we were all still living in Africa at that time. This was an African man who gave rise to all the Y chromosome diversity around the world. It's only within the last 60,000 years that we have started to generate this incredible diversity we see around the world. Such an amazing story. We're all effectively part of an extended African family.Now, that seems so recent. Why didn't we start to leave earlier? Why didn't Homo erectus evolve into separate species, or sub-species rather, human races around the world? Why was it that we seem to have come out of Africa so recently? Well, that's a big question. These "why" questions, particularly in genetics and the study of history in general, are always the big ones, the ones that are tough to answer.And so when all else fails, talk about the weather. What was going on to the world's weather around 60,000 years ago? Well, we were going into the worst part of the last ice age. The last ice age started roughly 120,000 years ago. It went up and down, and it really started to accelerate around 70,000 years ago. Lots of evidence from sediment cores and the pollen types, oxygen isotopes and so on. We hit the last glacial maximum around 16,000 years ago, but basically, from 70,000 years on, things were getting really tough, getting very cold. The Northern Hemisphere had massive growing ice sheets. New York City, Chicago, Seattle, all under a sheet of ice. Most of Britain, all of Scandinavia, covered by ice several kilometers thick.Now, Africa is the most tropical continent on the planet — about 85 percent of it lies between Cancer and Capricorn — and there aren't a lot of glaciers here, except on the high mountains here in East Africa. So what was going on here? We weren't covered in ice in Africa. Rather, Africa was drying out at that time. This is a paleo-climatological map of what Africa looked like between 60,000 and 70,000 years ago, reconstructed from all these pieces of evidence that I mentioned before. The reason for that is that ice actually sucks moisture out of the atmosphere. If you think about Antarctica, it's technically a desert, it gets so little precipitation.So the whole world was drying out. The sea levels were dropping. And Africa was turning to desert. The Sahara was much bigger then than it is now. And the human habitat was reduced to just a few small pockets, compared to what we have today. The evidence from genetic data is that the human population around this time, roughly 70,000 years ago, crashed to fewer than 2,000 individuals. We nearly went extinct. We were hanging on by our fingernails.And then something happened. A great illustration of it. Look at some stone tools. The ones on the left are from Africa, from around a million years ago. The ones on the right were made by Neanderthals, our distant cousins, not our direct ancestors, living in Europe, and they date from around 50,000 or 60,000 years ago. Now, at the risk of offending any paleoanthropologists or physical anthropologists in the audience, basically there's not a lot of change between these two stone tool groups. The ones on the left are pretty similar to the ones on the right. We are in a period of long cultural stasis from a million years ago until around 60,000 to 70,000 years ago. The tool styles don't change that much. The evidence is that the human way of life didn't change that much during that period.But then 50, 60, 70 thousand years ago, somewhere in that region, all hell breaks loose. Art makes its appearance. The stone tools become much more finely crafted. The evidence is that humans begin to specialize in particular prey species, at particular times of the year. The population size started to expand. Probably, according to what many linguists believe, fully modern language, syntactic language — subject, verb, object — that we use to convey complex ideas, like I'm doing now, appeared around that time. We became much more social. The social networks expanded.This change in behavior allowed us to survive these worsening conditions in Africa, and they allowed us to start to expand around the world. We've been talking at this conference about African success stories. Well, you want the ultimate African success story? Look in the mirror. You're it. The reason you're alive today is because of those changes in our brains that took place in Africa — probably somewhere in the region where we're sitting right now, around 60, 70 thousand years ago — allowing us not only to survive in Africa, but to expand out of Africa. An early coastal migration along the south coast of Asia, leaving Africa around 60,000 years ago, reaching Australia very rapidly, by 50,000 years ago. A slightly later migration up into the Middle East. These would have been savannah hunters.So those of you who are going on one of the post-conference tours, you'll get to see what a real savannah is like. And it's basically a meat locker. People who would have specialized in killing the animals, hunting the animals on those meat locker savannahs, moving up, following the grasslands into the Middle East around 45,000 years ago, during one of the rare wet phases in the Sahara. Migrating eastward, following the grasslands, because that's what they were adapted to live on.And when they reached Central Asia, they reached what was effectively a steppe super-highway, a grassland super-highway. The grasslands at that time — this was during the last ice age — stretched basically from Germany all the way over to Korea, and the entire continent was open to them. Entering Europe around 35,000 years ago, and finally, a small group migrating up through the worst weather imaginable, Siberia, inside the Arctic Circle, during the last ice age — temperature was at -70, -80, even -100, perhaps — migrating into the Americas, ultimately reaching that final frontier.An amazing story, and it happened first in Africa. The changes that allowed us to do that, the evolution of this highly adaptable brain that we all carry around with us, allowing us to create novel cultures, allowing us to develop the diversity that we see on a whirlwind trip like the one I've just been on.Now, that story I just told you is literally a whirlwind tour of how we populated the world, the great Paleolithic wanderings of our species. And that's the story that I told a couple of years ago in my book, "The Journey of Man," and a film that we made with the same title. And as we were finishing up that film — it was co-produced with National Geographic — I started talking to the folks at NG about this work. And they got really excited about it. They liked the film, but they said, "You know, we really see this as kind of the next wave in the study of human origins, where we all came from, using the tools of DNA to map the migrations around the world. You know, the study of human origins is kind of in our DNA, and we want to take it to the next level. What do you want to do next?" Which is a great question to be asked by National Geographic.And I said, "Well, you know, what I've sketched out here is just that. It is a very coarse sketch of how we migrated around the planet. And it's based on a few thousand people we've sampled from, you know, a handful of populations around the world. Studied a few genetic markers, and there are lots of gaps on this map. We've just connected the dots. What we need to do is increase our sample size by an order of magnitude or more — hundreds of thousands of DNA samples from people all over the world."And that was the genesis of the Genographic Project. The project launched in April 2005. It has three core components. Obviously, science is a big part of it. The field research that we're doing around the world with indigenous peoples. People who have lived in the same location for a long period of time retain a connection to the place where they live that many of the rest of us have lost. So my ancestors come from all over northern Europe. I live in the Eastern Seaboard of North America when I'm not traveling. Where am I indigenous to? Nowhere really. My genes are all jumbled up. But there are people who retain that link to their ancestors that allows us to contextualize the DNA results.That's the focus of the field research, the centers that we've set up all over the world — 10 of them, top population geneticists. But, in addition, we wanted to open up this study to anybody around the world. How often do you get to participate in a big scientific project? The Human Genome Project, or a Mars Rover mission.In this case, you actually can. You can go onto our website, Nationalgeographic.com/genographic. You can order a kit. You can test your own DNA. And you can actually submit those results to the database, and tell us a little about your genealogical background, have the data analyzed as part of the scientific effort.Now, this is all a nonprofit enterprise, and so the money that we raise, after we cover the cost of doing the testing and making the kit components, gets plowed back into the project. The majority going to something we call the Legacy Fund. It's a charitable entity, basically a grant-giving entity that gives money back to indigenous groups around the world for educational, cultural projects initiated by them. They apply to this fund in order to do various projects, and I'll show you a couple of examples.So how are we doing on the project? We've got about 25,000 samples collected from indigenous people around the world. The most amazing thing has been the interest on the part of the public; 210,000 people have ordered these participation kits since we launched two years ago, which has raised around five million dollars, the majority of which, at least half, is going back into the Legacy Fund.We've just awarded the first Legacy Grants totaling around 500,000 dollars. Projects around the world — documenting oral poetry in Sierra Leone, preserving traditional weaving patterns in Gaza, language revitalization in Tajikistan, etc., etc. So the project is going very, very well, and I urge you to check out the website and watch this space.Thank you very much. (Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:20.958
Jambo, bonjour, zdravstvujtye, dayo: these are a few of the languages

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:24.958
that I've spoken little bits of over the course of the last six weeks,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:29.958
as I've been to 17 countries I think I'm up to, on this crazy tour I've been doing,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
checking out various aspects of the project that we're doing.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
And I'm going to tell you a little bit about later on.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
And visiting some pretty incredible places,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:43.958
places like Mongolia, Cambodia, New Guinea, South Africa, Tanzania twice --

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
I was here a month ago.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:50.958
And the opportunity to make a whirlwind tour of the world like that

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
is utterly amazing, for lots of reasons.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
You see some incredible stuff.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
And you get to make these spot comparisons

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
between people all around the globe.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
And the thing that you really take away from that,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
the kind of surface thing that you take away from it,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:08.958
is not that we're all one, although I'm going to tell you about that,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
but rather how different we are.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
There is so much diversity around the globe.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
6,000 different languages spoken by six and a half billion people,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
all different colors, shapes, sizes.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
You walk down the street in any big city, you travel like that,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
and you are amazed at the diversity in the human species.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
How do we explain that diversity?

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
Well, that's what I'm going to talk about today,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
is how we're using the tools of genetics,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:39.958
population genetics in particular, to tell us how we generated this diversity,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and how long it took.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
Now, the problem of human diversity,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
like all big scientific questions --

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
how do you explain something like that --

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
can be broken down into sub-questions.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
And you can ferret away at those little sub-questions.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
First one is really a question of origins.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
Do we all share a common origin, in fact?

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
And given that we do -- and that's the assumption

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
everybody, I think, in this room would make -- when was that?

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
When did we originate as a species?

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
How long have we been divergent from each other?

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
And the second question is related, but slightly different.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
If we do spring from a common source,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
how did we come to occupy every corner of the globe,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
and in the process generate all of this diversity,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
the different ways of life, the different appearances,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
the different languages around the world?

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
Well, the question of origins, as with so many other questions in biology,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
seems to have been answered by Darwin over a century ago.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
In "The Descent of Man," he wrote,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
"In each great region of the world, the living mammals

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
are closely related to the extinct species of the same region.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
It's therefore probable that Africa was formerly inhabited by extinct apes

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
closely allied to the gorilla and chimpanzee,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
and as these two species are now man's nearest allies,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
it's somewhat more probable that our early progenitors

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
lived on the African continent than elsewhere."

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
So we're done, we can go home -- finished the origin question.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.958
Well, not quite. Because Darwin was talking about our distant ancestry,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
our common ancestry with apes.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:00.958
And it is quite clear that apes originated on the African continent.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
Around 23 million years ago, they appear in the fossil record.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
Africa was actually disconnected from the other landmasses at that time,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.958
due to the vagaries of plate tectonics, floating around the Indian Ocean.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
Bumped into Eurasia around 16 million years ago,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and then we had the first African exodus, as we call it.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
The apes that left at that time ended up in Southeast Asia,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
became the gibbons and the orangutans.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
And the ones that stayed on in Africa

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
evolved into the gorillas, the chimpanzees and us.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
So, yes, if you're talking about our common ancestry with apes,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
it's very clear, by looking at the fossil record, we started off here.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
But that's not really the question I'm asking.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
I'm asking about our human ancestry,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
things that we would recognize as being like us

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
if they were sitting here in the room.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
If they were peering over your shoulder,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
you wouldn't leap back, like that. What about our human ancestry?

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Because if we go far enough back,

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
we share a common ancestry with every living thing on Earth.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
DNA ties us all together, so we share ancestry with barracuda

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
and bacteria and mushrooms, if you go far enough back -- over a billion years.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
What we're asking about though is human ancestry.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
How do we study that?

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
Well, historically, it has been studied using the science of paleoanthropology.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Digging things up out of the ground,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
and largely on the basis of morphology --

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
the way things are shaped, often skull shape -- saying,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
"This looks a little bit more like us than that, so this must be my ancestor.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
This must be who I'm directly descended from."

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
The field of paleoanthropology, I'll argue,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
gives us lots of fascinating possibilities about our ancestry,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
but it doesn't give us the probabilities that we really want as scientists.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
What do I mean by that?

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
You're looking at a great example here.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
These are three extinct species of hominids,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
potential human ancestors.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
All dug up just west of here in Olduvai Gorge, by the Leakey family.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
And they're all dating to roughly the same time.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
From left to right, we've got Homo erectus, Homo habilis,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
and Australopithecus -- now called Paranthropus boisei,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:51.958
the robust australopithecine. Three extinct species, same place, same time.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
That means that not all three could be my direct ancestor.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
Which one of these guys am I actually related to?

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:02.958
Possibilities about our ancestry, but not the probabilities that we're really looking for.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:07.958
Well, a different approach has been to look at morphology in humans

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
using the only data that people really had at hand until quite recently --

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
again, largely skull shape.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
The first person to do this systematically was Linnaeus,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
Carl von Linne, a Swedish botanist,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
who in the eighteenth century took it upon himself

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
to categorize every living organism on the planet.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
You think you've got a tough job?

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
And he did a pretty good job.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
He categorized about 12,000 species in "Systema Naturae."

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
He actually coined the term Homo sapiens -- it means wise man in Latin.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
But looking around the world at the diversity of humans, he said,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
"Well, you know, we seem to come in discreet sub-species or categories."

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
And he talked about Africans and Americans and Asians and Europeans,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
and a blatantly racist category he termed "Monstrosus,"

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
which basically included all the people he didn't like,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
including imaginary folk like elves.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:06:00.958
It's easy to dismiss this as the perhaps well-intentioned

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
but ultimately benighted musings of an eighteenth century scientist

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
working in the pre-Darwinian era.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
Except, if you had taken physical anthropology

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
as recently as 20 or 30 years ago, in many cases you would have learned

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
basically that same classification of humanity.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:18.958
Human races that according to physical anthropologists of 30, 40 years ago --

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Carlton Coon is the best example --

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
had been diverging from each other -- this was in the post-Darwinian era --

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
for over a million years, since the time of Homo erectus.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
But based on what data?

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
Very little. Very little. Morphology and a lot of guesswork.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Well, what I'm going to talk about today,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
what I'm going to talk about now is a new approach to this problem.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Instead of going out and guessing about our ancestry,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
digging things up out of the ground, possible ancestors,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
and saying it on the basis of morphology --

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
which we still don't completely understand,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
we don't know the genetic causes underlying this morphological variation --

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
what we need to do is turn the problem on its head.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Because what we're really asking is a genealogical problem,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
or a genealogical question.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:04.958
What we're trying to do is construct a family tree for everybody alive today.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And as any genealogist will tell you --

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
anybody have a member of the family, or maybe you

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
have tried to construct a family tree, trace back in time?

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
You start in the present, with relationships you're certain about.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
You and your siblings, you have a parent in common.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
You and your cousins share a grandparent in common.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
You gradually trace further and further back into the past,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
adding these ever more distant relationships.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:26.958
But eventually, no matter how good you are at digging up the church records,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
and all that stuff, you hit what the genealogists call a brick wall.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
A point beyond which you don't know anything else about your ancestors,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
and you enter this dark and mysterious realm we call history

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
that we have to feel our way through with whispered guidance.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Who were these people who came before?

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
We have no written record. Well, actually, we do.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
Written in our DNA, in our genetic code --

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
we have a historical document that takes us back in time

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:54.958
to the very earliest days of our species. And that's what we study.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Now, a quick primer on DNA.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
I suspect that not everybody in the audience is a geneticist.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:03.958
It is a very long, linear molecule, a coded version

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
of how to make another copy of you. It's your blueprint.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
It's composed of four subunits: A, C, G and T, we call them.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And it's the sequence of those subunits that defines that blueprint.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
How long is it? Well, it's billions of these subunits in length.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
A haploid genome -- we actually have two copies of all of our chromosomes --

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
a haploid genome is around 3.2 billion nucleotides in length.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
And the whole thing, if you add it all together,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
is over six billion nucleotides long.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
If you take all the DNA out of one cell in your body,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
and stretch it end to end, it's around two meters long.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
If you take all the DNA out of every cell in your body,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and you stretch it end to end, it would reach from here to the moon and back,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
thousands of times. It's a lot of information.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:49.958
And so when you're copying this DNA molecule to pass it on, it's a pretty tough job.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Imagine the longest book you can think of, "War and Peace."

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
Now multiply it by 100.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
And imagine copying that by hand.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
And you're working away until late at night,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
and you're very, very careful, and you're drinking coffee

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
and you're paying attention, but, occasionally,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
when you're copying this by hand,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
you're going to make a little typo, a spelling mistake --

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
substitute an I for an E, or a C for a T.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Same thing happens to our DNA as it's being passed on through the generations.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
It doesn't happen very often. We have a proofreading mechanism built in.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
But when it does happen, and these changes get transmitted down

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
through the generations, they become markers of descent.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
If you share a marker with someone,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
it means you share an ancestor at some point in the past,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
the person who first had that change in their DNA.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And it's by looking at the pattern of genetic variation,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
the pattern of these markers in people all over the world,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
and assessing the relative ages when they occurred throughout our history,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
that we've been able to construct a family tree for everybody alive today.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
These are two pieces of DNA that we use quite widely in our work.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
Mitochondrial DNA, tracing a purely maternal line of descent.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
You get your mtDNA from your mother, and your mother's mother,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
all the way back to the very first woman.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
The Y chromosome, the piece of DNA that makes men men,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
traces a purely paternal line of descent.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Everybody in this room, everybody in the world,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
falls into a lineage somewhere on these trees.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Now, even though these are simplified versions of the real trees,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
they're still kind of complicated, so let's simplify them.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Turn them on their sides, combine them so that they look like a tree

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
with the root at the bottom and the branches going up.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
What's the take-home message?

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
Well, the thing that jumps out at you first

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
is that the deepest lineages in our family trees

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:30.958
are found within Africa, among Africans.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
That means that Africans have been accumulating

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
this mutational diversity for longer.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And what that means is that we originated in Africa. It's written in our DNA.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Every piece of DNA we look at has greater diversity within Africa than outside of Africa.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And at some point in the past, a sub-group of Africans

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
left the African continent to go out and populate the rest of the world.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
Now, how recently do we share this ancestry?

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
Was it millions of years ago, which we might suspect

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
by looking at all this incredible variation around the world?

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
No, the DNA tells a story that's very clear.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:09.958
Within the last 200,000 years, we all share an ancestor, a single person --

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.958
Mitochondrial Eve, you might have heard about her -- in Africa,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
an African woman who gave rise to all the mitochondrial diversity in the world today.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
But what's even more amazing

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
is that if you look at the Y-chromosome side,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
the male side of the story, the Y-chromosome Adam

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
only lived around 60,000 years ago.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
That's only about 2,000 human generations,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
the blink of an eye in an evolutionary sense.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
That tells us we were all still living in Africa at that time.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
This was an African man who gave rise

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
to all the Y chromosome diversity around the world.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
It's only within the last 60,000 years

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
that we have started to generate this incredible diversity we see around the world.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Such an amazing story.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
We're all effectively part of an extended African family.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Now, that seems so recent. Why didn't we start to leave earlier?

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Why didn't Homo erectus evolve into separate species,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
or sub-species rather, human races around the world?

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Why was it that we seem to have come out of Africa so recently?

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
Well, that's a big question. These "why" questions,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:12.958
particularly in genetics and the study of history in general, are always the big ones,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
the ones that are tough to answer.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
And so when all else fails, talk about the weather.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
What was going on to the world's weather around 60,000 years ago?

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Well, we were going into the worst part of the last ice age.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
The last ice age started roughly 120,000 years ago.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
It went up and down, and it really started to accelerate around 70,000 years ago.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Lots of evidence from sediment cores

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
and the pollen types, oxygen isotopes and so on.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
We hit the last glacial maximum around 16,000 years ago,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.958
but basically, from 70,000 years on, things were getting really tough,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:47.958
getting very cold. The Northern Hemisphere had massive growing ice sheets.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:51.958
New York City, Chicago, Seattle, all under a sheet of ice.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Most of Britain, all of Scandinavia, covered by ice several kilometers thick.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Now, Africa is the most tropical continent on the planet --

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
about 85 percent of it lies between Cancer and Capricorn --

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
and there aren't a lot of glaciers here,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
except on the high mountains here in East Africa.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
So what was going on here? We weren't covered in ice in Africa.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Rather, Africa was drying out at that time.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
This is a paleo-climatological map

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
of what Africa looked like between 60,000 and 70,000 years ago,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
reconstructed from all these pieces of evidence that I mentioned before.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
The reason for that is that ice actually sucks moisture out of the atmosphere.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
If you think about Antarctica, it's technically a desert, it gets so little precipitation.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
So the whole world was drying out.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
The sea levels were dropping. And Africa was turning to desert.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
The Sahara was much bigger then than it is now.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
And the human habitat was reduced to just a few small pockets,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
compared to what we have today.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
The evidence from genetic data

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
is that the human population around this time, roughly 70,000 years ago,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
crashed to fewer than 2,000 individuals.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:56.958
We nearly went extinct. We were hanging on by our fingernails.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
And then something happened. A great illustration of it.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
Look at some stone tools.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
The ones on the left are from Africa, from around a million years ago.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
The ones on the right were made by Neanderthals, our distant cousins,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
not our direct ancestors, living in Europe,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
and they date from around 50,000 or 60,000 years ago.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Now, at the risk of offending any paleoanthropologists

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
or physical anthropologists in the audience,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:25.958
basically there's not a lot of change between these two stone tool groups.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
The ones on the left are pretty similar to the ones on the right.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:32.958
We are in a period of long cultural stasis from a million years ago

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
until around 60,000 to 70,000 years ago.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
The tool styles don't change that much.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
The evidence is that the human way of life

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
didn't change that much during that period.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:45.958
But then 50, 60, 70 thousand years ago, somewhere in that region,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
all hell breaks loose. Art makes its appearance.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
The stone tools become much more finely crafted.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
The evidence is that humans begin to specialize in particular prey species,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
at particular times of the year.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
The population size started to expand.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
Probably, according to what many linguists believe,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
fully modern language, syntactic language -- subject, verb, object --

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958
that we use to convey complex ideas, like I'm doing now, appeared around that time.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
We became much more social. The social networks expanded.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:18.958
This change in behavior allowed us to survive these worsening conditions in Africa,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:22.958
and they allowed us to start to expand around the world.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
We've been talking at this conference about African success stories.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
Well, you want the ultimate African success story?

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
Look in the mirror. You're it. The reason you're alive today

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
is because of those changes in our brains that took place in Africa --

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
probably somewhere in the region where we're sitting right now,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
around 60, 70 thousand years ago --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
allowing us not only to survive in Africa, but to expand out of Africa.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
An early coastal migration along the south coast of Asia,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
leaving Africa around 60,000 years ago,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.958
reaching Australia very rapidly, by 50,000 years ago.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
A slightly later migration up into the Middle East.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
These would have been savannah hunters.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
So those of you who are going on one of the post-conference tours,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
you'll get to see what a real savannah is like.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
And it's basically a meat locker.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
People who would have specialized in killing the animals,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
hunting the animals on those meat locker savannahs, moving up,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:14.958
following the grasslands into the Middle East around 45,000 years ago,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
during one of the rare wet phases in the Sahara.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
Migrating eastward, following the grasslands,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
because that's what they were adapted to live on.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
And when they reached Central Asia,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
they reached what was effectively a steppe super-highway,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
a grassland super-highway.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
The grasslands at that time -- this was during the last ice age --

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
stretched basically from Germany all the way over to Korea,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
and the entire continent was open to them.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
Entering Europe around 35,000 years ago,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
and finally, a small group migrating up

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
through the worst weather imaginable, Siberia,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
inside the Arctic Circle, during the last ice age --

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
temperature was at -70, -80, even -100, perhaps --

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:53.958
migrating into the Americas, ultimately reaching that final frontier.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
An amazing story, and it happened first in Africa.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
The changes that allowed us to do that,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
the evolution of this highly adaptable brain that we all carry around with us,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
allowing us to create novel cultures,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
allowing us to develop the diversity

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
that we see on a whirlwind trip like the one I've just been on.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958
Now, that story I just told you is literally a whirlwind tour

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:20.958
of how we populated the world, the great Paleolithic wanderings of our species.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
And that's the story that I told a couple of years ago

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:26.958
in my book, "The Journey of Man," and a film that we made with the same title.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
And as we were finishing up that film --

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
it was co-produced with National Geographic --

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
I started talking to the folks at NG about this work.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:38.958
And they got really excited about it. They liked the film, but they said,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
"You know, we really see this as kind of

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
the next wave in the study of human origins, where we all came from,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:49.958
using the tools of DNA to map the migrations around the world.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
You know, the study of human origins is kind of in our DNA,

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
and we want to take it to the next level.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
What do you want to do next?"

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Which is a great question to be asked by National Geographic.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:01.958
And I said, "Well, you know, what I've sketched out here is just that.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:05.958
It is a very coarse sketch of how we migrated around the planet.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
And it's based on a few thousand people we've sampled from,

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
you know, a handful of populations around the world.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:14.958
Studied a few genetic markers, and there are lots of gaps on this map.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:16.958
We've just connected the dots. What we need to do

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:20.958
is increase our sample size by an order of magnitude or more --

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:24.958
hundreds of thousands of DNA samples from people all over the world."

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:27.958
And that was the genesis of the Genographic Project.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
The project launched in April 2005.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:34.958
It has three core components. Obviously, science is a big part of it.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
The field research that we're doing around the world with indigenous peoples.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
People who have lived in the same location for a long period of time

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
retain a connection to the place where they live

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:44.958
that many of the rest of us have lost.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
So my ancestors come from all over northern Europe.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
I live in the Eastern Seaboard of North America when I'm not traveling.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
Where am I indigenous to? Nowhere really. My genes are all jumbled up.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
But there are people who retain that link to their ancestors

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
that allows us to contextualize the DNA results.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
That's the focus of the field research,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
the centers that we've set up all over the world --

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
10 of them, top population geneticists.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
But, in addition, we wanted to open up this study to anybody around the world.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:13.958
How often do you get to participate in a big scientific project?

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:15.958
The Human Genome Project, or a Mars Rover mission.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
In this case, you actually can.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:21.958
You can go onto our website, Nationalgeographic.com/genographic.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
You can order a kit. You can test your own DNA.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
And you can actually submit those results to the database,

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
and tell us a little about your genealogical background,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:33.958
have the data analyzed as part of the scientific effort.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:37.958
Now, this is all a nonprofit enterprise, and so the money that we raise,
