come in contact with magma, and come shooting out hot.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:50.958
We weren't really aware that it would be so rich with sulfides, hydrogen sulfides.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
We didn't have any idea about these things, which we call chimneys.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
This is one of these hydrothermal vents.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Six hundred degree F water coming out of the Earth.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
On either side of us are mountain ranges that are higher than the Alps,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
so the setting here is very dramatic.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
BL: The white material is a type of bacteria

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
that thrives at 180 degrees C.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
DG: I think that's one of the greatest stories right now

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
that we're seeing from the bottom of the sea,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
is that the first thing we see coming out of the sea floor

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
after a volcanic eruption is bacteria.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And we started to wonder for a long time,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
how did it all get down there?

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
What we find out now is that it's probably coming from inside the Earth.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Not only is it coming out of the Earth --

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
so, biogenesis made from volcanic activity --

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
but that bacteria supports these colonies of life.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
The pressure here is 4,000 pounds per square inch.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
A mile and a half from the surface to two miles to three miles --

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
no sun has ever gotten down here.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
All the energy to support these life forms

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
is coming from inside the Earth -- so, chemosynthesis.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And you can see how dense the population is.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
These are called tube worms.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
BL: These worms have no digestive system. They have no mouth.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
But they have two types of gill structures.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
One for extracting oxygen out of the deep-sea water,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
another one which houses this chemosynthetic bacteria,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
which takes the hydrothermal fluid --

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
that hot water that you saw coming out of the bottom --

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and converts that into simple sugars that the tube worm can digest.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
DG: You can see, here's a crab that lives down there.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
He's managed to grab a tip of these worms.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Now, they normally retract as soon as a crab touches them.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
Oh! Good going.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
So, as soon as a crab touches them,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
they retract down into their shells, just like your fingernails.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
There's a whole story being played out here

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
that we're just now beginning to have some idea of

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
because of this new camera technology.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
BL: These worms live in a real temperature extreme.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Their foot is at about 200 degrees C

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
and their head is out at three degrees C,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
so it's like having your hand in boiling water and your foot in freezing water.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
That's how they like to live.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
(Laughter)

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
DG: This is a female of this kind of worm.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
And here's a male.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
You watch. It doesn't take long before two guys here --

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
this one and one that will show up over here -- start to fight.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
Everything you see is played out in the pitch black of the deep sea.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
There are never any lights there, except the lights that we bring.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Here they go.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
On one of the last dive series,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
we counted 200 species in these areas --

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
198 were new, new species.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
BL: One of the big problems is that for the biologists

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
working at these sites, it's rather difficult to collect these animals.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And they disintegrate on the way up,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
so the imagery is critical for the science.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
DG: Two octopods at about two miles depth.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
This pressure thing really amazes me --

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
that these animals can exist there at a depth

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
with pressure enough to crush the Titanic like an empty Pepsi can.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
What we saw up till now was from the Pacific.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
This is from the Atlantic. Even greater depth.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
You can see this shrimp is harassing this poor little guy here,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and he'll bat it away with his claw. Whack!

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:43.958
(Laughter)

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
And the same thing's going on over here.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
What they're getting at is that -- on the back of this crab --

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
the foodstuff here is this very strange bacteria

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
that lives on the backs of all these animals.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And what these shrimp are trying to do

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
is actually harvest the bacteria from the backs of these animals.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
And the crabs don't like it at all.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
These long filaments that you see on the back of the crab

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
are actually created by the product of that bacteria.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
So, the bacteria grows hair on the crab.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
On the back, you see this again.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
The red dot is the laser light of the submarine Alvin

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
to give us an idea about how far away we are from the vents.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Those are all shrimp.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
You see the hot water over here, here and here, coming out.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
They're clinging to a rock face

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
and actually scraping bacteria off that rock face.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Here's a tiny, little vent that's come out of the side of that pillar.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
Those pillars get up to several stories.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
So here, you've got this valley with this incredible alien landscape

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
of pillars and hot springs and volcanic eruptions and earthquakes,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
inhabited by these very strange animals

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
that live only on chemical energy coming out of the ground.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
They don't need the sun at all.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
BL: You see this white V-shaped mark on the back of the shrimp?

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
It's actually a light-sensing organ.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
It's how they find the hydrothermal vents.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
The vents are emitting a black body radiation -- an IR signature --

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:59.958
and so they're able to find these vents at considerable distances.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
DG: All this stuff is happening along that 40,000-mile long mountain range

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
that we're calling the ribbon of life, because just even today,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
as we speak, there's life being generated there from volcanic activity.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
This is the first time we've ever tried this any place.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
We're going to try to show you high definition from the Pacific.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
We're moving up one of these pillars.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
This one's several stories tall.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
In it, you'll see that it's a habitat for a lot of different animals.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
There's a funny kind of hot plate here, with vent water coming out of it.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
So all of these are individual homes for worms.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Now here's a closer view of that community.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Here's crabs here, worms here.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
There are smaller animals crawling around.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
Here's pagoda structures.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
I think this is the neatest-looking thing.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
I just can't get over this --

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that you've got these little chimneys sitting here smoking away.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
This stuff is toxic as hell, by the way.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
You could never get a permit to dump this in the ocean,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
and it's coming out all from it.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
(Laughter)

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
It's unbelievable. It's basically sulfuric acid,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and it's being just dumped out, at incredible rates.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
And animals are thriving -- and we probably came from here.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
That's probably where we evolved from.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
BL: This bacteria that we've been talking about

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
turns out to be the most simplest form of life found.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
There are a number of groups that are proposing

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
that life evolved at these vent sites.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Although the vent sites are short-lived --

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.958
an individual site may last only 10 years or so --

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:24.958
as an ecosystem they've been stable for millions -- well, billions -- of years.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
DG: It works too well. You see there're some fish inside here as well.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
There's a fish sitting here.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Here's a crab with his claw right at the end of that tube worm,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
waiting for that worm to stick his head out.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
(Laughter)

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
BL: The biologists right now cannot explain

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
why these animals are so active.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
The worms are growing inches per week!

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
DG: I already said that this site,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
from a human perspective, is toxic as hell.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Not only that, but on top -- the lifeblood --

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
that plumbing system turns off every year or so.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Their plumbing system turns off, so the sites have to move.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
And then there's earthquakes,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
and then volcanic eruptions, on the order of one every five years,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
that completely wipes the area out.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
Despite that, these animals grow back in about a year's time.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
You're talking about biodensities and biodiversity, again,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
higher than the rainforest that just springs back to life.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Is it sensitive? Yes.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Is it fragile? No, it's not really very fragile.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I'll end up with saying one thing.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
There's a story in the sea, in the waters of the sea,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
in the sediments and the rocks of the sea floor.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
It's an incredible story.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
What we see when we look back in time,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
in those sediments and rocks, is a record of Earth history.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Everything on this planet -- everything -- works by cycles and rhythms.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
The continents move apart. They come back together.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Oceans come and go. Mountains come and go. Glaciers come and go.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
El Nino comes and goes. It's not a disaster, it's rhythmic.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
What we're learning now, it's almost like a symphony.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
It's just like music -- it really is just like music.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
And what we're learning now is that

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
you can't listen to a five-billion-year long symphony, get to today and say,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
"Stop! We want tomorrow's note to be the same as it was today."

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
It's absurd. It's just absurd.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
So, what we've got to learn now is to find out where this planet's going

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
at all these different scales and work with it.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
Learn to manage it.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
The concept of preservation is futile.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Conservation's tougher, but we can probably get there.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Thank you very much.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Thank you.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:16.958
(Applause)

title: Once upon a time, my mother ...
transcript: When I knew I was going to come to speak to you, I thought, "I gotta call my mother." I have a little Cuban mother — she's about that big. Four feet. Nothing larger than the sum of her figurative parts. You still with me? (Laughter) I called her up. "Hello, how're you doing, baby?" "Hey, ma, I got to talk to you." "You're talking to me already. What's the matter?" I said, "I've got to talk to a bunch of nice people." "You're always talking to nice people, except when you went to the White House." "Ma, don't start!" And I told her I was coming to TED, and she said, "What's the problem?" And I said, "Well, I'm not sure." I said, "I have to talk to them about stories. It's 'Technology, Entertainment and Design.'" And she said, "Well, you design a story when you make it up, it's entertainment when you tell it, and you're going to use a microphone." (Laughter) I said, "You're a peach, ma. Pop there?" "What's the matter? The pearls of wisdom leaping from my lips like lemmings is no good for you?" (Laughter) Then my pop got on there. My pop, he's one of the old souls, you know — old Cuban man from Camaguey. Camaguey is a province in Cuba. He's from Florida. He was born there in 1924. He grew up in a bohio of dirt floors, and the structure was the kind used by the Tainos, our old Arawak ancestors. My father is at once quick-witted, wickedly funny, and then poignancy turns on a dime and leaves you breathless. "Papi, help." "I already heard your mother. I think she's right." (Laughter) "After what I just told you?" My whole life, my father's been there. So we talked for a few minutes, and he said, "Why don't you tell them what you believe?" I love that, but we don't have the time. Good storytelling is crafting a story that someone wants to listen to. Great story is the art of letting go. So I'm going to tell you a little story. Remember, this tradition comes to us not from the mists of Avalon, back in time, but further still, before we were scratching out these stories on papyrus, or we were doing the pictographs on walls in moist, damp caves. Back then, we had an urge, a need, to tell the story. When Lexus wants to sell you a car, they're telling you a story. Have you been watching the commercials? Because every one of us has this desire, for once — just once — to tell our story and have it heard. There are stories you tell from stages. There's stories that you may tell in a small group of people with some good wine. And there's stories you tell late at night to a friend, maybe once in your life. And then there are stories that we whisper into a Stygian darkness. I'm not telling you that story. I'm telling you this one. It's called, "You're Going to Miss Me." It's about human connection. My Cuban mother, which I just briefly introduced you to in that short character sketch, came to the United States one thousand years ago. I was born in 19 — I forget, and I came to this country with them in the aftermath of the Cuban revolution. We went from Havana, Cuba to Decatur, Georgia. And Decatur, Georgia's a small Southern town. And in that little Southern town, I grew up, and grew up hearing these stories. But this story only happened a few years ago. I called my mom. It was a Saturday morning. And I was calling about how to make ajiaco. It's a Cuban meal. It's delicious. It's savory. It makes spit froth in the little corners of your mouth — is that enough? It makes your armpits juicy, you know? That kind of food, yeah. This is the sensory part of the program, people. I called my mother, and she said, "Carmen, I need you to come, please. I need to go to the mall, and you know your father now, he takes a nap in the afternoon, and I got to go. I got an errand to run." Let me parenthetically pause here and tell you — Esther, my mother, had stopped driving several years ago, to the collective relief of the entire city of Atlanta. Any vehicular outing with that woman from the time I was a young child, guys, naturally included flashing, blue lights. But she'd become adept at dodging the boys in blue, and when she did meet them, oh, she had wonderful, well, rapport. "Ma'am, did you know that was a light you just ran?" (Spanish) "You don't speak English?" "No." (Laughter) But eventually, every dog has its day, and she ended up in traffic court, where she bartered with the judge for a discount. There's a historical marker. But now she was a septuagenarian, she'd stopped driving. And that meant that everyone in the family had to sign up to take her to have her hair dyed, you know, that peculiar color of blue that matches her polyester pants suit, you know, same color as the Buick. Anybody? All right. Little picks on the legs, where she does her needlepoint, and leaves little loops. Rockports — they're for this. That's why they call them that. (Laughter) This is her ensemble. And this is the woman that wants me to come on a Saturday morning when I have a lot to do, but it doesn't take long because Cuban guilt is a weighty thing. I'm not going political on you but ... And so, I go to my mother's. I show up. She's in the carport. Of course, they have a carport. The kind with the corrugated roof, you know. The Buick's parked outside, and she's jingling, jangling a pair of keys. "I got a surprise for you, baby!" "We taking your car?" "Not we, I." And she reaches into her pocket and pulls out a catastrophe. Somebody's storytelling. Interactive art. You can talk to me. Oh, a driver's license, a perfectly valid driver's license. Issued, evidently, by the DMV in her own county of Gwinnett. Blithering fucking idiots. (Laughter) I said, "Is that thing real?" "I think so." "Can you even see?" "I guess I must." "Oh, Jesus." She gets into the car — she's sitting on two phone books. I can't even make this part up because she's that tiny. She's engineered an umbrella so she can — bam! — slam the door. Her daughter, me, the village idiot with the ice cream cone in the middle of her forehead, is still standing there, slack-jawed. "You coming? You no coming?" "Oh, my God." I said, "OK, fine. Does pop know you're driving?" "Are you kidding me?" "How are you doing it?" "He's got to sleep sometime." And so we left my father fast asleep, because I knew he'd kill me if I let her go by herself, and we get in the car. Puts it in reverse. Fifty-five out of the driveway, in reverse. I am buckling in seatbelts from the front. I'm yanking them in from the back. I'm doing double knots. I mean, I've got a mouth as dry as the Kalahari Desert. I've got a white-knuckle grip on the door. You know what I'm talking about? And she's whistling, and finally I do the kind of birth breathing — you know, that one? Only a couple of women are going uh-huh, uh-huh, uh-huh. Right. And I said, "Ma, would you slow down?" Because now she's picked up the Highway 285, the perimeter around Atlanta, which encompasses now — there's seven lanes, she's on all of them, y'all. I said, "Ma, pick a lane!" "They give you seven lanes, they expect you to use them." And there she goes, right. I don't believe for a minute she has been out and not been stopped. So, I think, hey, we can talk. It'll be a diversion. It'll help my breathing. It'll do something for my pulse, maybe. "Mommy, I know you have been stopped." "No, no, what you talking about?" "You have a license. How long have you been driving?" "Four or five days." "Yeah. And you haven't been stopped?" "I did not get a ticket." I said, "Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, but come on, come on, come on." "OK, so I stopped at a light and there's a guy, you know, in the back." "Would this guy have, like, a blue uniform and a terrified look on his face?" "You weren't there, don't start." "Come on. You got a ticket?" "No." She explained, "The man" — I have to tell you as she did, because it loses something if I don't, you know — "he come to the window, and he does a thing like this, which tells me he's pretty old, you know. So I look up and I'm thinking, maybe he's still going to think I'm kind of cute." "Ma, are you still doing that?" "If it works, it works, baby. So, I say, 'Perdon, yo no hablo ingles.' Well, wouldn't you know, he had been in Honduras for the Peace Corps." (Laughter) So he's talking to her, and at some point she says, "Then, you know, it was it. That was it. It was done." "Yeah? What? He gave you a ticket? He didn't give you a ticket? What?" "No, I look up, and the light, she change." (Laughter) You should be terrified. Now, I don't know if she's toying with me, kind of like a cat batting back a mouse, batting back a mouse — left paw, right paw, left paw, right paw — but by now, we've reached the mall. Now, you have all been at a mall during the holidays, yes? Talk to me. Yes. Yes. You can say yes. Audience: Yes. Carmen Agra Deedy: All right, then you know that you have now entered parking lot purgatory, praying to that saint of perpetual availability that as you join that serpentine line of cars crawling along, some guy's going to turn on the brake lights just as you pull up behind him. But that doesn't happen most of the time, right? So, first I say, "Ma, why are we here?" "You mean, like, in the car?" "No, don't — why are we here today? It's Saturday. It's the holidays." "Because I have to exchange your father's underwear." Now, see, this is the kind of Machiavellian thinking, that you really have to — you know, in my mind, it's a rabbit's warren, this woman's mind. Do I want to walk in, because unless I have Ariadne's thread to anchor — enough metaphors for you? — somewhere, I may not get out. But you know. (Laughter) "Why do we have to take pop's underwear back now? And why? What is wrong with his underwear?" "It will upset you." "It won't upset me. Why? What? Is something wrong with him?" "No, no, no. The only thing with him is, he's an idiot. I sent him to the store, which was my first mistake, and he went to buy underwear, and he bought the grippers, and he's supposed to buy the boxers." "Why?" "I read it on the Intersnet. You cannot have children." "Oh, my God!" (Laughter) Olivia? Huh? Huh? By now, we have now crawled another four feet, and my mother finally says to me, "I knew it, I knew it. I'm an immigrant. We make a space. What I tell you? Right there." And she points out the passenger window, and I look out, and three — three — aisles down, "Look, the Chevy." You want to laugh, but you don't know — you're that politically corrected, have you noticed? Correct the other direction now, it's OK. "Look, the Chevy — he's coming this way." "Mama, mama, mama, wait, wait, wait. The Chevy is three aisles away." She looks at me like I'm her, you know, her moron child, the cretin, the one she's got to speak to very slowly and distinctly. "I know that, honey. Get out of the car and go stand in the parking space till I get there." OK, I want a vote. Come on, come on. No, no. How many of you once in your — you were a kid, you were an adult — you stood in a parking space to hold it for someone? See, we're a secret club with a secret handshake. (Laughter) And years of therapy later, we're doing great. We're doing great. We're doing fine. Well, I stood up to her. This is — you know, you'd think by now I'm — and still holding? I said, "No way, ma, you have embarrassed me my entire life." Of course, her comeback is, "When have I embarrassed you?" (Spanish) And she's still talking while she puts the car in park, hits the emergency brake, opens the door, and with a spryness astounding in a woman her age, she jumps out of the car, knocks out the phone books, and then she walks around — she's carrying her cheap Kmart purse with her — around the front of the car. She has amazing land speed for a woman her age, too. Before I know it, she has skiddled across the parking lot and in between the cars, and people behind me, with that kind of usual religious charity that the holidays bring us, wah-wah wah-wah. "I'm coming." Italian hand signals follow. I scoot over. I close the door. I leave the phone books. This is new and fast, just so you — are you still with us? We'll wait for the slow ones. OK. I start, and this is where a child says to me — and the story doesn't work if I tell you about her before, because this is my laconic child. A brevity, brevity of everything with this child. You know, she eats small portions. Language is something to be meted out in small phonemes, you know — just little hmm, hmm-hmm. She carries a mean spiral notebook and a pen. She wields great power. She listens, because that's what people who tell stories do first. But she pauses occasionally and says, "How do you spell that? What year? OK." When she writes the expose in about 20 years, don't believe a word of it. But this is my daughter, Lauren, my remarkable daughter, my borderline Asperger's kid. Bless you, Dr. Watson. She says, "Ma, you got to look!" Now, when this kid says I got to look, you know. But it isn't like I haven't seen this crime scene before. I grew up with this woman. I said, "Lauren, you know what, give me a play-by-play. I can't." "No, mama, you got to look." I got to look. You got to look. Don't you want to look? There she is. I look in bewildered awe: she's standing, those Rockports slightly apart, but grounded. She's holding out that cheap Kmart purse, and she is wielding it. She's holding back tons of steel with the sheer force of her little personality, in that crone-ish voice, saying things like, "Back it up, buddy! No, it's reserved!" (Laughter) Ready? Brace yourselves. Here it comes. "No, my daughter, she's coming in the Buick. Honey, sit up so they can see you." Oh, Jesus. Oh, Jesus. I finally come — and now, it's the South. I don't know what part of the country you live in. I think we all secretly love stories. We all secretly want our blankie and our Boo Bear. We want to curl up and say, "Tell it to me, tell it to me. Come on, honey, tell it to me." But in the South, we love a good story. People have pulled aside, I mean, they've come out of that queue line, they have popped their trunks, pulled out lawn chairs and cool drinks. Bets are placed. "I'm with the little lady. Damn!" (Laughter) And she's bringing me in with a slight salsa movement. She is, after all, Cuban. I'm thinking, "Accelerator, break. Accelerator, break." Like you've never thought that in your life? Right? Yeah. I pull in. I put the car in park. Engine's still running — mine, not the car. I jump out next to her going, "Don't you move!" "I'm not going anywhere." She's got front seat in a Greek tragedy. I come out, and there's Esther. She's hugging the purse. "Que?" Which means "what," and so much more. (Laughter) "Ma, have you no shame? People are watching us all around," right? Now, some of them you've got to make up, people. Secret of the trade. Guess what? Some of these stories I sculpt a little, here and there. Some, they're just right there, right there. Put them right there. She says this to me. After I say — let me refresh you — "have you no shame?" "No. I gave it up with pantyhose — they're both too binding." (Laughter) (Applause) Yeah, you can clap, but then you're about 30 seconds from the end. I'm about to snap like a brittle twig, when suddenly someone taps me on the shoulder. Intrepid soul. I'm thinking, "This is my kid. How dare she? She jumped out of that car." That's OK, because my mother yells at me, I yell at her. It's a beautiful hierarchy, and it works. (Laughter) I turn around, but it's not a child. It's a young woman, a little taller than I, pale green, amused eyes. With her is a young man — husband, brother, lover, it's not my job. And she says, "Pardon me, ma'am" — that's how we talk down there — "is that your mother?" I said, "No, I follow little old women around parking lots to see if they'll stop. Yes, it's my mother!" The boy, now, he says. "Well, what my sister meant" — they look at each other, it's a knowing glance — "God, she's crazy!" I said, (Spanish), and the young girl and the young boy say, "No, no, honey, we just want to know one more thing." I said, "Look, please, let me take care of her, OK, because I know her, and believe me, she's like a small atomic weapon, you know, you just want to handle her really gingerly." And the girl goes, "I know, but, I mean, I swear to God, she reminds us of our mother." I almost miss it. He turns to her on the heel of his shoe. It's a half-whisper, "God, I miss her." They turn then, shoulder to shoulder, and walk away, lost in their own reverie. Memories of some maddening woman who was the luck of their DNA draw. And I turn to Esther, who's rocking on those 'ports, and says, "You know what, honey?" "What, ma?" "I'm going to drive you crazy probably for about 14, 15 more years, if you're lucky, but after that, honey, you're going to miss me." (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:16.958
When I knew I was going to come to speak to you, I thought,

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:19.958
"I gotta call my mother."

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
I have a little Cuban mother -- she's about that big.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
Four feet. Nothing larger than the sum of her figurative parts.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
You still with me? (Laughter)

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:28.958
I called her up.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
"Hello, how're you doing, baby?"

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
"Hey, ma, I got to talk to you."

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
"You're talking to me already. What's the matter?"

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
I said, "I've got to talk to a bunch of nice people."

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
"You're always talking to nice people, except when you went

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:39.958
to the White House."

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
"Ma, don't start!"

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
And I told her I was coming to TED, and she said,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:47.958
"What's the problem?"

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
And I said, "Well, I'm not sure."

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:54.958
I said, "I have to talk to them about stories.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
It's 'Technology, Entertainment and Design.'"

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:05.958
And she said, "Well, you design a story when you make it up,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
it's entertainment when you tell it,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
and you're going to use a microphone."

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
(Laughter)

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
I said, "You're a peach, ma. Pop there?"

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
"What's the matter? The pearls of wisdom

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
leaping from my lips like lemmings is no good for you?"

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
(Laughter)

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:22.958
Then my pop got on there.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
My pop, he's one of the old souls, you know --

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
old Cuban man from Camaguey.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
Camaguey is a province in Cuba.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
He's from Florida.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
He was born there in 1924.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:38.958
He grew up in a bohio of dirt floors,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and the structure was the kind used by the Tainos,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
our old Arawak ancestors.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:50.958
My father is at once quick-witted, wickedly funny,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:59.958
and then poignancy turns on a dime and leaves you breathless.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
"Papi, help."

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
"I already heard your mother. I think she's right."

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
(Laughter)

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
"After what I just told you?"

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
My whole life, my father's been there.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
So we talked for a few minutes, and he said,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
"Why don't you tell them what you believe?"

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
I love that, but we don't have the time.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:24.958
Good storytelling is crafting a story that someone wants to listen to.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
Great story is the art of letting go.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
So I'm going to tell you a little story.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
Remember, this tradition comes to us

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
not from the mists of Avalon, back in time, but further still,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
before we were scratching out these stories on papyrus,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:46.958
or we were doing the pictographs on walls in moist, damp caves.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Back then, we had an urge, a need, to tell the story.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
When Lexus wants to sell you a car, they're telling you a story.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
Have you been watching the commercials?

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:01.958
Because every one of us has this desire, for once -- just once --

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
to tell our story and have it heard.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
There are stories you tell from stages.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:12.958
There's stories that you may tell

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
in a small group of people with some good wine.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And there's stories you tell late at night to a friend,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
maybe once in your life.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:32.958
And then there are stories that we whisper into a Stygian darkness.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
I'm not telling you that story.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
I'm telling you this one.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
It's called, "You're Going to Miss Me."

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
It's about human connection.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
My Cuban mother, which I just briefly introduced you to

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
in that short character sketch,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
came to the United States one thousand years ago.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
I was born in 19 -- I forget, and I came to this country

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
with them in the aftermath of the Cuban revolution.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
We went from Havana, Cuba to Decatur, Georgia.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
And Decatur, Georgia's a small Southern town.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
And in that little Southern town, I grew up,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
and grew up hearing these stories.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
But this story only happened a few years ago.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
I called my mom.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
It was a Saturday morning.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
And I was calling about how to make ajiaco. It's a Cuban meal.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
It's delicious. It's savory.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
It makes spit froth in the little corners of your mouth --

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
is that enough? It makes your armpits juicy, you know?

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
That kind of food, yeah.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
This is the sensory part of the program, people.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
I called my mother, and she said, "Carmen, I need you to come, please.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
I need to go to the mall, and you know your father now,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
he takes a nap in the afternoon, and I got to go.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:38.958
I got an errand to run."

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
Let me parenthetically pause here and tell you --

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Esther, my mother, had stopped driving several years ago,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
to the collective relief of the entire city of Atlanta.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Any vehicular outing with that woman from the time I was a young child,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:51.958
guys, naturally included flashing, blue lights.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
But she'd become adept at dodging the boys in blue,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:02.958
and when she did meet them, oh, she had wonderful, well, rapport.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
"Ma'am, did you know that was a light you just ran?"

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
(Spanish)

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
"You don't speak English?"

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
"No."

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:14.958
(Laughter)

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
But eventually, every dog has its day,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and she ended up in traffic court,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
where she bartered with the judge for a discount.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
There's a historical marker.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
But now she was a septuagenarian, she'd stopped driving.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
And that meant that everyone in the family had to sign up

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
to take her to have her hair dyed, you know,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
that peculiar color of blue that matches her polyester pants suit,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
you know, same color as the Buick.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
Anybody? All right.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Little picks on the legs, where she does her needlepoint, and leaves little loops.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Rockports -- they're for this.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
That's why they call them that.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:49.958
(Laughter)

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
This is her ensemble.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
And this is the woman that wants me to come on a Saturday morning

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:58.958
when I have a lot to do, but it doesn't take long because Cuban guilt is a weighty thing.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
I'm not going political on you but ... And so, I go to my mother's.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
I show up. She's in the carport.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:05.958
Of course, they have a carport.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
The kind with the corrugated roof, you know.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:08.958
The Buick's parked outside,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
and she's jingling, jangling a pair of keys.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
"I got a surprise for you, baby!"

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
"We taking your car?"

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
"Not we, I."

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
And she reaches into her pocket and pulls out a catastrophe.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Somebody's storytelling. Interactive art. You can talk to me.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Oh, a driver's license, a perfectly valid driver's license.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Issued, evidently, by the DMV in her own county of Gwinnett.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Blithering fucking idiots.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:33.958
(Laughter)

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:34.958
I said, "Is that thing real?"

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:35.958
"I think so."

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
"Can you even see?"

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:37.958
"I guess I must."

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:38.958
"Oh, Jesus."

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
She gets into the car -- she's sitting on two phone books.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
I can't even make this part up because she's that tiny.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
She's engineered an umbrella so she can -- bam! -- slam the door.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Her daughter, me, the village idiot with the ice cream cone

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
in the middle of her forehead, is still standing there, slack-jawed.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:52.958
"You coming? You no coming?"

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
"Oh, my God." I said, "OK, fine. Does pop know you're driving?"

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
"Are you kidding me?"

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:58.958
"How are you doing it?"

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
"He's got to sleep sometime."

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
And so we left my father fast asleep, because I knew he'd kill me

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
if I let her go by herself, and we get in the car.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
Puts it in reverse. Fifty-five out of the driveway, in reverse.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
I am buckling in seatbelts from the front.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
I'm yanking them in from the back. I'm doing double knots.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
I mean, I've got a mouth as dry as the Kalahari Desert.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
I've got a white-knuckle grip on the door. You know what I'm talking about?

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.958
And she's whistling, and finally I do the kind of

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
birth breathing -- you know, that one?

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
Only a couple of women are going uh-huh, uh-huh, uh-huh. Right.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:29.958
And I said, "Ma, would you slow down?"

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Because now she's picked up the Highway 285,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
the perimeter around Atlanta, which encompasses now --

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
there's seven lanes, she's on all of them, y'all.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
I said, "Ma, pick a lane!"

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
"They give you seven lanes, they expect you to use them."

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
And there she goes, right.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
I don't believe for a minute she has been out and not been stopped.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
So, I think, hey, we can talk. It'll be a diversion.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
It'll help my breathing. It'll do something for my pulse, maybe.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
"Mommy, I know you have been stopped."

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
"No, no, what you talking about?"

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:58.958
"You have a license. How long have you been driving?"

00:07:58.958 --> 00:07:59.958
"Four or five days."

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:00.958
"Yeah. And you haven't been stopped?"

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
"I did not get a ticket."

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:07.958
I said, "Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, but come on, come on, come on."

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
"OK, so I stopped at a light

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and there's a guy, you know, in the back."

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
"Would this guy have, like, a blue uniform

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
and a terrified look on his face?"

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:16.958
"You weren't there, don't start."

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
"Come on. You got a ticket?"

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
"No." She explained,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
"The man" -- I have to tell you as she did,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
because it loses something if I don't, you know --

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
"he come to the window, and he does a thing like this,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
which tells me he's pretty old, you know.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
So I look up and I'm thinking,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
maybe he's still going to think I'm kind of cute."

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:39.958
"Ma, are you still doing that?"

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
"If it works, it works, baby.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
So, I say, 'Perdon, yo no hablo ingles.'

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Well, wouldn't you know, he had been in Honduras for the Peace Corps."

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
(Laughter)

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
So he's talking to her, and at some point she says,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
"Then, you know, it was it. That was it. It was done."

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
"Yeah? What?

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
He gave you a ticket? He didn't give you a ticket? What?"

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
"No, I look up, and the light, she change."

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
(Laughter)

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:07.958
You should be terrified.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Now, I don't know if she's toying with me,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
kind of like a cat batting back a mouse, batting back a mouse --

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
left paw, right paw, left paw, right paw --

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
but by now, we've reached the mall.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
Now, you have all been at a mall during the holidays, yes?

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Talk to me. Yes. Yes. You can say yes.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:21.958
Audience: Yes.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Carmen Agra Deedy: All right, then you know that you have now entered parking lot purgatory,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
praying to that saint of perpetual availability

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
that as you join that serpentine line of cars crawling along,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
some guy's going to turn on the brake lights

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:32.958
just as you pull up behind him.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
But that doesn't happen most of the time, right?

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
So, first I say, "Ma, why are we here?"

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:38.958
"You mean, like, in the car?"

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
"No, don't -- why are we here today?

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:45.958
It's Saturday. It's the holidays."

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
"Because I have to exchange your father's underwear."

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Now, see, this is the kind of Machiavellian thinking,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
that you really have to -- you know, in my mind, it's a rabbit's warren,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:53.958
this woman's mind.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Do I want to walk in, because unless I have Ariadne's thread to anchor --

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
enough metaphors for you? -- somewhere, I may not get out.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:01.958
But you know.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:05.958
(Laughter)

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
"Why do we have to take pop's underwear back now?

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And why? What is wrong with his underwear?"

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:11.958
"It will upset you."

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
"It won't upset me. Why? What? Is something wrong with him?"

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
"No, no, no. The only thing with him is, he's an idiot.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
I sent him to the store, which was my first mistake,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and he went to buy underwear, and he bought the grippers,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and he's supposed to buy the boxers."

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:26.958
"Why?"

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
"I read it on the Intersnet. You cannot have children."

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:30.958
"Oh, my God!"

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
(Laughter)

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
Olivia? Huh? Huh?

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
By now, we have now crawled another four feet,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and my mother finally says to me, "I knew it, I knew it.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
I'm an immigrant. We make a space. What I tell you? Right there."

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
And she points out the passenger window, and I look out,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and three -- three -- aisles down,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
"Look, the Chevy."

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
You want to laugh, but you don't know --

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
you're that politically corrected, have you noticed?

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Correct the other direction now, it's OK.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:03.958
"Look, the Chevy -- he's coming this way."

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
"Mama, mama, mama, wait, wait, wait. The Chevy is three aisles away."

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
She looks at me like I'm her, you know, her moron child,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
the cretin, the one she's got to speak to very slowly and distinctly.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
"I know that, honey. Get out of the car

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and go stand in the parking space till I get there."

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
OK, I want a vote. Come on, come on. No, no.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
How many of you once in your -- you were a kid, you were an adult --

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
you stood in a parking space to hold it for someone?

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
See, we're a secret club with a secret handshake.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
(Laughter)

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And years of therapy later, we're doing great.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
We're doing great. We're doing fine.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Well, I stood up to her.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:42.958
This is -- you know, you'd think by now I'm -- and still holding?

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
I said, "No way, ma, you have embarrassed me my entire life."

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Of course, her comeback is, "When have I embarrassed you?"

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
(Spanish)

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
And she's still talking while she puts the car in park,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
hits the emergency brake, opens the door,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and with a spryness astounding in a woman her age,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
she jumps out of the car, knocks out the phone books,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:02.958
and then she walks around --

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
she's carrying her cheap Kmart purse with her --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
around the front of the car.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
She has amazing land speed for a woman her age, too.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Before I know it, she has skiddled across the parking lot

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and in between the cars, and people behind me, with that kind of

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:19.958
usual religious charity that the holidays bring us, wah-wah wah-wah.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
"I'm coming." Italian hand signals follow.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
I scoot over. I close the door. I leave the phone books.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
This is new and fast, just so you -- are you still with us?

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
We'll wait for the slow ones. OK.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
I start, and this is where a child says to me --

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and the story doesn't work if I tell you about her before,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
because this is my laconic child.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
A brevity, brevity of everything with this child.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
You know, she eats small portions.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
Language is something to be meted out

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:48.958
in small phonemes, you know -- just little hmm, hmm-hmm.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
She carries a mean spiral notebook and a pen.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
She wields great power.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:58.958
She listens, because that's what people who tell stories do first.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
But she pauses occasionally and says,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
"How do you spell that? What year? OK."

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
When she writes the expose in about 20 years,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:08.958
don't believe a word of it.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
But this is my daughter, Lauren, my remarkable daughter,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
my borderline Asperger's kid.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
Bless you, Dr. Watson.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
She says, "Ma, you got to look!"

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
Now, when this kid says I got to look, you know.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
But it isn't like I haven't seen this crime scene before.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
I grew up with this woman.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
I said, "Lauren, you know what, give me a play-by-play. I can't."

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:32.958
"No, mama, you got to look."

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
I got to look. You got to look.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
Don't you want to look?

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
There she is.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
I look in bewildered awe:

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
she's standing, those Rockports slightly apart, but grounded.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
She's holding out that cheap Kmart purse, and she is wielding it.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:54.958
She's holding back tons of steel with the sheer force

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
of her little personality, in that crone-ish voice, saying things like,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
"Back it up, buddy! No, it's reserved!"

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
(Laughter)

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Ready? Brace yourselves. Here it comes.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
"No, my daughter, she's coming in the Buick.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Honey, sit up so they can see you."

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Oh, Jesus. Oh, Jesus.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
I finally come -- and now, it's the South.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
I don't know what part of the country you live in.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
I think we all secretly love stories.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
We all secretly want our blankie and our Boo Bear.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:23.958
We want to curl up and say, "Tell it to me, tell it to me.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Come on, honey, tell it to me."

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
But in the South, we love a good story.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
People have pulled aside,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
I mean, they've come out of that queue line,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
they have popped their trunks, pulled out lawn chairs and cool drinks.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Bets are placed.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
"I'm with the little lady. Damn!"

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
(Laughter)

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And she's bringing me in with a slight salsa movement.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
She is, after all, Cuban.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
I'm thinking, "Accelerator, break. Accelerator, break."

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Like you've never thought that in your life? Right? Yeah.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
I pull in. I put the car in park.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
Engine's still running -- mine, not the car.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
I jump out next to her going, "Don't you move!"

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
"I'm not going anywhere."

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
She's got front seat in a Greek tragedy.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
I come out, and there's Esther.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
She's hugging the purse.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
"Que?" Which means "what," and so much more.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:14.958
(Laughter)

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
"Ma, have you no shame?

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
People are watching us all around," right?

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
Now, some of them you've got to make up, people.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Secret of the trade.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:27.958
Guess what? Some of these stories I sculpt a little, here and there.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
Some, they're just right there, right there. Put them right there.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
She says this to me.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
After I say -- let me refresh you --

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
"have you no shame?"

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:44.958
"No. I gave it up with pantyhose -- they're both too binding."

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
(Laughter)

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
(Applause)

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Yeah, you can clap, but then you're about 30 seconds from the end.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
I'm about to snap like a brittle twig, when suddenly someone taps me on the shoulder.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Intrepid soul.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
I'm thinking, "This is my kid. How dare she?

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
She jumped out of that car."

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
That's OK, because my mother yells at me, I yell at her.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
It's a beautiful hierarchy, and it works.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:10.958
(Laughter)

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
I turn around, but it's not a child. It's a young woman,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
a little taller than I, pale green, amused eyes.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
With her is a young man -- husband, brother, lover, it's not my job.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
And she says, "Pardon me, ma'am" -- that's how we talk down there --

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
"is that your mother?"

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
I said, "No, I follow little old women around parking lots

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
to see if they'll stop. Yes, it's my mother!"

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
The boy, now, he says. "Well, what my sister meant" --

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:36.958
they look at each other, it's a knowing glance -- "God, she's crazy!"

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:40.958
I said, (Spanish), and the young girl and the young boy say,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
"No, no, honey, we just want to know one more thing."

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
I said, "Look, please, let me take care of her, OK,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
because I know her, and believe me, she's like a small atomic weapon,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
you know, you just want to handle her really gingerly."

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And the girl goes, "I know, but, I mean, I swear to God,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
she reminds us of our mother."

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
I almost miss it.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
He turns to her on the heel of his shoe.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:07.958
It's a half-whisper, "God, I miss her."

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
They turn then, shoulder to shoulder, and walk away,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
lost in their own reverie.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Memories of some maddening woman who was the luck of their DNA draw.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:23.958
And I turn to Esther, who's rocking on those 'ports, and says,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:24.958
"You know what, honey?"

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:25.958
"What, ma?"

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
"I'm going to drive you crazy probably for about 14, 15 more years,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:36.958
if you're lucky, but after that, honey, you're going to miss me."

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:45.958
(Applause)

title: The camel's hump
transcript: [SHIT]This is arguably the back end of the design of animals.(Laughter)But the reason I put this up here is because when I was in Africa last year, my wife and I were driving around, we had this wonderful guide, who showed us something that surprised both of us, and it was very revealing in terms of the fascination that comes with the design of animals. It turns out that in about the 1880s, the missionaries came to Africa to spread the word of Christianity, to teach English to the natives. And they brought blackboards and chalk. And I'd like you to imagine that that's a blackboard, and I just used some chalk on there. And they brought quite a bit of this stuff. But over the years, the blackboards were fine, but they ran out of chalk. And this is a real crisis for them.And that's where the hyena comes in. The hyena is probably the most perfectly designed scavenging animal in the world. It strip-mines carcasses, and it has amazing teeth, because it enables the hyena to essentially eat bones. Now, the end product of that action is up on the board here. What the missionaries would do is, they'd walk around and they'd pick up hyena shit. And the incredible thing about hyena shit is, it makes great chalk.(Laughter)That's not what I'm here to talk about, but it is a fascinating aspect of animal design. What I'm here to talk about is the camel. When I started talking to Richard about what I was going to speak about, I had recently come back from Jordan, where I had an amazing experience with a camel.(Laughter)And we were in the desert.Richard Wurman: That's the end! Keith Bellows: Yeah, yeah.We were in the desert, in Wadi Rum, in a small Jeep. There were four of us, two Bedouin drivers. You can just imagine, this expanse is an ocean of sand, 105 degrees, one water bottle. And we were driving in what they told us was their very, very best Jeep. Didn't look like it to me. And as we started to go through the desert, the Jeep broke down. The guys got out, they put the hood up, they started working under the hood, got it going again. About a hundred yards, it broke down. This went on about 6-7 times, we were getting more and more alarmed, we were also getting deeper and deeper into the desert.And eventually, our worst nightmare happened: they flooded the engine. And they said, "Ah, no problem! We just get out and walk." And we said, "We get out and walk?" One water bottle, remember, guys, four people. And they said, "Yeah, yeah, we'll walk. We'll find some camels." We got out and walked, and sure enough, about half a mile, we came over the crest of this hill, and there was a huge gathering of Bedouin with their camels. The guy went up and started dickering, and 10 dollars later, we had four camels. They went down like elevators; we got on them. They went back up, and the Bedouin, each Bedouin, four of them, got behind each of the camels with a little whip. And they started slashing away at the back of the camels, and they started galloping. And if you've ever been on a camel, it is a very, very uncomfortable ride. There's also one other aspect about these camels. About every 10 steps, they lean back and try to take a chunk out of your leg.(Laughter)So we kept on going, and this camel kept on trying to take a chunk out of my leg. And eventually, three miles later, we arrived at our destination, where a Jeep was supposed to meet us. And the camels come down again like elevators, we sort of clumsily get off, and they, obviously, try to take another chunk out of my leg. And I've developed a very wonderful relationship with this creature by this point, and I've realized that this is a mean son of a bitch. And much meaner, by the way, than the Bedouin who greeted me and tried to sell me one of his 26 daughters to take back to the States.So as we talked, Richard and I, I said, "You know, maybe I should bring a camel. It's the best designed animal in the world." He went, "Nah. I don't think we want to be bringing a camel." And you should be really glad we decided not to bring the camel. So I did the next best thing. I went to the Washington Zoo. Richard said, "I want you to get up close and personal with this camel. I want you to inspect its mouth, look at its teeth. Go underneath it. Go above it. Go around it. Pull its tail up; take a look in there. I want you to get as close to that camel as you possibly can."So, I got a National Geographic film crew. We went down there, and I took one look at this camel. It is a 2,000 pound creature who is in rut.(Laughter)Now, if you've ever seen a 2,000 pound camel in rut, it is a scary, scary thing to behold. And if Richard thought I was getting in the ring with that camel, someone was smoking Bedouin high grade.(Laughter)So we got as close to it as possible, and I'm going to share this. Chris, if you want to roll this film. Then I'm going to show you a little bit more about the design of camels.Do you want to roll the film?(Adventure music)(Video) Hello. This is Keith Bellows with the TED National Geographic Camel Investigation Unit. I'm here to look at the ultimate desert machine.(Music continues)Keith Bellows: And you'll note I started chewing gum because I was around this camel all day.(Video) That's it, OK. No! See, now he's getting a little overexcited. So we'll need to be very careful around him. Don't let him get you. Now, you can see copious amounts of saliva in there. I always called myself the unstable stable boy. Their nose, you can see his nose is flared right now. When they're in rut, they're similar to seals in the way, like, a seal has to open its nose to breathe. And they're similar. They have to consciously open their nose.KB: Ears?SK: They are small. But they have excellent hearing. But not big; for instance, in zebras, they have a huge ear that's very mobile, so they can actually turn them both around. And they use them in the same way we use our binocular vision. They use that to pinpoint sound. The desert's extremely windy as well as being very cold. So not only do they have the very long eyelashes, but there's the secondary — I guess you'd call it the [unclear] or whatever. It's this hair that's above the eyes, and below it, it's longer.Most people think that the humps store water. They don't. They store fat. Now, I'm not a chemist, but basically what happens is the fat is oxidized by their breathing. And that will turn it into actually usable water. Like a lot of predators, they walk on their toes. But there's a big fat pad in there that squishes out. They're like sun shoes, but, you know, with sand. Hooves? They don't have traditional hooves, but they do have one, like, big nail.(Audience laughter)You can't really see too clear. The fur's kind of grown over. But they use their tails a lot, especially in rut. He will urinate and spin his tail to spread the urine around and make him more attractive. I don't know why that would be, but it works for them. So, what the hell.(Audience laughter)Now, they will also defecate in certain areas. Generally, they poop wherever they want to, but during their rut, they will defecate in perimeter areas. I don't know if you've read or heard about the sub-sonic sounds from elephants, you know what I mean, like, "Br-r-r!" These big, big rumbling sounds. He will do the same thing. You can actually see, right here, it will vibrate. We weigh our animals. Unfortunately, he's a very aggressive animal, so he's actually destroyed some of the scales. We had these big things that I weigh the bison on, for instance. I'm guessing that he's at least 1,600 pounds. But I would put him closer to 2,000. He's basically a walking mulch pile. We're kind of like buds, but I'm also a male as well.KB: He sees you as competition? Senior Keeper: Yeah, exactly. And it makes him very dangerous at this time of year. Don't even think about it. Don't think about it!But now, we're going to meet. Out! Out! Out! No. Out!(Music)(Applause)KB: What I didn't show you was, you got that swinging thing going? Well, and you're glad I didn't show you this. One of the other things about the camel's beautiful design is that its penis points backwards. That way the camel can dip its tail in the stream, and just whacker the entire area around him. And that's how he really marks his territory. Now, what you also didn't see was that — and you may have noticed in the pen beside him and, by the way, the camel's name is Suki. In the pen beside him is Jasmine. Jasmine has been his mate for some time. But on this particular occasion, it was very, very clear that as horny as Suki was, Jasmine was having none of it. And so we started thinking. Well, if poor old Suki is in search of a mate, what would Suki do to find the perfect mate?I'm going to show you another film. But before I do, I just want to mention that this animal truly is a sort of the SUV of the sand, the ship of the desert. It's so vital to the inhabitants of the areas in which the camel is found, largely Mongolia and Sahara, that there are 160 words in Arabic to describe the camel. And if this is a creature that was designed by committee, it's certainly been like no committee I've ever been on. So here's what Suki would do in search of a mate. Can you roll it, please?Camel seeking camel Lusty beast desires attractive and sincere mate. I'm seven feet, 2,000 lbs., with brown hair and eyes, long legs — and I'm very well ... hung. I'm TED Camel. The perfect desert machine. I'm smartly designed. Eyelashes that keep out sand and a third eyelash that works like a windshield wiper. A distinguished nose — with nostrils lined to filter out sand and dust and a groove that catches moisture. Amazingly full lips — that allow me to eat practically anything that grows. Callouses on my knees that let me kneel comfortably. Leathery chest pads that beat the heat. Short fur that keeps my skin cool. Long legs that allow heat to escape. And my hump? Ogden Nash once wrote: "The camel has a single hump; the dromedary two, or else the other way around. I'm never sure. Are you?" Here's a hint: Bactarian. Dromedary. My hump contains up to 80 lbs. of fat, but doesn't store H2O. I'm built to last. I'm the go-to animal when the oasis is dry. I usually won't sweat until my body reaches 105 ºF, enough to fry an egg. I'm able to lose 40% of my weight without dying. (Most animals would if they lost half that much.) I'll drink 5 to 7 gallons of water a day. But go without for more than a month. I'm powerful. Able to pack up to 400 lbs. of cargo. Outrun a horse — And cover 26 miles on a good day. Camelot. Jackie O. once said that traveling by camel made riding an elephant seem like taking a jet plane. Yet my large, soft feet allow me to navigate sand. (Is that why the Bedouin claim I can dance?) I'm a good provider, too. Bedouins call the camel the Gift of God. No surprise. Tents and rugs are made of my hair. My dried bones are prized as a sort of ivory. My dung is burned as fuel. My milk is used for cheese. "Camels are like angels," a Bedouin once said.(Applause)Thank you. I just want to leave you with one last thought, which is probably the most important thing to take away. Humans, the animal, are pretty lucky creatures because, by and large, we really don't have to adapt to our environment; we adapt our environment to us. And we've seen that repeatedly through this conference, not just this year, but in past years. But this creature that you've just seen ultimately adapts, and keeps adapting and adapting. I think when you look at the animal kingdom, that is one of the most remarkable things. It doesn't have an environment that adapts to it; it has to adapt to the environment.Ricky, thank you very much for having me.RW: That's terrific. Thank you.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.934
[SHIT]

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.934
This is arguably the back end
of the design of animals.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.934
(Laughter)

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:28.378
But the reason
I put this up here is because

00:00:28.402 --> 00:00:32.513
when I was in Africa last year,
my wife and I were driving around,

00:00:32.537 --> 00:00:34.759
we had this wonderful guide,

00:00:34.783 --> 00:00:37.934
who showed us something
that surprised both of us,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.934
and it was very revealing
in terms of the fascination

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.934
that comes with the design of animals.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.934
It turns out that in about the 1880s,
the missionaries came to Africa

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.934
to spread the word of Christianity,

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.935
to teach English to the natives.

00:00:50.959 --> 00:00:53.852
And they brought blackboards and chalk.

00:00:53.876 --> 00:00:56.429
And I'd like you to imagine
that that's a blackboard,

00:00:56.453 --> 00:00:58.275
and I just used some chalk on there.

00:00:58.299 --> 00:01:00.700
And they brought
quite a bit of this stuff.

00:01:00.803 --> 00:01:03.361
But over the years,
the blackboards were fine,

00:01:03.385 --> 00:01:05.362
but they ran out of chalk.

00:01:05.386 --> 00:01:07.386
And this is a real crisis for them.

00:01:07.549 --> 00:01:10.259
And that's where the hyena comes in.

00:01:10.676 --> 00:01:13.034
The hyena is probably
the most perfectly designed

00:01:13.058 --> 00:01:14.935
scavenging animal in the world.

00:01:14.959 --> 00:01:18.934
It strip-mines carcasses,
and it has amazing teeth,

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:23.751
because it enables the hyena
to essentially eat bones.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:28.958
Now, the end product of that action
is up on the board here.

00:01:29.709 --> 00:01:34.623
What the missionaries would do is,
they'd walk around

00:01:34.995 --> 00:01:36.711
and they'd pick up hyena shit.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.434
And the incredible thing
about hyena shit is, it makes great chalk.

00:01:40.917 --> 00:01:42.013
(Laughter)

00:01:42.037 --> 00:01:43.934
That's not what I'm here to talk about,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:48.569
but it is a fascinating aspect
of animal design.

00:01:48.593 --> 00:01:50.934
What I'm here to talk about is the camel.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.934
When I started talking to Richard

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.934
about what I was going to speak about,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.582
I had recently come back from Jordan,

00:01:57.606 --> 00:02:00.828
where I had an amazing
experience with a camel.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.934
(Laughter)

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.379
And we were in the desert.

00:02:05.403 --> 00:02:08.220
Richard Wurman: That's the end!
Keith Bellows: Yeah, yeah.

00:02:08.244 --> 00:02:11.489
We were in the desert,
in Wadi Rum, in a small Jeep.

00:02:11.513 --> 00:02:13.513
There were four of us,
two Bedouin drivers.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:17.845
You can just imagine,
this expanse is an ocean of sand,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
105 degrees, one water bottle.

00:02:20.656 --> 00:02:25.918
And we were driving in what they told us
was their very, very best Jeep.

00:02:26.140 --> 00:02:28.560
Didn't look like it to me.

00:02:28.584 --> 00:02:31.486
And as we started to go
through the desert,

00:02:32.653 --> 00:02:33.934
the Jeep broke down.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.934
The guys got out, they put the hood up,

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.633
they started working
under the hood, got it going again.

00:02:38.657 --> 00:02:40.427
About a hundred yards, it broke down.

00:02:40.451 --> 00:02:43.728
This went on about 6-7 times,
we were getting more and more alarmed,

00:02:43.752 --> 00:02:46.410
we were also getting deeper
and deeper into the desert.

00:02:46.434 --> 00:02:48.934
And eventually,
our worst nightmare happened:

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.934
they flooded the engine.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.682
And they said, "Ah, no problem!
We just get out and walk."

00:02:55.153 --> 00:02:56.935
And we said, "We get out and walk?"

00:02:56.959 --> 00:02:59.211
One water bottle, remember,
guys, four people.

00:02:59.235 --> 00:03:02.592
And they said, "Yeah, yeah, we'll walk.
We'll find some camels."

00:03:02.902 --> 00:03:04.855
We got out and walked, and sure enough,

00:03:04.879 --> 00:03:07.489
about half a mile, we came
over the crest of this hill,

00:03:07.513 --> 00:03:10.411
and there was a huge gathering
of Bedouin with their camels.

00:03:10.435 --> 00:03:12.330
The guy went up and started dickering,

00:03:12.354 --> 00:03:14.934
and 10 dollars later, we had four camels.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.476
They went down like elevators;
we got on them.

00:03:17.500 --> 00:03:20.934
They went back up, and the Bedouin,
each Bedouin, four of them,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.934
got behind each of the camels
with a little whip.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.934
And they started slashing away
at the back of the camels,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.250
and they started galloping.

00:03:28.274 --> 00:03:31.751
And if you've ever been on a camel,
it is a very, very uncomfortable ride.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.934
There's also one other aspect
about these camels.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.934
About every 10 steps, they lean back

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.934
and try to take a chunk out of your leg.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.037
(Laughter)

00:03:40.061 --> 00:03:41.934
So we kept on going,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.934
and this camel kept on trying
to take a chunk out of my leg.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.092
And eventually, three miles later,
we arrived at our destination,

00:03:48.116 --> 00:03:49.934
where a Jeep was supposed to meet us.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.275
And the camels come down
again like elevators,

00:03:52.434 --> 00:03:53.934
we sort of clumsily get off,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.934
and they, obviously, try to take
another chunk out of my leg.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.934
And I've developed
a very wonderful relationship

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.934
with this creature by this point,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
and I've realized
that this is a mean son of a bitch.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.934
And much meaner, by the way,
than the Bedouin who greeted me

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.498
and tried to sell me
one of his 26 daughters

00:04:11.522 --> 00:04:13.498
to take back to the States.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.832
So as we talked, Richard and I,

00:04:15.856 --> 00:04:18.117
I said, "You know, maybe
I should bring a camel.

00:04:18.141 --> 00:04:20.374
It's the best designed
animal in the world."

00:04:20.398 --> 00:04:23.282
He went, "Nah. I don't think
we want to be bringing a camel."

00:04:23.306 --> 00:04:26.443
And you should be really glad
we decided not to bring the camel.

00:04:26.467 --> 00:04:27.958
So I did the next best thing.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.919
I went to the Washington Zoo.

00:04:30.943 --> 00:04:35.296
Richard said, "I want you to get up
close and personal with this camel.

00:04:35.527 --> 00:04:38.471
I want you to inspect its mouth,
look at its teeth.

00:04:38.495 --> 00:04:40.934
Go underneath it.
Go above it. Go around it.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.491
Pull its tail up; take a look in there.

00:04:43.696 --> 00:04:46.934
I want you to get as close
to that camel as you possibly can."

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.204
So, I got a National Geographic film crew.

00:04:50.624 --> 00:04:55.130
We went down there,
and I took one look at this camel.

00:04:56.340 --> 00:05:00.934
It is a 2,000 pound creature
who is in rut.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.752
(Laughter)

00:05:03.776 --> 00:05:06.633
Now, if you've ever seen
a 2,000 pound camel in rut,

00:05:06.657 --> 00:05:08.894
it is a scary, scary thing to behold.

00:05:09.815 --> 00:05:13.481
And if Richard thought I was getting
in the ring with that camel,

00:05:13.505 --> 00:05:15.934
someone was smoking Bedouin high grade.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.140
(Laughter)

00:05:17.164 --> 00:05:20.934
So we got as close to it as possible,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.300
and I'm going to share this.

00:05:22.324 --> 00:05:24.093
Chris, if you want to roll this film.

00:05:24.117 --> 00:05:25.371
Then I'm going to show you

00:05:25.395 --> 00:05:27.491
a little bit more
about the design of camels.

00:05:27.515 --> 00:05:28.896

Now, you can see copious amounts
