00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
You can understand why artists are so different from accountants.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
You can actually predict what kinds of books they like to read,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
what kinds of places they like to travel to,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
and what kinds of food they like to eat.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
Once you understand this trait, you can understand

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:28.958
why anybody would eat at Applebee's, but not anybody that you know.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:34.958
(Laughter)

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
This trait also tells us a lot about politics.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
The main researcher of this trait, Robert McCrae says that,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:43.958
"Open individuals have an affinity for liberal, progressive, left-wing political views" --

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
they like a society which is open and changing --

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:50.958
"whereas closed individuals prefer conservative, traditional, right-wing views."

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:54.958
This trait also tells us a lot about the kinds of groups people join.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
So here's the description of a group I found on the Web.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
What kinds of people would join a global community

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
welcoming people from every discipline and culture,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
who seek a deeper understanding of the world,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and who hope to turn that understanding into a better future for us all?

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
This is from some guy named Ted.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
(Laughter)

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
Well, let's see now, if openness predicts who becomes liberal,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and openness predicts who becomes a TEDster,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
then might we predict that most TEDsters are liberal?

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Let's find out.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
I'm going to ask you to raise your hand, whether you are liberal, left of center --

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
on social issues, we're talking about, primarily --

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
or conservative, and I'll give a third option,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
because I know there are a number of libertarians in the audience.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
So, right now, please raise your hand --

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:32.958
down in the simulcast rooms, too,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
let's let everybody see who's here --

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
please raise your hand if you would say that you are liberal or left of center.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
Please raise your hand high right now. OK.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
Please raise your hand if you'd say you're libertarian.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
OK, about a -- two dozen.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
And please raise your hand if you'd say you are right of center or conservative.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:54.958
One, two, three, four, five -- about eight or 10.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
OK. This is a bit of a problem.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
Because if our goal is to understand the world,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
to seek a deeper understanding of the world,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
our general lack of moral diversity here is going to make it harder.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.958
Because when people all share values, when people all share morals,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
they become a team, and once you engage the psychology of teams,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
it shuts down open-minded thinking.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
When the liberal team loses, as it did in 2004,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:26.958
and as it almost did in 2000, we comfort ourselves.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
(Laughter)

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
We try to explain why half of America voted for the other team.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:37.958
We think they must be blinded by religion, or by simple stupidity.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
(Laughter)

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:48.958
(Applause)

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:54.958
So, if you think that half of America votes Republican

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
because they are blinded in this way,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
then my message to you is that you're trapped in a moral matrix,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:01.958
in a particular moral matrix.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
And by the matrix, I mean literally the matrix, like the movie "The Matrix."

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
But I'm here today to give you a choice.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:11.958
You can either take the blue pill and stick to your comforting delusions,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
or you can take the red pill,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
learn some moral psychology and step outside the moral matrix.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Now, because I know --

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
(Applause) --

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
OK, I assume that answers my question.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
I was going to ask you which one you picked, but no need.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
You're all high in openness to experience, and besides,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
it looks like it might even taste good, and you're all epicures.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
So anyway, let's go with the red pill.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
Let's study some moral psychology and see where it takes us.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Let's start at the beginning.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
What is morality and where does it come from?

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
The worst idea in all of psychology

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
is the idea that the mind is a blank slate at birth.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
Developmental psychology has shown

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
that kids come into the world already knowing so much

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
about the physical and social worlds,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
and programmed to make it really easy for them to learn certain things

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:54.958
and hard to learn others.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
The best definition of innateness I've ever seen --

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
this just clarifies so many things for me --

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
is from the brain scientist Gary Marcus.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:05.958
He says, "The initial organization of the brain does not depend that much on experience.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
Nature provides a first draft, which experience then revises.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
Built-in doesn't mean unmalleable;

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
it means organized in advance of experience."

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
OK, so what's on the first draft of the moral mind?

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
To find out, my colleague, Craig Joseph, and I

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
read through the literature on anthropology,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
on culture variation in morality

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
and also on evolutionary psychology, looking for matches.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
What are the sorts of things that people talk about across disciplines?

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
That you find across cultures and even across species?

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
We found five -- five best matches,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
which we call the five foundations of morality.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
The first one is harm/care.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:39.958
We're all mammals here, we all have a lot of neural and hormonal programming

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
that makes us really bond with others, care for others,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
feel compassion for others, especially the weak and vulnerable.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
It gives us very strong feelings about those who cause harm.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
This moral foundation underlies about 70 percent

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
of the moral statements I've heard here at TED.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
The second foundation is fairness/reciprocity.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
There's actually ambiguous evidence

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
as to whether you find reciprocity in other animals,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
but the evidence for people could not be clearer.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
This Norman Rockwell painting is called "The Golden Rule,"

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
and we heard about this from Karen Armstrong, of course,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
as the foundation of so many religions.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
That second foundation underlies the other 30 percent

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
of the moral statements I've heard here at TED.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
The third foundation is in-group/loyalty.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
You do find groups in the animal kingdom --

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
you do find cooperative groups --

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
but these groups are always either very small or they're all siblings.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
It's only among humans that you find very large groups of people

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
who are able to cooperate, join together into groups,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
but in this case, groups that are united to fight other groups.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
This probably comes from our long history of tribal living, of tribal psychology.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And this tribal psychology is so deeply pleasurable

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
that even when we don't have tribes,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
we go ahead and make them, because it's fun.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
(Laughter)

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Sports is to war as pornography is to sex.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
We get to exercise some ancient, ancient drives.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
The fourth foundation is authority/respect.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Here you see submissive gestures from two members of very closely related species.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
But authority in humans is not so closely based on power and brutality,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
as it is in other primates.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
It's based on more voluntary deference,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
and even elements of love, at times.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
The fifth foundation is purity/sanctity.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
This painting is called "The Allegory Of Chastity,"

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
but purity's not just about suppressing female sexuality.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
It's about any kind of ideology, any kind of idea

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
that tells you that you can attain virtue

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:21.958
by controlling what you do with your body,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
by controlling what you put into your body.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
And while the political right may moralize sex much more,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
the political left is really doing a lot of it with food.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Food is becoming extremely moralized nowadays,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and a lot of it is ideas about purity,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
about what you're willing to touch, or put into your body.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
I believe these are the five best candidates

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
for what's written on the first draft of the moral mind.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I think this is what we come with, at least

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
a preparedness to learn all of these things.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
But as my son, Max, grows up in a liberal college town,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
how is this first draft going to get revised?

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And how will it end up being different

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
from a kid born 60 miles south of us in Lynchburg, Virginia?

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
To think about culture variation, let's try a different metaphor.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
If there really are five systems at work in the mind --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
five sources of intuitions and emotions --

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
then we can think of the moral mind

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
as being like one of those audio equalizers that has five channels,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
where you can set it to a different setting on every channel.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
And my colleagues, Brian Nosek and Jesse Graham, and I,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
made a questionnaire, which we put up on the Web at www.YourMorals.org.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
And so far, 30,000 people have taken this questionnaire, and you can too.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Here are the results.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
Here are the results from about 23,000 American citizens.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
On the left, I've plotted the scores for liberals;

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
on the right, those for conservatives; in the middle, the moderates.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
The blue line shows you people's responses

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
on the average of all the harm questions.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So, as you see, people care about harm and care issues.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
They give high endorsement of these sorts of statements

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
all across the board, but as you also see,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
liberals care about it a little more than conservatives -- the line slopes down.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Same story for fairness.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
But look at the other three lines.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
For liberals, the scores are very low.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
Liberals are basically saying, "No, this is not morality.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
In-group, authority, purity -- this stuff has nothing to do with morality. I reject it."

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
But as people get more conservative, the values rise.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
We can say that liberals have a kind of a two-channel,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:01.958
or two-foundation morality.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
Conservatives have more of a five-foundation,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
or five-channel morality.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:06.958
We find this in every country we look at.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
Here's the data for 1,100 Canadians.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
I'll just flip through a few other slides.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
The U.K., Australia, New Zealand, Western Europe, Eastern Europe,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
Latin America, the Middle East, East Asia and South Asia.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Notice also that on all of these graphs,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
the slope is steeper on in-group, authority, purity.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Which shows that within any country,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
the disagreement isn't over harm and fairness.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Everybody -- I mean, we debate over what's fair --

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
but everybody agrees that harm and fairness matter.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Moral arguments within cultures

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
are especially about issues of in-group, authority, purity.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
This effect is so robust that we find it no matter how we ask the question.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
In one recent study,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
we asked people to suppose you're about to get a dog.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:45.958
You picked a particular breed,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
you learned some new information about the breed.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Suppose you learn that this particular breed is independent-minded,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and relates to its owner as a friend and an equal?

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
Well, if you are a liberal, you say, "Hey, that's great!"

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Because liberals like to say, "Fetch, please."

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
(Laughter)

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
But if you're conservative, that's not so attractive.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
If you're conservative, and you learn that a dog's extremely loyal

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
to its home and family, and doesn't warm up quickly to strangers,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
for conservatives, well, loyalty is good -- dogs ought to be loyal.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
But to a liberal, it sounds like this dog

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
is running for the Republican nomination.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:17.958
(Laughter)

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
So, you might say, OK,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
there are these differences between liberals and conservatives,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
but what makes those three other foundations moral?

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
Aren't those just the foundations of xenophobia

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and authoritarianism and Puritanism?

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:28.958
What makes them moral?

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
The answer, I think, is contained in this incredible triptych from Hieronymus Bosch,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
"The Garden of Earthly Delights."

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
In the first panel, we see the moment of creation.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
All is ordered, all is beautiful, all the people and animals

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
are doing what they're supposed to be doing, where they're supposed to be.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
But then, given the way of the world, things change.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
We get every person doing whatever he wants,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
with every aperture of every other person and every other animal.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Some of you might recognize this as the '60s.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:54.958
(Laughter)

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
But the '60s inevitably gives way to the '70s,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:02.958
where the cuttings of the apertures hurt a little bit more.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
Of course, Bosch called this hell.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
So this triptych, these three panels

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:12.958
portray the timeless truth that order tends to decay.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
The truth of social entropy.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
But lest you think this is just some part of the Christian imagination

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
where Christians have this weird problem with pleasure,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
here's the same story, the same progression,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
told in a paper that was published in Nature a few years ago,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
in which Ernst Fehr and Simon Gachter had people play a commons dilemma.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
A game in which you give people money,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and then, on each round of the game,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
they can put money into a common pot,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and then the experimenter doubles what's in there,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and then it's all divided among the players.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
So it's a really nice analog for all sorts of environmental issues,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
where we're asking people to make a sacrifice

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and they themselves don't really benefit from their own sacrifice.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
But you really want everybody else to sacrifice,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
but everybody has a temptation to a free ride.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
And what happens is that, at first, people start off reasonably cooperative --

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
and this is all played anonymously.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
On the first round, people give about half of the money that they can.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
But they quickly see, "You know what, other people aren't doing so much though.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
I don't want to be a sucker. I'm not going to cooperate."

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
And so cooperation quickly decays from reasonably good, down to close to zero.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
But then -- and here's the trick --

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
Fehr and Gachter said, on the seventh round, they told people,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
"You know what? New rule.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
If you want to give some of your own money

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.958
to punish people who aren't contributing, you can do that."

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
And as soon as people heard about the punishment issue going on,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
cooperation shoots up.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
It shoots up and it keeps going up.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
There's a lot of research showing that to solve cooperative problems, it really helps.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
It's not enough to just appeal to people's good motives.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
It really helps to have some sort of punishment.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
Even if it's just shame or embarrassment or gossip,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
you need some sort of punishment to bring people,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
when they're in large groups, to cooperate.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
There's even some recent research suggesting that religion --

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
priming God, making people think about God --

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:51.958
often, in some situations, leads to more cooperative, more pro-social behavior.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
Some people think that religion is an adaptation

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
evolved both by cultural and biological evolution

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
to make groups to cohere,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
in part for the purpose of trusting each other,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
and then being more effective at competing with other groups.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:03.958
I think that's probably right,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
although this is a controversial issue.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
But I'm particularly interested in religion,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and the origin of religion, and in what it does to us and for us.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
Because I think that the greatest wonder in the world is not the Grand Canyon.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
The Grand Canyon is really simple.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
It's just a lot of rock, and then a lot of water and wind, and a lot of time,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and you get the Grand Canyon.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:22.958
It's not that complicated.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
This is what's really complicated,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
that there were people living in places like the Grand Canyon,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
cooperating with each other, or on the savannahs of Africa,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
or on the frozen shores of Alaska, and then some of these villages

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
grew into the mighty cities of Babylon, and Rome, and Tenochtitlan.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:36.958
How did this happen?

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
This is an absolute miracle, much harder to explain than the Grand Canyon.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
The answer, I think, is that they used every tool in the toolbox.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
It took all of our moral psychology

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
to create these cooperative groups.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
Yes, you do need to be concerned about harm,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:49.958
you do need a psychology of justice.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
But it really helps to organize a group if you can have sub-groups,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
and if those sub-groups have some internal structure,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
and if you have some ideology that tells people

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
to suppress their carnality, to pursue higher, nobler ends.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
And now we get to the crux of the disagreement

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
between liberals and conservatives.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Because liberals reject three of these foundations.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
They say "No, let's celebrate diversity, not common in-group membership."

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
They say, "Let's question authority."

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
And they say, "Keep your laws off my body."

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Liberals have very noble motives for doing this.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Traditional authority, traditional morality can be quite repressive,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
and restrictive to those at the bottom, to women, to people that don't fit in.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
So liberals speak for the weak and oppressed.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
They want change and justice, even at the risk of chaos.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
This guy's shirt says, "Stop bitching, start a revolution."

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
If you're high in openness to experience, revolution is good,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
it's change, it's fun.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
Conservatives, on the other hand, speak for institutions and traditions.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
They want order, even at some cost to those at the bottom.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
The great conservative insight is that order is really hard to achieve.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
It's really precious, and it's really easy to lose.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
So as Edmund Burke said, "The restraints on men,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
as well as their liberties, are to be reckoned among their rights."

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
This was after the chaos of the French Revolution.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
So once you see this -- once you see

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
that liberals and conservatives both have something to contribute,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
that they form a balance on change versus stability --

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
then I think the way is open to step outside the moral matrix.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:09.958
This is the great insight that all the Asian religions have attained.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
Think about yin and yang.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Yin and yang aren't enemies. Yin and yang don't hate each other.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
Yin and yang are both necessary, like night and day,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
for the functioning of the world.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
You find the same thing in Hinduism.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
There are many high gods in Hinduism.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
Two of them are Vishnu, the preserver, and Shiva, the destroyer.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
This image actually is both of those gods sharing the same body.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
You have the markings of Vishnu on the left,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
so we could think of Vishnu as the conservative god.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
You have the markings of Shiva on the right,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
Shiva's the liberal god. And they work together.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
You find the same thing in Buddhism.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
These two stanzas contain, I think, the deepest insights

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
that have ever been attained into moral psychology.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
From the Zen master Seng-ts'an:

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
"If you want the truth to stand clear before you, never be for or against.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:53.958
The struggle between for and against is the mind's worst disease."

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Now unfortunately, it's a disease

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
that has been caught by many of the world's leaders.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
But before you feel superior to George Bush,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
before you throw a stone, ask yourself, do you accept this?

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
Do you accept stepping out of the battle of good and evil?

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
Can you be not for or against anything?

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
So, what's the point? What should you do?

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
Well, if you take the greatest insights

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
from ancient Asian philosophies and religions,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
and you combine them with the latest research on moral psychology,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
I think you come to these conclusions:

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
that our righteous minds were designed by evolution

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
to unite us into teams, to divide us against other teams

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
and then to blind us to the truth.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
So what should you do? Am I telling you to not strive?

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Am I telling you to embrace Seng-ts'an and stop,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
stop with this struggle of for and against?

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
No, absolutely not. I'm not saying that.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
This is an amazing group of people who are doing so much,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
using so much of their talent, their brilliance, their energy, their money,

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
to make the world a better place, to fight --

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
to fight wrongs, to solve problems.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
But as we learned from Samantha Power, in her story

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:06.958
about Sergio Vieira de Mello, you can't just go charging in,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
saying, "You're wrong, and I'm right."

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
Because, as we just heard, everybody thinks they are right.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
A lot of the problems we have to solve

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
are problems that require us to change other people.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
And if you want to change other people, a much better way to do it

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
is to first understand who we are -- understand our moral psychology,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
understand that we all think we're right -- and then step out,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:31.958
even if it's just for a moment, step out -- check in with Seng-ts'an.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Step out of the moral matrix,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
just try to see it as a struggle playing out,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
in which everybody does think they're right,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
and everybody, at least, has some reasons -- even if you disagree with them --

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
everybody has some reasons for what they're doing.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:42.958
Step out.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:46.958
And if you do that, that's the essential move to cultivate moral humility,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:47.958
to get yourself out of this self-righteousness,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
which is the normal human condition.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
Think about the Dalai Lama.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
Think about the enormous moral authority of the Dalai Lama --

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
and it comes from his moral humility.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
So I think the point -- the point of my talk,

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
and I think the point of TED --

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
is that this is a group that is passionately engaged

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
in the pursuit of changing the world for the better.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
People here are passionately engaged

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
in trying to make the world a better place.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
But there is also a passionate commitment to the truth.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:20.958
And so I think that the answer is to use that passionate commitment

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:24.958
to the truth to try to turn it into a better future for us all.

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:25.958
Thank you.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:28.958

title: What security means to me
transcript: I think it'll be a relief to some people and a disappointment to others that I'm not going to talk about vaginas today. I began "The Vagina Monologues" because I was worried about vaginas. I'm very worried today about this notion, this world, this prevailing kind of force of security. I see this word, hear this word, feel this word everywhere. Real security, security checks, security watch, security clearance. Why has all this focus on security made me feel so much more insecure? What does anyone mean when they talk about real security? And why have we, as Americans particularly, become a nation that strives for security above all else? In fact, I think that security is elusive. It's impossible. We all die. We all get old. We all get sick. People leave us. People change us. Nothing is secure. And that's actually the good news.This is, of course, unless your whole life is about being secure. I think that when that is the focus of your life, these are the things that happen. You can't travel very far or venture too far outside a certain circle. You can't allow too many conflicting ideas into your mind at one time, as they might confuse you or challenge you. You can't open yourself to new experiences, new people, new ways of doing things — they might take you off course. You can't not know who you are, so you cling to hard-matter identity. You become a Christian, Muslim, Jew. You're an Indian, Egyptian, Italian, American. You're a heterosexual or a homosexual, or you never have sex. Or at least, that's what you say when you identify yourself. You become part of an "us." In order to be secure, you defend against "them." You cling to your land because it is your secure place. You must fight anyone who encroaches upon it. You become your nation. You become your religion. You become whatever it is that will freeze you, numb you and protect you from doubt or change. But all this does, actually, is shut down your mind. In reality, it does not really make you safer.I was in Sri Lanka, for example, three days after the tsunami, and I was standing on the beaches and it was absolutely clear that, in a matter of five minutes, a 30-foot wave could rise up and desecrate a people, a population and lives. All this striving for security, in fact, has made you much more insecure because now you have to watch out all the time. There are people not like you — people who you now call enemies. You have places you cannot go, thoughts you cannot think, worlds that you can no longer inhabit. And so you spend your days fighting things off, defending your territory and becoming more entrenched in your fundamental thinking. Your days become devoted to protecting yourself. This becomes your mission. That is all you do. Ideas get shorter. They become sound bytes. There are evildoers and saints, criminals and victims.There are those who, if they're not with us, are against us. It gets easier to hurt people because you do not feel what's inside them. It gets easier to lock them up, force them to be naked, humiliate them, occupy them, invade them and kill them, because they are only obstacles now to your security. In six years, I've had the extraordinary privilege through V-Day, a global movement against [violence against] women, to travel probably to 60 countries, and spend a great deal of time in different portions. I've met women and men all over this planet, who through various circumstances — war, poverty, racism, multiple forms of violence — have never known security, or have had their illusion of security forever devastated. I've spent time with women in Afghanistan under the Taliban, who were essentially brutalized and censored. I've been in Bosnian refugee camps. I was with women in Pakistan who have had their faces melted off with acid. I've been with girls all across America who were date-raped, or raped by their best friends when they were drugged one night.One of the amazing things that I've discovered in my travels is that there is this emerging species. I loved when he was talking about this other world that's right next to this world. I've discovered these people, who, in V-Day world, we call Vagina Warriors. These particular people, rather than getting AK-47s, or weapons of mass destruction, or machetes, in the spirit of the warrior, have gone into the center, the heart of pain, of loss. They have grieved it, they have died into it, and allowed and encouraged poison to turn into medicine. They have used the fuel of their pain to begin to redirect that energy towards another mission and another trajectory.These warriors now devote themselves and their lives to making sure what happened to them doesn't happen to anyone else. There are thousands if not millions of them on the planet. I venture there are many in this room. They have a fierceness and a freedom that I believe is the bedrock of a new paradigm. They have broken out of the existing frame of victim and perpetrator. Their own personal security is not their end goal, and because of that, because, rather than worrying about security, because the transformation of suffering is their end goal, I actually believe they are creating real safety and a whole new idea of security. I want to talk about a few of these people that I've met.Tomorrow, I am going to Cairo, and I'm so moved that I will be with women in Cairo who are V-Day women, who are opening the first safe house for battered women in the Middle East. That will happen because women in Cairo made a decision to stand up and put themselves on the line, and talk about the degree of violence that is happening in Egypt, and were willing to be attacked and criticized. And through their work over the last years, this is not only happening that this house is opening, but it's being supported by many factions of the society who never would have supported it. Women in Uganda this year, who put on "The Vagina Monologues" during V-Day, actually evoked the wrath of the government.And, I love this story so much. There was a cabinet meeting and a meeting of the presidents to talk about whether "Vaginas" could come to Uganda. And in this meeting — it went on for weeks in the press, two weeks where there was huge discussion. The government finally made a decision that "The Vagina Monologues" could not be performed in Uganda. But the amazing news was that because they had stood up, these women, and because they had been willing to risk their security, it began a discussion that not only happened in Uganda, but all of Africa. As a result, this production, which had already sold out, every single person in that 800-seat audience, except for 10 people, made a decision to keep the money. They raised 10,000 dollars on a production that never occurred.There's a young woman named Carrie Rethlefsen in Minnesota. She's a high school student. She had seen "The Vagina Monologues" and she was really moved. And as a result, she wore an "I heart my vagina" button to her high school in Minnesota.(Laughter)She was basically threatened to be expelled from school. They told her she couldn't love her vagina in high school, that it was not a legal thing, that it was not a moral thing, that it was not a good thing. So she really struggled with this, what to do, because she was a senior and she was doing well in her school and she was threatened expulsion. So what she did is she got all her friends together — I believe it was 100, 150 students all wore "I love my vagina" T-shirts, and the boys wore "I love her vagina" T-shirts to school.(Laughter)Now this seems like a fairly, you know, frivolous, but what happened as a result of that, is that that school now is forming a sex education class. It's beginning to talk about sex, it's beginning to look at why it would be wrong for a young high school girl to talk about her vagina publicly or to say that she loved her vagina publicly.I know I've talked about Agnes here before, but I want to give you an update on Agnes. I met Agnes three years ago in the Rift Valley. When she was a young girl, she had been mutilated against her will. That mutilation of her clitoris had actually obviously impacted her life and changed it in a way that was devastating. She made a decision not to go and get a razor or a glass shard, but to devote her life to stopping that happening to other girls. For eight years, she walked through the Rift Valley. She had this amazing box that she carried and it had a torso of a woman's body in it, a half a torso, and she would teach people, everywhere she went, what a healthy vagina looked like and what a mutilated vagina looked like. In the years that she walked, she educated parents, mothers, fathers. She saved 1,500 girls from being cut.When V-Day met her, we asked her how we could support her and she said, "Well, if you got me a Jeep, I could get around a lot faster." So, we bought her a Jeep. In the year she had the Jeep, she saved 4,500 girls from being cut. So, we said, what else could we do? She said, "If you help me get money, I could open a house." Three years ago, Agnes opened a safe house in Africa to stop mutilation. When she began her mission eight years ago, she was reviled, she was detested, she was completely slandered in her community. I am proud to tell you that six months ago, she was elected the deputy mayor of Narok.(Applause)I think what I'm trying to say here is that if your end goal is security, and if that's all you're focusing on, what ends up happening is that you create not only more insecurity in other people, but you make yourself far more insecure. Real security is contemplating death, not pretending it doesn't exist. Not running from loss, but entering grief, surrendering to sorrow. Real security is not knowing something, when you don't know it. Real security is hungering for connection rather than power. It cannot be bought or arranged or made with bombs. It is deeper, it is a process, it is acute awareness that we are all utterly inter-bended, and one action by one being in one tiny town has consequences everywhere. Real security is not only being able to tolerate mystery, complexity, ambiguity, but hungering for them and only trusting a situation when they are present.Something happened when I began traveling in V-Day, eight years ago. I got lost. I remember being on a plane going from Kenya to South Africa, and I had no idea where I was. I didn't know where I was going, where I'd come from, and I panicked. I had a total anxiety attack. And then I suddenly realized that it absolutely didn't matter where I was going, or where I had come from because we are all essentially permanently displaced people. All of us are refugees. We come from somewhere and we are hopefully traveling all the time, moving towards a new place. Freedom means I may not be identified as any one group, but that I can visit and find myself in every group. It does not mean that I don't have values or beliefs, but it does mean I am not hardened around them. I do not use them as weapons. In the shared future, it will be just that, shared. The end goal will [be] becoming vulnerable, realizing the place of our connection to one another, rather than becoming secure, in control and alone. Thank you very much.(Applause)Chris Anderson: And how are you doing? Are you exhausted? On a typical day, do you wake up with hope or gloom? Eve Ensler: You know, I think Carl Jung once said that in order to survive the twentieth century, we have to live with two existing thoughts, opposite thoughts, at the same time. And I think part of what I'm learning in this process is that one must allow oneself to feel grief. And I think as long as I keep grieving, and weeping, and then moving on, I'm fine. When I start to pretend that what I'm seeing isn't impacting me, and isn't changing my heart, then I get in trouble. Because when you spend a lot of time going from place to place, country to country, and city to city, the degree to which women, for example, are violated, and the epidemic of it, and the kind of ordinariness of it, is so devastating to one's soul that you have to take the time, or I have to take the time now, to process that.CA: There are a lot of causes out there in the world that have been talked about, you know, poverty, sickness and so on. You spent eight years on this one. Why this one? EE: I think that if you think about women, women are the primary resource of the planet. They give birth, we come from them, they are mothers, they are visionaries, they are the future. If you think that the U.N. now says that one out of three women on the planet will be raped or beaten in their lifetime, we're talking about the desecration of the primary resource of the planet, we're talking about the place where we come from, we're talking about parenting. Imagine that you've been raped and you're bringing up a boy child. How does it impact your ability to work, or envision a future, or thrive, as opposed to just survive? What I believe is if we could figure out how to make women safe and honor women, it would be parallel or equal to honoring life itself.
