and I was standing on the beaches

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
and it was absolutely clear that, in a matter of five minutes,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
a 30-foot wave could rise up

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
and desecrate a people, a population and lives.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
All this striving for security, in fact,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
has made you much more insecure

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
because now you have to watch out all the time.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
There are people not like you -- people who you now call enemies.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
You have places you cannot go, thoughts you cannot think,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
worlds that you can no longer inhabit.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:48.958
And so you spend your days fighting things off, defending your territory

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
and becoming more entrenched in your fundamental thinking.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
Your days become devoted to protecting yourself.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
This becomes your mission. That is all you do.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
Ideas get shorter. They become sound bytes.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
There are evildoers and saints, criminals and victims.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
There are those who, if they're not with us, are against us.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
It gets easier to hurt people because you do not feel what's inside them.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:13.958
It gets easier to lock them up, force them to be naked, humiliate them,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
occupy them, invade them and kill them,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
because they are only obstacles now to your security.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:23.958
In six years, I've had the extraordinary privilege through V-Day,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:24.958
a global movement against [violence against] women,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
to travel probably to 60 countries,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:31.958
and spend a great deal of time in different portions.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
I've met women and men all over this planet,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
who through various circumstances --

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:40.958
war, poverty, racism, multiple forms of violence --

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
have never known security,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
or have had their illusion of security forever devastated.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
I've spent time with women in Afghanistan under the Taliban,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
who were essentially brutalized and censored.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
I've been in Bosnian refugee camps.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
I was with women in Pakistan

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
who have had their faces melted off with acid.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
I've been with girls all across America who were date-raped,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
or raped by their best friends when they were drugged one night.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
One of the amazing things that I've discovered in my travels

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
is that there is this emerging species.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:15.958
I loved when he was talking about this other world that's right next to this world.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
I've discovered these people, who, in V-Day world,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
we call Vagina Warriors.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
These particular people, rather than getting AK-47s,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
or weapons of mass destruction, or machetes,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:32.958
in the spirit of the warrior, have gone into the center, the heart of pain, of loss.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
They have grieved it, they have died into it,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
and allowed and encouraged poison to turn into medicine.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.958
They have used the fuel of their pain to begin to redirect that energy

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
towards another mission and another trajectory.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
These warriors now devote themselves and their lives

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
to making sure what happened to them doesn't happen to anyone else.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
There are thousands if not millions of them on the planet.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
I venture there are many in this room.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
They have a fierceness and a freedom

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
that I believe is the bedrock of a new paradigm.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:08.958
They have broken out of the existing frame of victim and perpetrator.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Their own personal security is not their end goal,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
and because of that, because, rather than worrying about security,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
because the transformation of suffering is their end goal,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
I actually believe they are creating real safety

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
and a whole new idea of security.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
I want to talk about a few of these people that I've met.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
Tomorrow, I am going to Cairo,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and I'm so moved that I will be with women in Cairo

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
who are V-Day women, who are opening the first safe house

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
for battered women in the Middle East.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
That will happen because women in Cairo made a decision to stand up

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
and put themselves on the line,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
and talk about the degree of violence that is happening in Egypt,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
and were willing to be attacked and criticized.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
And through their work over the last years,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
this is not only happening that this house is opening,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
but it's being supported by many factions of the society

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
who never would have supported it.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
Women in Uganda this year,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
who put on "The Vagina Monologues" during V-Day,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
actually evoked the wrath of the government.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And, I love this story so much.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
There was a cabinet meeting and a meeting of the presidents

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
to talk about whether "Vaginas" could come to Uganda.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
And in this meeting -- it went on for weeks in the press,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
two weeks where there was huge discussion.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
The government finally made a decision

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
that "The Vagina Monologues" could not be performed in Uganda.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
But the amazing news was that because they had stood up, these women,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and because they had been willing to risk their security,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
it began a discussion that not only happened in Uganda,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
but all of Africa.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
As a result, this production, which had already sold out,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:47.958
every single person in that 800-seat audience, except for 10 people,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
made a decision to keep the money.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:55.958
They raised 10,000 dollars on a production that never occurred.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
There's a young woman named Carrie Rethlefsen in Minnesota.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
She's a high school student.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
She had seen "The Vagina Monologues" and she was really moved. And as a result,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:09.958
she wore an "I heart my vagina" button to her high school in Minnesota.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:10.958
(Laughter)

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:15.958
She was basically threatened to be expelled from school.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
They told her she couldn't love her vagina in high school,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
that it was not a legal thing, that it was not a moral thing,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
that it was not a good thing.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
So she really struggled with this, what to do,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
because she was a senior and she was doing well in her school

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:32.958
and she was threatened expulsion. So what she did is she got all her friends together --

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
I believe it was 100, 150 students

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
all wore "I love my vagina" T-shirts,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
and the boys wore "I love her vagina" T-shirts to school.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
(Laughter)

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
Now this seems like a fairly, you know, frivolous,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:51.958
but what happened as a result of that, is that that school now

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
is forming a sex education class. It's beginning to talk about sex,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
it's beginning to look at why it would be wrong

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
for a young high school girl to talk about her vagina publicly

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
or to say that she loved her vagina publicly.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
I know I've talked about Agnes here before,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
but I want to give you an update on Agnes.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
I met Agnes three years ago in the Rift Valley.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:17.958
When she was a young girl, she had been mutilated against her will.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
That mutilation of her clitoris

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
had actually obviously impacted her life

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
and changed it in a way that was devastating.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
She made a decision not to go and get a razor or a glass shard,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
but to devote her life to stopping that happening to other girls.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
For eight years, she walked through the Rift Valley.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
She had this amazing box that she carried and it had a

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
torso of a woman's body in it, a half a torso,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and she would teach people, everywhere she went,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
what a healthy vagina looked like and what a mutilated vagina looked like.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
In the years that she walked, she educated parents, mothers, fathers.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
She saved 1,500 girls from being cut.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
When V-Day met her, we asked her how we could support her

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and she said, "Well, if you got me a Jeep,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
I could get around a lot faster." So, we bought her a Jeep.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:04.958
In the year she had the Jeep, she saved 4,500 girls from being cut.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:05.958
So, we said, what else could we do?

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
She said, "If you help me get money, I could open a house."

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Three years ago, Agnes opened a safe house in Africa to stop mutilation.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
When she began her mission eight years ago, she was reviled,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
she was detested, she was completely slandered in her community.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
I am proud to tell you that six months ago,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
she was elected the deputy mayor of Narok.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:36.958
(Applause)

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
I think what I'm trying to say here

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
is that if your end goal is security,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and if that's all you're focusing on, what ends up happening

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
is that you create not only more insecurity in other people,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
but you make yourself far more insecure.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Real security is contemplating death, not pretending it doesn't exist.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Not running from loss, but entering grief, surrendering to sorrow.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Real security is not knowing something, when you don't know it.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Real security is hungering for connection rather than power.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
It cannot be bought or arranged or made with bombs.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
It is deeper, it is a process, it is acute awareness

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
that we are all utterly inter-bended,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and one action by one being in one tiny town

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
has consequences everywhere.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Real security is not only being able

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
to tolerate mystery, complexity, ambiguity, but hungering for them

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
and only trusting a situation when they are present.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:39.958
Something happened when I began traveling in V-Day, eight years ago. I got lost.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:44.958
I remember being on a plane going from Kenya to South Africa,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and I had no idea where I was.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
I didn't know where I was going, where I'd come from,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
and I panicked. I had a total anxiety attack.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
And then I suddenly realized that it absolutely didn't matter

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
where I was going, or where I had come from

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:01.958
because we are all essentially permanently displaced people.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
All of us are refugees.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
We come from somewhere and we are hopefully traveling all the time,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
moving towards a new place.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Freedom means I may not be identified as any one group,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
but that I can visit and find myself in every group.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
It does not mean that I don't have values or beliefs,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
but it does mean I am not hardened around them.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
I do not use them as weapons.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
In the shared future, it will be just that, shared.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
The end goal will [be] becoming vulnerable,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
realizing the place of our connection to one another,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:39.958
rather than becoming secure, in control and alone.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Thank you very much.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
(Applause)

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Chris Anderson: And how are you doing? Are you exhausted?

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
On a typical day, do you wake up with hope or gloom?

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Eve Ensler: You know, I think Carl Jung once said

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
that in order to survive the twentieth century,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
we have to live with two existing thoughts, opposite thoughts, at the same time.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And I think part of what I'm learning in this process

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
is that one must allow oneself to feel grief.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
And I think as long as I keep grieving, and weeping,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
and then moving on, I'm fine.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
When I start to pretend that what I'm seeing isn't impacting me,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and isn't changing my heart, then I get in trouble.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Because when you spend a lot of time going from place to place,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
country to country, and city to city,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
the degree to which women, for example, are violated,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:36.958
and the epidemic of it, and the kind of ordinariness of it,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
is so devastating to one's soul that you have to take the time,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
or I have to take the time now, to process that.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
CA: There are a lot of causes out there in the world that have been talked about,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:53.958
you know, poverty, sickness and so on. You spent eight years on this one.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Why this one?

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
EE: I think that if you think about women,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:02.958
women are the primary resource of the planet. They give birth,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
we come from them, they are mothers, they are visionaries,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
they are the future. If you think that the U.N. now says

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
that one out of three women on the planet

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
will be raped or beaten in their lifetime,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
we're talking about the desecration of the primary resource of the planet,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
we're talking about the place where we come from, we're talking about parenting.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Imagine that you've been raped and you're bringing up a boy child.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
How does it impact your ability to work, or envision a future,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
or thrive, as opposed to just survive? What I believe is

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
if we could figure out how to make women safe and honor women,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:39.958
it would be parallel or equal to honoring life itself.

title: How to pitch to a VC
transcript: Good morning. My name is David Rose. I am a serial entrepreneur turned serial investor. And by the use of pitching PowerPoints to VCs, I have personally raised tens of millions of dollars from VCs through PowerPoint pitches. And turning to the other side of the equation, I've personally supervised the investment of tens of millions of dollars into companies who have pitched me with PowerPoint presentations. So I think it's safe to say I know a little bit about the process of pitching.So, the very first question you've got to figure out is: What is the single most important thing that a VC is looking for when you come to them pitching your new business idea? There are obviously all kinds of things — business models and financials and markets and this and that. Overall, of all the things that you have to do, what is the single most important thing the VC is going to be investing in? Somebody? What?Audience: People!David Rose: People! You! That's it — you are the person. Therefore, the entire purpose of a VC pitch is to convince them that you are the entrepreneur in whom they are going to invest their money and make a lot of money in return.Now, how do you do this? You can't just walk up and say, "Hi, I'm a really good guy, good girl, and you should invest in me." Right? So in the course of your VC pitch — you have a very few minutes; most VC pitches, angel pitches, are about 15 minutes, most should be less than half an hour — people's attention span, after 18 minutes, begins to drop off. Tests have shown. So in that 18 or 10 or five minutes, you have to convey a whole bunch of different characteristics, about 10 different characteristics, while you're standing up there. What's the single most important thing you've got to convey? What?Audience: Integrity.DR: Boy, oh boy, oh boy! That's a straight line, look at that! And I didn't even prompt him. Right, integrity. The key thing. I would much rather invest in, take a chance on, somebody who I know is straight than where there's any possible question of who are they looking out for, and what's going on. So the most important thing is integrity. What's the second most important thing? Let's see if you can get this one.Audience: Self-confidence.DR: Close enough. Passion. Right? Entrepreneurs, by definition, are people who are leaving something else, starting a new world, creating and putting their lifeblood into this thing. You've got to convey passion. If you're not passionate, why should anyone else be, or put money into your company if you're not passionate about it? Integrity, passion: the most important things.Then there's a whole panoply of other things you've got to wrap up in this package you're presenting to a VC. Experience: you've got to be able to say, "Hey, you know, I've done this before." "Done this before" is starting an enterprise, creating value, and taking something from beginning to end. That's why VCs love to fund serial entrepreneurs — even if you didn't do it right the first time, you've learned the lessons, which puts you in good stead the next time.Along with the experience of starting an enterprise or running something — doesn't have to be a business, it can be an organization in a school, a not-for-profit. But experience in creating an organization.Next: knowledge. If you tell me you're going to be the developer of the map of the human genome, you better know what a human genome is; I want you to have expertise. I don't want somebody who says, "I've got a great idea in a business I know nothing about. I don't know who the players are, what the market is like." You've got to know your market, your area.And you have to have the skills that it takes to get a company going. Those skills include everything from technical skills if it's a technology business, to marketing and sales and management and so on. But, you know, not everybody has all these skills. Very few people have the full set of skills it takes to run a company.What else do you require? Well, leadership. You've got to be able to convince us that you either have developed a team that has all those factors in it, or else you can. And you have the charisma and the management style and the ability to get people to follow your lead, to inspire them, to motivate them to be part of your team.Having done all that, what else do I want to know as a VC? I want to know that you have commitment. That you are going to be here to the end. I want you to say — or I want you to convey — that you are going to die if you have to, with your very last breath, your fingernails scratching as they draw you out. You'll keep my money alive and make more from it. I don't want someone who'll cut and run at the first opportunity. Bad things happen. There's never been a venture-funded company where bad things didn't happen. So know that you're committed to the very end.You've got to have vision to see where this is going. I don't want another "me too" product. I want somebody who can change the world out there. But on top of that, I need realism, Because while changing the world is great, it doesn't always happen. And before you get to change the world, bad things are going to take place; you have to deal with that. And you have to have rational projections.Finally, you're asking for my money — not just because it's my money, but because it's me. You need to be coachable. I need to know you have the ability to listen. We've had a lot of experience. People who are VCs or angels investing in you have had experience, and they'd like to know that you want to hear that experience.So how do you convey these 10 things in 10 minutes without saying them? You can't say, "I've got integrity, invest in me!" You've got to do a whole pitch that conveys this without conveying it. Think about your pitch as a timeline. It starts off, you walk in the door. They know nothing whatsoever about you. You can take them on an emotional — all pitches, all sales presentations, are emotional at some level. You can go up, you can go down, right? And it goes from beginning to end.You walk in, the first thing you've got to do, the overall arc of your presentation, it's got to start like a rocket. You've got maybe 10 seconds — between 10 and 30 seconds, depending on how long the pitch is — to get their attention. In my case, I've invested. I've gotten millions of dollars from PowerPoint pitches. "I've invested millions." That should get you right there. This can be a fact or something counterintuitive. It can be a story or an experience. But you've got to grab their emotional attention, focused on you, within that first few seconds. And then from there, you've got to take them on a very solid, steady, upward path, right from beginning to end. Everything has to reinforce this.And you've got to get better and better and better, revving up to the very end, then you've got to — boom! — knock them out of the park. You want to get them to such an emotional high they're ready to write you a check, throw money at you, before you leave.How do you do that? First of all, logical progression. Any time you go backwards, any time you skip a step — imagine walking up a staircase where some of the treads are missing, or the heights are different. You stop, you need to figure out a nice, logical progression. Start with what the market is: Why are you going to do X, Y or Z? And then you've got to tell me how you're going to do it, and what you're going to do. And it's got to flow from beginning to end.You've got to let me know there are touchstones, to tie in to the rest of the world out there. For example, reference companies I've heard of, or basic items in your business. I want to know about things that I can relate to: validators, or anything that tells me somebody else has approved this, or there's outside validation. It can be sales; it can be you got an award for something; it can be people have done it before; it can be your beta tests are going great, whatever. I want to know validation — not just what you're telling me, but that somebody or something else out there says this makes sense. And then, I'm looking for the upside; I need a believable upside. That's two parts; it's got to be upside and believable. The upside means if you tell me that five years out, you're making a million dollars a year, that's not really upside. Telling me you'll be making a billion dollars a year — that's not believable. So it's got to be both.On the other hand are things that take the emotional level down. You have to recover from those. For example, anything that I know is not true. "We have no competition. Nobody makes a widget like this." Odds are I know somebody who's made a widget, and the minute you tell me that, I discount half of what you're saying from then on. Anything I don't understand, where I have to make the leap myself, in my own head, will stop the flow of the presentation. So you've got to take me through like a sixth-grader — dub, dub, dub — but without patronizing me. And it's a very tricky path. But if you can do it, it works really well.Anything that's inconsistent within your concept — if you tell me sales of X, Y or Z are 10 million dollars, five slides later, they're five million dollars ... One may have been gross sales, one may have been net sales, but I want to know that all the numbers make sense together.And then, finally: anything that's an error or a typo, or a stupid mistake or a line that's in the wrong place — that shows me that if you can't do a presentation, how can you run a company? So this all feeds in together.The best way to do this is to look at our betters, people who have done this before. Let's look at the most successful technology executive in the business, and see how a presentation goes. Bill Gates's PowerPoint presentation over here. Here's Gates doing a thing for Windows. Is this how to do a PowerPoint presentation? What do you think? No. Who do you think we should look at as our role model?Oh, isn't that funny! There's another great one over here. OK, Steve Jobs. You want absolute — this is the Zen of presentation, right? Here he is, one little guy, black jeans and stuff, on a totally empty stage. What are you focusing on? You're focusing on him! This is Steve Jobs.So are these wonderful long bullet points, whole list of things good? No, they're not. The long bullet points are bad. What's good? Short. Short bullet points. But you know what? Even better than short bullet points are no bullet points. Just give me the headline. And you know what? How many bullet points does Steve Jobs use? Basically, none. What do you do? Best of all, images. Just a simple image. I look at the image; a picture's worth a thousand words. You look at the image and you've got the whole thing. Then you come back to me; you're focused on me, why I'm such a great guy, why you want to invest, why this all makes sense.That said, we only have a very short time, so let's run through the things to include in your presentation. First of all, none of these big, long-titled slides with blah, blah, I'm presenting to so-and-so on X date. I know the day, I know who I am — I don't need all that. Just give me your company logo. I look at the logo, and it ties it to my brain. Then I come back to you. I'm focused on you, OK? You give me your quick, 15-second or 30-second intro, grab my attention. Then you give me a quick business overview. This is not a five-minute pitch. This is, you know, two sentences. "We build widgets for the X, Y, Z market." Or, "We sell services to help do X." You know, whatever. And that is like the picture on the outside of a jigsaw puzzle box. That lets me know the context. It gives me the armature for the whole thing you'll be going through; it lets me put everything in relation to what you've told me.Then you've got to walk me through, show me who your management team is. I want to know the size of the market. Why is this market worth getting at? I want to know your product, that's very important. Now, this is not a product pitch or sales pitch. I don't want to know all the ins and outs, just what the heck is it? If it's a website, show me a screenshot of your website. Don't do a live demo. Never do a live demo. Do a canned demo, or something that lets me know why people are going to buy whatever it is.Now that I know what you're selling, tell me how you make money on it. For every X you sell, you get Y, or services of Z. I want to know what the business model is on a per-unit basis, or for the actual product you're selling. I want to know who you're selling to in terms of customers and if you have any special relationships that will help you, whether it's a distribution relationship or a producing partner. Again, validation. This helps to say you're bigger than just one little thing over here.But everybody has competition. There's never been a company with no competition, even if the competition is the old way of doing something. I want to know exactly what your competition is, and that will help me judge how you fit into the whole operation. I want to know how you're special.I know what your competition does — how are you going to prevent them from eating your lunch? All this ties into the financial overview. And you can't do a VC pitch without giving me your financials. I want to know a year or two back, or as long as you've been in existence. And I want to know four or five years forward. Five is a bit much. Probably four.And I want to know how that business model, on a product basis, will translate into a company model: How many widgets will you sell? You make X amount per widget. I want to know what the driver is. We'll have 1,000 customers this year and 10,000 the next, our revenues will do this and that. That gives me the whole picture for the next several years into which I'm investing. And I want to know how the money from me will help you get there. You're going to open an offshore plant in China, you're going to spend it all on sales and marketing, you're going to go to Tahiti, whatever.But then comes the ask, where you tell me how much you want. You're looking for 5 million — at what valuation? Two million? 100,000? What's the money in so far? Who invested? I hope you invested — if you can't invest in your own thing, why should I? So I like to know if you have friends and family, or angel investors, or more VCs before. What's the capital structure up until this point? Finally, having done all that, you've now told me the whole thing, so now you bring it back to that conclusion. This is that rocket going up. Hopefully everything has been positive. And everything you say clicks, it all makes sense. And I'm thinking, "This is really great!"Then you take me back to just your logo on the screen. And I look at the logo — OK, good. Now I come back to you. Nothing else to look at, right? Now you've got to wrap it up to give me the final — boom! — the final pitch that's going to send me into space. Now, in the process of doing this, how do you remember the sequences and do it? You've noticed I'm not looking at the screen, right? The screen is in front of me, so I couldn't even see if I wanted to.So how do I know what's going on? Well, I have a laptop in front of me. You're looking at me and at this. What am I looking at? You think that I'm looking at that? No, I'm looking, actually, at a special version of PowerPoint over here, which shows me the slides ahead and behind, my notes, so I can see what's going on. PowerPoint has this built into every copy of it that's shipped. If you use Apple's Keynote, it's got an even better version. There's another program called Ovation you can get from Adobe that they bought last summer, which helps you run the timers and lets you figure out what's going on.So, here's my wrap-up to take you to the moon, right? I usually do a Top 10, but we don't have time, so: David's Top Five Presentation Tips. Number five: always use presenter mode, or Ovation, or presenter tools. It lets you know exactly where you're going, helps you pace yourself, gives you a timer, the whole bit.Number four: always use remote control. Have you seen me touch the computer? No. Why not? Because I'm using remote control. Always use remote control.Number three: the handouts you give are not your presentation. If you follow my suggestions, you'll have a very spare, Zen-like presentation, which is great to convey who you are and get people emotionally involved, but not good as a handout. You want a handout that gives more information; it has to stand without you.Number two: don't read your speech. Can you imagine?(Reading) "You should invest in my company ... "It doesn't work. And the number one presentation tip: never, ever look at the screen. You're making a connection with your audience, and you always want a one-on-one connection. The screen should come up behind you and supplement what you're doing, instead of replace you. And that is how to pitch to a VC.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.283 --> 00:00:13.443
Good morning.

00:00:13.467 --> 00:00:14.727
My name is David Rose.

00:00:14.751 --> 00:00:18.307
I am a serial entrepreneur
turned serial investor.

00:00:18.331 --> 00:00:21.927
And by the use of pitching
PowerPoints to VCs,

00:00:21.951 --> 00:00:24.427
I have personally raised
tens of millions of dollars

00:00:24.451 --> 00:00:27.321
from VCs through PowerPoint pitches.

00:00:27.345 --> 00:00:29.523
And turning to the other side
of the equation,

00:00:29.547 --> 00:00:32.963
I've personally supervised the investment
of tens of millions of dollars

00:00:32.987 --> 00:00:36.054
into companies who have pitched me
with PowerPoint presentations.

00:00:36.078 --> 00:00:37.403
So I think it's safe to say

00:00:37.427 --> 00:00:40.079
I know a little bit
about the process of pitching.

00:00:40.103 --> 00:00:42.735
So, the very first question
you've got to figure out is:

00:00:42.759 --> 00:00:46.417
What is the single most important
thing that a VC is looking for

00:00:46.441 --> 00:00:49.559
when you come to them
pitching your new business idea?

00:00:49.583 --> 00:00:51.588
There are obviously all kinds of things --

00:00:51.612 --> 00:00:54.494
business models and financials
and markets and this and that.

00:00:54.518 --> 00:00:56.724
Overall, of all the things
that you have to do,

00:00:56.748 --> 00:00:58.655
what is the single most important thing

00:00:58.679 --> 00:01:00.655
the VC is going to be investing in?

00:01:01.701 --> 00:01:02.934
Somebody? What?

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.112
Audience: People!

00:01:04.460 --> 00:01:07.839
David Rose: People! You!
That's it -- you are the person.

00:01:07.863 --> 00:01:11.739
Therefore, the entire purpose
of a VC pitch is to convince them

00:01:11.763 --> 00:01:15.357
that you are the entrepreneur in whom
they are going to invest their money

00:01:15.381 --> 00:01:17.271
and make a lot of money in return.

00:01:17.295 --> 00:01:18.462
Now, how do you do this?

00:01:18.486 --> 00:01:19.986
You can't just walk up and say,

00:01:20.010 --> 00:01:23.954
"Hi, I'm a really good guy, good girl,
and you should invest in me." Right?

00:01:23.978 --> 00:01:27.552
So in the course of your VC pitch --
you have a very few minutes;

00:01:27.576 --> 00:01:30.689
most VC pitches, angel pitches,
are about 15 minutes,

00:01:30.713 --> 00:01:33.133
most should be less than half an hour --

00:01:33.157 --> 00:01:36.075
people's attention span,
after 18 minutes, begins to drop off.

00:01:36.099 --> 00:01:37.250
Tests have shown.

00:01:37.274 --> 00:01:39.469
So in that 18 or 10 or five minutes,

00:01:39.493 --> 00:01:42.429
you have to convey a whole bunch
of different characteristics,

00:01:42.453 --> 00:01:44.515
about 10 different characteristics,

00:01:44.539 --> 00:01:46.032
while you're standing up there.

00:01:46.056 --> 00:01:49.670
What's the single most important thing
you've got to convey? What?

00:01:49.694 --> 00:01:50.888
Audience: Integrity.

00:01:50.912 --> 00:01:52.111
DR: Boy, oh boy, oh boy!

00:01:52.135 --> 00:01:53.921
That's a straight line, look at that!

00:01:53.945 --> 00:01:55.342
And I didn't even prompt him.

00:01:55.366 --> 00:01:57.294
Right, integrity. The key thing.

00:01:57.318 --> 00:02:00.326
I would much rather invest in,
take a chance on,

00:02:00.350 --> 00:02:03.977
somebody who I know is straight
than where there's any possible question

00:02:04.001 --> 00:02:06.499
of who are they looking out for,
and what's going on.

00:02:06.523 --> 00:02:08.507
So the most important thing is integrity.

00:02:08.531 --> 00:02:10.625
What's the second most important thing?

00:02:10.649 --> 00:02:12.275
Let's see if you can get this one.

00:02:12.299 --> 00:02:13.605
Audience: Self-confidence.

00:02:13.629 --> 00:02:14.934
DR: Close enough. Passion.

00:02:15.676 --> 00:02:19.489
Right? Entrepreneurs, by definition,
are people who are leaving something else,

00:02:19.513 --> 00:02:23.195
starting a new world, creating and putting
their lifeblood into this thing.

00:02:23.219 --> 00:02:24.604
You've got to convey passion.

00:02:24.628 --> 00:02:25.931
If you're not passionate,

00:02:25.955 --> 00:02:29.107
why should anyone else be,
or put money into your company

00:02:29.131 --> 00:02:30.822
if you're not passionate about it?

00:02:30.846 --> 00:02:33.154
Integrity, passion:
the most important things.

00:02:33.178 --> 00:02:36.359
Then there's a whole panoply
of other things you've got to wrap up

00:02:36.383 --> 00:02:38.573
in this package you're presenting to a VC.

00:02:38.597 --> 00:02:40.651
Experience: you've got to be able to say,

00:02:40.675 --> 00:02:42.833
"Hey, you know, I've done this before."

00:02:42.857 --> 00:02:45.893
"Done this before" is starting
an enterprise, creating value,

00:02:45.917 --> 00:02:47.926
and taking something
from beginning to end.

00:02:47.950 --> 00:02:50.465
That's why VCs love to fund
serial entrepreneurs --

00:02:50.489 --> 00:02:52.641
even if you didn't do it right
the first time,

00:02:52.665 --> 00:02:56.004
you've learned the lessons, which puts
you in good stead the next time.

00:02:56.028 --> 00:02:59.581
Along with the experience of starting
an enterprise or running something --

00:02:59.605 --> 00:03:01.051
doesn't have to be a business,

00:03:01.075 --> 00:03:03.781
it can be an organization
in a school, a not-for-profit.

00:03:03.805 --> 00:03:05.859
But experience
in creating an organization.

00:03:05.883 --> 00:03:07.034
Next: knowledge.

00:03:07.058 --> 00:03:08.209
If you tell me

00:03:08.233 --> 00:03:11.264
you're going to be the developer
of the map of the human genome,

00:03:11.288 --> 00:03:14.678
you better know what a human genome is;
I want you to have expertise.

00:03:14.702 --> 00:03:16.187
I don't want somebody who says,

00:03:16.211 --> 00:03:18.934
"I've got a great idea
in a business I know nothing about.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.737
I don't know who the players are,
what the market is like."

00:03:21.761 --> 00:03:23.777
You've got to know your market, your area.

00:03:23.801 --> 00:03:25.904
And you have to have
the skills that it takes

00:03:25.928 --> 00:03:27.078
to get a company going.

00:03:27.102 --> 00:03:30.175
Those skills include
everything from technical skills

00:03:30.199 --> 00:03:31.921
if it's a technology business,

00:03:31.945 --> 00:03:34.719
to marketing and sales
and management and so on.

00:03:34.743 --> 00:03:37.425
But, you know, not everybody
has all these skills.

00:03:37.449 --> 00:03:41.144
Very few people have the full set
of skills it takes to run a company.

00:03:41.168 --> 00:03:43.195
What else do you require?
Well, leadership.

00:03:43.219 --> 00:03:46.725
You've got to be able to convince us
that you either have developed a team

00:03:46.749 --> 00:03:49.573
that has all those factors
in it, or else you can.

00:03:49.597 --> 00:03:52.028
And you have the charisma
and the management style

00:03:52.052 --> 00:03:54.831
and the ability to get people
to follow your lead,

00:03:54.855 --> 00:03:58.143
to inspire them, to motivate them
to be part of your team.

00:03:58.167 --> 00:03:59.715
Having done all that,

00:03:59.739 --> 00:04:01.460
what else do I want to know as a VC?

00:04:01.484 --> 00:04:03.579
I want to know that you have commitment.

00:04:03.603 --> 00:04:05.564
That you are going to be here to the end.

00:04:05.588 --> 00:04:08.210
I want you to say --
or I want you to convey --

00:04:08.234 --> 00:04:11.858
that you are going to die if you
have to, with your very last breath,

00:04:11.882 --> 00:04:14.208
your fingernails scratching
as they draw you out.

00:04:14.232 --> 00:04:16.708
You'll keep my money alive
and make more from it.

00:04:16.732 --> 00:04:19.790
I don't want someone who'll
cut and run at the first opportunity.

00:04:19.814 --> 00:04:20.965
Bad things happen.

00:04:20.989 --> 00:04:24.530
There's never been a venture-funded
company where bad things didn't happen.

00:04:24.554 --> 00:04:26.699
So know that you're committed
to the very end.

00:04:26.723 --> 00:04:29.319
You've got to have vision
to see where this is going.

00:04:29.343 --> 00:04:31.156
I don't want another "me too" product.

00:04:31.180 --> 00:04:33.606
I want somebody who can
change the world out there.

00:04:33.630 --> 00:04:35.302
But on top of that, I need realism,

00:04:35.326 --> 00:04:39.483
Because while changing the world
is great, it doesn't always happen.

00:04:39.507 --> 00:04:41.436
And before you get to change the world,

00:04:41.460 --> 00:04:43.131
bad things are going to take place;

00:04:43.155 --> 00:04:44.483
you have to deal with that.

00:04:44.507 --> 00:04:46.512
And you have to have rational projections.

00:04:46.536 --> 00:04:48.455
Finally, you're asking for my money --

00:04:48.479 --> 00:04:50.913
not just because it's my money,
but because it's me.

00:04:50.937 --> 00:04:52.133
You need to be coachable.

00:04:52.157 --> 00:04:54.308
I need to know
you have the ability to listen.

00:04:54.332 --> 00:04:55.772
We've had a lot of experience.

00:04:55.796 --> 00:04:59.075
People who are VCs or angels
investing in you have had experience,

00:04:59.099 --> 00:05:02.099
and they'd like to know that you
want to hear that experience.

00:05:02.123 --> 00:05:05.479
So how do you convey these 10 things
in 10 minutes without saying them?

00:05:05.503 --> 00:05:07.878
You can't say, "I've got
integrity, invest in me!"

00:05:07.902 --> 00:05:11.224
You've got to do a whole pitch
that conveys this without conveying it.

00:05:11.248 --> 00:05:13.015
Think about your pitch as a timeline.

00:05:13.039 --> 00:05:14.921
It starts off, you walk in the door.

00:05:14.945 --> 00:05:16.824
They know nothing whatsoever about you.

00:05:16.848 --> 00:05:20.479
You can take them on an emotional --
all pitches, all sales presentations,

00:05:20.503 --> 00:05:21.869
are emotional at some level.

00:05:21.893 --> 00:05:23.789
You can go up, you can go down, right?

00:05:23.813 --> 00:05:25.437
And it goes from beginning to end.

00:05:25.461 --> 00:05:27.611
You walk in, the first thing
you've got to do,

00:05:27.635 --> 00:05:31.005
the overall arc of your presentation,
it's got to start like a rocket.

00:05:31.029 --> 00:05:32.764
You've got maybe 10 seconds --

00:05:32.788 --> 00:05:35.948
between 10 and 30 seconds,
depending on how long the pitch is --

00:05:35.972 --> 00:05:37.496
to get their attention.

00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:38.966
In my case, I've invested.

00:05:38.990 --> 00:05:41.784
I've gotten millions of dollars
from PowerPoint pitches.

00:05:41.808 --> 00:05:44.667
"I've invested millions."
That should get you right there.

00:05:44.691 --> 00:05:47.005
This can be a fact
or something counterintuitive.

00:05:47.029 --> 00:05:48.728
It can be a story or an experience.

00:05:48.752 --> 00:05:51.836
But you've got to grab
their emotional attention, focused on you,

00:05:51.860 --> 00:05:53.336
within that first few seconds.

00:05:53.360 --> 00:05:55.428
And then from there,
you've got to take them

00:05:55.452 --> 00:05:59.316
on a very solid, steady, upward path,
right from beginning to end.

00:05:59.340 --> 00:06:00.933
Everything has to reinforce this.

00:06:00.957 --> 00:06:03.358
And you've got to get better
and better and better,

00:06:03.382 --> 00:06:04.754
revving up to the very end,

00:06:04.778 --> 00:06:06.285
then you've got to -- boom! --

00:06:06.309 --> 00:06:07.611
knock them out of the park.

00:06:07.635 --> 00:06:09.794
You want to get them
to such an emotional high

00:06:09.818 --> 00:06:12.398
they're ready to write you a check,
throw money at you,

00:06:12.422 --> 00:06:13.573
before you leave.

00:06:13.597 --> 00:06:14.748
How do you do that?

00:06:14.772 --> 00:06:16.586
First of all, logical progression.

00:06:16.610 --> 00:06:19.969
Any time you go backwards,
any time you skip a step --

00:06:19.993 --> 00:06:23.195
imagine walking up a staircase
where some of the treads are missing,

00:06:23.219 --> 00:06:24.935
or the heights are different.

00:06:24.959 --> 00:06:27.852
You stop, you need to figure out
a nice, logical progression.

00:06:27.876 --> 00:06:31.100
Start with what the market is:
Why are you going to do X, Y or Z?

00:06:31.124 --> 00:06:33.815
And then you've got to tell me
how you're going to do it,

00:06:33.839 --> 00:06:35.364
and what you're going to do.

00:06:35.388 --> 00:06:37.553
And it's got to flow
from beginning to end.

00:06:37.577 --> 00:06:39.863
You've got to let me know
there are touchstones,

00:06:39.887 --> 00:06:42.037
to tie in to the rest
of the world out there.

00:06:42.061 --> 00:06:45.359
For example, reference
companies I've heard of,

00:06:45.383 --> 00:06:47.915
or basic items in your business.

00:06:47.939 --> 00:06:50.692
I want to know about things
that I can relate to:

00:06:50.716 --> 00:06:54.413
validators, or anything that tells me
somebody else has approved this,

00:06:54.437 --> 00:06:56.140
or there's outside validation.

00:06:56.164 --> 00:06:59.188
It can be sales; it can be
you got an award for something;

00:06:59.212 --> 00:07:01.910
it can be people have done it before;

00:07:01.934 --> 00:07:04.914
it can be your beta tests
are going great, whatever.

00:07:04.938 --> 00:07:07.835
I want to know validation --
not just what you're telling me,

00:07:07.859 --> 00:07:09.958
but that somebody
or something else out there

00:07:09.982 --> 00:07:11.216
says this makes sense.

00:07:11.240 --> 00:07:14.307
And then, I'm looking for the upside;
I need a believable upside.

00:07:14.331 --> 00:07:16.957
That's two parts; it's got
to be upside and believable.

00:07:16.981 --> 00:07:19.461
The upside means if you tell me
that five years out,

00:07:19.485 --> 00:07:22.544
you're making a million dollars a year,
that's not really upside.

00:07:22.568 --> 00:07:25.149
Telling me you'll be making
a billion dollars a year --

00:07:25.173 --> 00:07:26.324
that's not believable.

00:07:26.348 --> 00:07:27.499
So it's got to be both.

00:07:27.523 --> 00:07:30.544
On the other hand are things
that take the emotional level down.

00:07:30.568 --> 00:07:32.047
You have to recover from those.

00:07:32.071 --> 00:07:34.218
For example, anything
that I know is not true.

00:07:34.242 --> 00:07:36.966
"We have no competition.
Nobody makes a widget like this."

00:07:36.990 --> 00:07:39.094
Odds are I know somebody
who's made a widget,

00:07:39.118 --> 00:07:40.726
and the minute you tell me that,

00:07:40.750 --> 00:07:43.378
I discount half of what
you're saying from then on.

00:07:43.402 --> 00:07:46.147
Anything I don't understand,

00:07:46.171 --> 00:07:48.703
where I have to make the leap
myself, in my own head,

00:07:48.727 --> 00:07:50.655
will stop the flow of the presentation.

00:07:50.679 --> 00:07:53.260
So you've got to take me
through like a sixth-grader --

00:07:53.284 --> 00:07:55.347
dub, dub, dub --
but without patronizing me.

00:07:55.371 --> 00:07:56.934
And it's a very tricky path.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.089
But if you can do it,
it works really well.

00:07:59.113 --> 00:08:02.795
Anything that's inconsistent
within your concept --

00:08:02.819 --> 00:08:05.495
if you tell me sales of X, Y or Z
are 10 million dollars,

00:08:05.519 --> 00:08:07.953
five slides later,
they're five million dollars ...

00:08:07.977 --> 00:08:10.761
One may have been gross sales,
one may have been net sales,

00:08:10.785 --> 00:08:13.668
but I want to know that all the numbers
make sense together.

00:08:13.692 --> 00:08:16.231
And then, finally: anything
that's an error or a typo,

00:08:16.255 --> 00:08:19.128
or a stupid mistake or a line
that's in the wrong place --

00:08:19.152 --> 00:08:22.781
that shows me that if you can't do
a presentation, how can you run a company?

00:08:22.805 --> 00:08:24.677
So this all feeds in together.

00:08:24.701 --> 00:08:27.054
The best way to do this
is to look at our betters,

00:08:27.078 --> 00:08:28.673
people who have done this before.

00:08:28.697 --> 00:08:32.075
Let's look at the most successful
technology executive in the business,

00:08:32.099 --> 00:08:33.911
and see how a presentation goes.

00:08:34.336 --> 00:08:36.569
Bill Gates's PowerPoint
presentation over here.

00:08:36.593 --> 00:08:38.641
Here's Gates doing a thing for Windows.

00:08:38.665 --> 00:08:41.791
Is this how to do a PowerPoint
presentation? What do you think?

00:08:41.815 --> 00:08:44.498
No. Who do you think we should
look at as our role model?

00:08:44.522 --> 00:08:47.322
Oh, isn't that funny!
There's another great one over here.

00:08:47.346 --> 00:08:48.527
OK, Steve Jobs.

00:08:48.551 --> 00:08:52.037
You want absolute --
this is the Zen of presentation, right?

00:08:52.061 --> 00:08:54.847
Here he is, one little guy,
black jeans and stuff,

00:08:54.871 --> 00:08:56.063
on a totally empty stage.

00:08:56.087 --> 00:08:57.665
What are you focusing on?

00:08:57.689 --> 00:08:59.738
You're focusing on him!
This is Steve Jobs.

00:08:59.762 --> 00:09:03.722
So are these wonderful long bullet points,
whole list of things good?

00:09:03.746 --> 00:09:06.277
No, they're not. The long
bullet points are bad.

00:09:06.301 --> 00:09:08.886
What's good? Short. Short bullet points.

00:09:08.910 --> 00:09:12.566
But you know what? Even better than short
bullet points are no bullet points.

00:09:12.590 --> 00:09:13.835
Just give me the headline.

00:09:13.859 --> 00:09:15.010
And you know what?

00:09:15.034 --> 00:09:17.058
How many bullet points
does Steve Jobs use?

00:09:17.082 --> 00:09:18.453
Basically, none.

00:09:18.477 --> 00:09:19.629
What do you do?

00:09:19.653 --> 00:09:22.489
Best of all, images. Just a simple image.

00:09:22.513 --> 00:09:25.144
I look at the image;
a picture's worth a thousand words.

00:09:25.168 --> 00:09:27.652
You look at the image
and you've got the whole thing.

00:09:27.676 --> 00:09:31.110
Then you come back to me; you're focused
on me, why I'm such a great guy,

00:09:31.134 --> 00:09:33.444
why you want to invest,
why this all makes sense.

00:09:33.468 --> 00:09:35.559
That said, we only have a very short time,

00:09:35.583 --> 00:09:38.621
so let's run through the things
to include in your presentation.

00:09:38.645 --> 00:09:41.126
First of all, none of these big,
long-titled slides

00:09:41.150 --> 00:09:43.729
with blah, blah, I'm presenting
to so-and-so on X date.

00:09:43.753 --> 00:09:46.475
I know the day, I know who I am --
I don't need all that.

00:09:46.499 --> 00:09:47.999
Just give me your company logo.

00:09:48.023 --> 00:09:50.230
I look at the logo,
and it ties it to my brain.

00:09:50.254 --> 00:09:53.650
Then I come back to you.
I'm focused on you, OK?

00:09:53.674 --> 00:09:57.599
You give me your quick, 15-second
or 30-second intro, grab my attention.

00:09:57.623 --> 00:09:59.628
Then you give me
a quick business overview.

00:09:59.652 --> 00:10:02.779
This is not a five-minute pitch.
This is, you know, two sentences.

00:10:02.803 --> 00:10:04.832
"We build widgets for the X, Y, Z market."

00:10:04.856 --> 00:10:07.518
Or, "We sell services to help do X."
You know, whatever.

00:10:07.542 --> 00:10:10.706
And that is like the picture
on the outside of a jigsaw puzzle box.

00:10:10.730 --> 00:10:12.187
That lets me know the context.

00:10:12.211 --> 00:10:15.463
It gives me the armature for the whole
thing you'll be going through;

00:10:15.487 --> 00:10:18.349
it lets me put everything
in relation to what you've told me.

00:10:18.373 --> 00:10:22.655
Then you've got to walk me through,
show me who your management team is.

00:10:22.679 --> 00:10:26.228
I want to know the size of the market.
Why is this market worth getting at?

00:10:26.252 --> 00:10:28.662
I want to know your product,
that's very important.

00:10:28.686 --> 00:10:30.937
Now, this is not
a product pitch or sales pitch.

00:10:30.961 --> 00:10:34.154
I don't want to know all the ins and outs,
just what the heck is it?

00:10:34.178 --> 00:10:37.240
If it's a website, show me
a screenshot of your website.

00:10:37.264 --> 00:10:39.276
Don't do a live demo.
Never do a live demo.

00:10:39.300 --> 00:10:41.550
Do a canned demo,
or something that lets me know

00:10:41.574 --> 00:10:43.732
why people are going
to buy whatever it is.

00:10:43.756 --> 00:10:45.996
Now that I know what you're selling,

00:10:46.020 --> 00:10:47.595
tell me how you make money on it.

00:10:47.619 --> 00:10:52.101
For every X you sell, you get Y,
or services of Z.

00:10:52.125 --> 00:10:55.071
I want to know what the business model
is on a per-unit basis,

00:10:55.095 --> 00:10:57.055
or for the actual product you're selling.

00:10:57.079 --> 00:10:59.799
I want to know who you're selling to
in terms of customers

00:10:59.823 --> 00:11:02.709
and if you have any special
relationships that will help you,

00:11:02.733 --> 00:11:05.743
whether it's a distribution relationship
or a producing partner.

00:11:05.767 --> 00:11:06.918
Again, validation.

00:11:06.942 --> 00:11:10.193
This helps to say you're bigger
than just one little thing over here.

00:11:10.217 --> 00:11:11.653
But everybody has competition.

00:11:11.677 --> 00:11:13.987
There's never been a company
with no competition,

00:11:14.011 --> 00:11:16.740
even if the competition
is the old way of doing something.

00:11:16.764 --> 00:11:19.044
I want to know exactly
what your competition is,

00:11:19.068 --> 00:11:22.135
and that will help me judge
how you fit into the whole operation.

00:11:22.159 --> 00:11:23.822
I want to know how you're special.

00:11:23.846 --> 00:11:25.568
I know what your competition does --

00:11:25.592 --> 00:11:28.267
how are you going to prevent
them from eating your lunch?

00:11:28.291 --> 00:11:30.299
All this ties into the financial overview.

00:11:30.323 --> 00:11:33.251
And you can't do a VC pitch
without giving me your financials.

00:11:33.275 --> 00:11:36.781
I want to know a year or two back,
or as long as you've been in existence.

00:11:36.805 --> 00:11:39.050
And I want to know
four or five years forward.

00:11:39.074 --> 00:11:40.703
Five is a bit much. Probably four.

00:11:40.727 --> 00:11:43.693
And I want to know how that business
model, on a product basis,

00:11:43.717 --> 00:11:46.921
will translate into a company model:
How many widgets will you sell?

00:11:46.945 --> 00:11:49.948
You make X amount per widget.
I want to know what the driver is.

00:11:49.972 --> 00:11:52.643
We'll have 1,000 customers
this year and 10,000 the next,

00:11:52.667 --> 00:11:54.338
our revenues will do this and that.

00:11:54.362 --> 00:11:57.083
That gives me the whole picture
for the next several years

00:11:57.107 --> 00:11:58.301
into which I'm investing.

00:11:58.325 --> 00:12:01.386
And I want to know how the money
from me will help you get there.

00:12:01.410 --> 00:12:03.651
You're going to open
an offshore plant in China,

00:12:03.675 --> 00:12:06.114
you're going to spend it all
on sales and marketing,

00:12:06.138 --> 00:12:08.001
you're going to go to Tahiti, whatever.

00:12:08.025 --> 00:12:10.841
But then comes the ask,
where you tell me how much you want.

00:12:10.865 --> 00:12:13.336
You're looking for 5 million --
at what valuation?

00:12:13.360 --> 00:12:15.570
Two million? 100,000?

00:12:15.594 --> 00:12:17.569
What's the money in so far? Who invested?

00:12:17.593 --> 00:12:21.580
I hope you invested -- if you can't invest
in your own thing, why should I?

00:12:21.604 --> 00:12:23.894
So I like to know if you have
friends and family,

00:12:23.918 --> 00:12:25.783
or angel investors, or more VCs before.

00:12:25.807 --> 00:12:28.153
What's the capital structure
up until this point?

00:12:28.177 --> 00:12:31.281
Finally, having done all that,
you've now told me the whole thing,

00:12:31.305 --> 00:12:33.796
so now you bring it back
to that conclusion.

00:12:33.820 --> 00:12:35.216
This is that rocket going up.

00:12:35.240 --> 00:12:37.110
Hopefully everything has been positive.

00:12:37.134 --> 00:12:39.581
And everything you say clicks,
it all makes sense.

00:12:39.605 --> 00:12:41.582
And I'm thinking, "This is really great!"

00:12:41.606 --> 00:12:44.153
Then you take me back
to just your logo on the screen.

00:12:44.177 --> 00:12:45.934
And I look at the logo -- OK, good.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.538
Now I come back to you.
Nothing else to look at, right?

00:12:48.562 --> 00:12:52.085
Now you've got to wrap it up
to give me the final -- boom! --

00:12:52.109 --> 00:12:54.498
the final pitch that's going
to send me into space.

00:12:54.522 --> 00:12:56.574
Now, in the process of doing this,

00:12:56.598 --> 00:12:59.053
how do you remember
the sequences and do it?

00:12:59.077 --> 00:13:01.514
You've noticed I'm not looking
at the screen, right?

00:13:01.538 --> 00:13:03.100
The screen is in front of me,

00:13:03.124 --> 00:13:04.935
so I couldn't even see if I wanted to.

00:13:04.959 --> 00:13:06.534
So how do I know what's going on?

00:13:06.558 --> 00:13:08.352
Well, I have a laptop in front of me.

00:13:08.376 --> 00:13:09.951
You're looking at me and at this.

00:13:09.975 --> 00:13:11.126
What am I looking at?

00:13:11.150 --> 00:13:12.822
You think that I'm looking at that?

00:13:12.846 --> 00:13:14.132
No, I'm looking, actually,

00:13:14.156 --> 00:13:16.496
at a special version
of PowerPoint over here,

00:13:16.520 --> 00:13:19.226
which shows me the slides
ahead and behind, my notes,

00:13:19.250 --> 00:13:20.647
so I can see what's going on.

00:13:20.671 --> 00:13:23.645
PowerPoint has this built into
every copy of it that's shipped.

00:13:23.669 --> 00:13:26.488
If you use Apple's Keynote,
it's got an even better version.

00:13:26.512 --> 00:13:29.545
There's another program called
Ovation you can get from Adobe

00:13:29.569 --> 00:13:30.954
that they bought last summer,

00:13:30.978 --> 00:13:34.665
which helps you run the timers
and lets you figure out what's going on.

00:13:34.689 --> 00:13:37.247
So, here's my wrap-up
to take you to the moon, right?

00:13:37.271 --> 00:13:39.425
I usually do a Top 10,
but we don't have time,

00:13:39.449 --> 00:13:41.338
so: David's Top Five Presentation Tips.

00:13:41.362 --> 00:13:43.701
Number five: always use presenter mode,

00:13:43.725 --> 00:13:46.098
or Ovation, or presenter tools.

00:13:46.122 --> 00:13:48.202
It lets you know
exactly where you're going,

00:13:48.226 --> 00:13:51.102
helps you pace yourself,
gives you a timer, the whole bit.

00:13:51.126 --> 00:13:52.992
Number four: always use remote control.

00:13:53.016 --> 00:13:55.315
Have you seen me touch
the computer? No. Why not?

00:13:55.339 --> 00:13:58.156
Because I'm using remote control.
Always use remote control.

00:13:58.180 --> 00:14:01.110
Number three: the handouts you give
are not your presentation.

00:14:01.134 --> 00:14:02.522
If you follow my suggestions,

00:14:02.546 --> 00:14:04.797
you'll have a very spare,
Zen-like presentation,

00:14:04.821 --> 00:14:08.253
which is great to convey who you are
and get people emotionally involved,

00:14:08.277 --> 00:14:09.523
but not good as a handout.

00:14:09.547 --> 00:14:13.124
You want a handout that gives more
information; it has to stand without you.

00:14:13.148 --> 00:14:15.677
Number two: don't read your speech.
Can you imagine?

00:14:15.701 --> 00:14:17.946
(Reading) "You should invest
in my company ... "

00:14:17.970 --> 00:14:19.122
It doesn't work.

00:14:19.146 --> 00:14:22.747
And the number one presentation tip:
never, ever look at the screen.

00:14:22.771 --> 00:14:24.955
You're making a connection
with your audience,

00:14:24.979 --> 00:14:27.457
and you always want
a one-on-one connection.

00:14:27.481 --> 00:14:29.516
The screen should come up behind you

00:14:29.540 --> 00:14:32.211
and supplement what you're doing,
instead of replace you.

00:14:32.235 --> 00:14:33.808
And that is how to pitch to a VC.

title: Health and the human mind
transcript: If you ask people about what part of psychology do they think is hard, and you say, "Well, what about thinking and emotions?" Most people will say, "Emotions are terribly hard. They're incredibly complex. They can't — I have no idea of how they work. But thinking is really very straightforward: it's just sort of some kind of logical reasoning, or something. But that's not the hard part."So here's a list of problems that come up. One nice problem is, what do we do about health? The other day, I was reading something, and the person said probably the largest single cause of disease is handshaking in the West. And there was a little study about people who don't handshake, and comparing them with ones who do handshake. And I haven't the foggiest idea of where you find the ones that don't handshake, because they must be hiding. And the people who avoid that have 30 percent less infectious disease or something. Or maybe it was 31 and a quarter percent. So if you really want to solve the problem of epidemics and so forth, let's start with that. And since I got that idea, I've had to shake hundreds of hands. And I think the only way to avoid it is to have some horrible visible disease, and then you don't have to explain.Education: how do we improve education? Well, the single best way is to get them to understand that what they're being told is a whole lot of nonsense. And then, of course, you have to do something about how to moderate that, so that anybody can — so they'll listen to you. Pollution, energy shortage, environmental diversity, poverty. How do we make stable societies? Longevity. Okay, there're lots of problems to worry about.Anyway, the question I think people should talk about — and it's absolutely taboo — is, how many people should there be? And I think it should be about 100 million or maybe 500 million. And then notice that a great many of these problems disappear. If you had 100 million people properly spread out, then if there's some garbage, you throw it away, preferably where you can't see it, and it will rot. Or you throw it into the ocean and some fish will benefit from it. The problem is, how many people should there be? And it's a sort of choice we have to make.Most people are about 60 inches high or more, and there's these cube laws. So if you make them this big, by using nanotechnology, I suppose — (Laughter) — then you could have a thousand times as many. That would solve the problem, but I don't see anybody doing any research on making people smaller. Now, it's nice to reduce the population, but a lot of people want to have children. And there's one solution that's probably only a few years off. You know you have 46 chromosomes. If you're lucky, you've got 23 from each parent. Sometimes you get an extra one or drop one out, but — so you can skip the grandparent and great-grandparent stage and go right to the great-great-grandparent. And you have 46 people and you give them a scanner, or whatever you need, and they look at their chromosomes and each of them says which one he likes best, or she — no reason to have just two sexes any more, even. So each child has 46 parents, and I suppose you could let each group of 46 parents have 15 children. Wouldn't that be enough? And then the children would get plenty of support, and nurturing, and mentoring, and the world population would decline very rapidly and everybody would be totally happy.Timesharing is a little further off in the future. And there's this great novel that Arthur Clarke wrote twice, called "Against the Fall of Night" and "The City and the Stars." They're both wonderful and largely the same, except that computers happened in between. And Arthur was looking at this old book, and he said, "Well, that was wrong. The future must have some computers." So in the second version of it, there are 100 billion or 1,000 billion people on Earth, but they're all stored on hard disks or floppies, or whatever they have in the future. And you let a few million of them out at a time. A person comes out, they live for a thousand years doing whatever they do, and then, when it's time to go back for a billion years — or a million, I forget, the numbers don't matter — but there really aren't very many people on Earth at a time. And you get to think about yourself and your memories, and before you go back into suspension, you edit your memories and you change your personality and so forth. The plot of the book is that there's not enough diversity, so that the people who designed the city make sure that every now and then an entirely new person is created. And in the novel, a particular one named Alvin is created. And he says, maybe this isn't the best way, and wrecks the whole system.I don't think the solutions that I proposed are good enough or smart enough. I think the big problem is that we're not smart enough to understand which of the problems we're facing are good enough. Therefore, we have to build super intelligent machines like HAL. As you remember, at some point in the book for "2001," HAL realizes that the universe is too big, and grand, and profound for those really stupid astronauts. If you contrast HAL's behavior with the triviality of the people on the spaceship, you can see what's written between the lines. Well, what are we going to do about that? We could get smarter. I think that we're pretty smart, as compared to chimpanzees, but we're not smart enough to deal with the colossal problems that we face, either in abstract mathematics or in figuring out economies, or balancing the world around. So one thing we can do is live longer. And nobody knows how hard that is, but we'll probably find out in a few years. You see, there's two forks in the road. We know that people live twice as long as chimpanzees almost, and nobody lives more than 120 years, for reasons that aren't very well understood. But lots of people now live to 90 or 100, unless they shake hands too much or something like that. And so maybe if we lived 200 years, we could accumulate enough skills and knowledge to solve some problems. So that's one way of going about it. And as I said, we don't know how hard that is. It might be — after all, most other mammals live half as long as the chimpanzee, so we're sort of three and a half or four times, have four times the longevity of most mammals. And in the case of the primates, we have almost the same genes. We only differ from chimpanzees, in the present state of knowledge, which is absolute hogwash, maybe by just a few hundred genes.What I think is that the gene counters don't know what they're doing yet. And whatever you do, don't read anything about genetics that's published within your lifetime, or something. (Laughter) The stuff has a very short half-life, same with brain science. And so it might be that if we just fix four or five genes, we can live 200 years. Or it might be that it's just 30 or 40, and I doubt that it's several hundred. So this is something that people will be discussing and lots of ethicists — you know, an ethicist is somebody who sees something wrong with whatever you have in mind. (Laughter) And it's very hard to find an ethicist who considers any change worth making, because he says, what about the consequences? And, of course, we're not responsible for the consequences of what we're doing now, are we? Like all this complaint about clones. And yet two random people will mate and have this child, and both of them have some pretty rotten genes, and the child is likely to come out to be average. Which, by chimpanzee standards, is very good indeed.If we do have longevity, then we'll have to face the population growth problem anyway. Because if people live 200 or 1,000 years, then we can't let them have a child more than about once every 200 or 1,000 years. And so there won't be any workforce. And one of the things Laurie Garrett pointed out, and others have, is that a society that doesn't have people of working age is in real trouble. And things are going to get worse, because there's nobody to educate the children or to feed the old. And when I'm talking about a long lifetime, of course, I don't want somebody who's 200 years old to be like our image of what a 200-year-old is — which is dead, actually.You know, there's about 400 different parts of the brain which seem to have different functions. Nobody knows how most of them work in detail, but we do know that there're lots of different things in there. And they don't always work together. I like Freud's theory that most of them are cancelling each other out. And so if you think of yourself as a sort of city with a hundred resources, then, when you're afraid, for example, you may discard your long-range goals, but you may think deeply and focus on exactly how to achieve that particular goal. You throw everything else away. You become a monomaniac — all you care about is not stepping out on that platform. And when you're hungry, food becomes more attractive, and so forth. So I see emotions as highly evolved subsets of your capability. Emotion is not something added to thought. An emotional state is what you get when you remove 100 or 200 of your normally available resources.So thinking of emotions as the opposite of — as something less than thinking is immensely productive. And I hope, in the next few years, to show that this will lead to smart machines. And I guess I better skip all the rest of this, which are some details on how we might make those smart machines and — (Laughter) — and the main idea is in fact that the core of a really smart machine is one that recognizes that a certain kind of problem is facing you. This is a problem of such and such a type, and therefore there's a certain way or ways of thinking that are good for that problem. So I think the future, main problem of psychology is to classify types of predicaments, types of situations, types of obstacles and also to classify available and possible ways to think and pair them up. So you see, it's almost like a Pavlovian — we lost the first hundred years of psychology by really trivial theories, where you say, how do people learn how to react to a situation? What I'm saying is, after we go through a lot of levels, including designing a huge, messy system with thousands of ports, we'll end up again with the central problem of psychology. Some problems are good for neural nets; we know that others, neural nets are hopeless on them. Genetic algorithms are great for certain things; I suspect I know what they're bad at, and I won't tell you. (Laughter)Thank you. (Applause)
