And in it, Tolstoy told of a trip that he'd recently made

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
to a very remote area of the Caucasus,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
where there were only wild barbarians,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
who had never left this part of Russia.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Knowing that Tolstoy was in their midst,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
they asked him to tell stories of the great men of history.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
So he said, "I told them about Napoleon

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and Alexander the Great and Frederick the Great

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and Julius Caesar, and they loved it.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
But before I finished, the chief of the barbarians stood up and said,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
'But wait, you haven't told us about the greatest ruler of them all.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
We want to hear about that man who spoke with a voice of thunder,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:05.958
who laughed like the sunrise,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
who came from that place called America, which is so far from here,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
that if a young man should travel there,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
he would be an old man when he arrived.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:16.958
Tell us of that man. Tell us of Abraham Lincoln.'"

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:17.958
He was stunned.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
He told them everything he could about Lincoln.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
And then in the interview he said, "What made Lincoln so great?

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
Not as great a general as Napoleon,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
not as great a statesman as Frederick the Great."

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
But his greatness consisted, and historians would roundly agree,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
in the integrity of his character

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and the moral fiber of his being.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So in the end that powerful ambition

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
that had carried Lincoln through his bleak childhood had been realized.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:43.958
That ambition that had allowed him to laboriously educate himself by himself,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
to go through that string of political failures

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and the darkest days of the war.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
His story would be told.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
So as for that second sphere, not of work, but of love --

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
encompassing family, friends and colleagues --

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
it, too, takes work and commitment.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
The Lyndon Johnson that I saw in the last years of his life,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
when I helped him on his memoirs,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
was a man who had spent so many years in the pursuit of

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
work, power and individual success,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
that he had absolutely no psychic or emotional resources left

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:13.958
to get him through the days

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
once the presidency was gone.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
My relationship with him began on a rather curious level.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
I was selected as a White House Fellow when I was 24 years old.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
We had a big dance at the White House.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
President Johnson did dance with me that night.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:27.958
Not that peculiar --

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
there were only three women out of the 16 White House Fellows.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
But he did whisper in my ear that he wanted me

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
to work directly for him in the White House.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:35.958
But it was not to be that simple.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
For in the months leading up to my selection,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
like many young people, I'd been active

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
in the anti-Vietnam War movement,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and had written an article against Lyndon Johnson,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:45.958
which unfortunately came out in The New Republic

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
two days after the dance in the White House.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
(Laugher)

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
And the theme of the article was how to remove Lyndon Johnson from power.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:53.958
(Laughter)

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So I was certain he would kick me out of the program.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:57.958
But instead, surprisingly, he said,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
"Oh, bring her down here for a year,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
and if I can't win her over, no one can."

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
So I did end up working for him in the White House.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
Eventually accompanied him to his ranch to help him on those memoirs,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
never fully understanding why he'd chosen me to spend so many hours with.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
I like to believe it was because I was a good listener.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:14.958
He was a great storyteller.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Fabulous, colorful, anecdotal stories.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
There was a problem with these stories, however,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
which I later discovered, which is that half of them weren't true.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:22.958
But they were great, nonetheless.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:23.958
(Laughter)

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
So I think that part of his attraction for me was that I loved listening to his tall tales.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
But I also worried that part of it was that I was then a young woman.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And he had somewhat of a minor league womanizing reputation.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
So I constantly chatted to him about boyfriends,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
even when I didn't have any at all.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Everything was working perfectly,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
until one day he said he wanted to discuss our relationship.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Sounded very ominous when he took me nearby to the lake,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
conveniently called Lake Lyndon Baines Johnson.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And there was wine and cheese and a red-checked tablecloth --

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
all the romantic trappings.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:52.958
And he started out,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
"Doris, more than any other woman I have ever known ... "

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
And my heart sank.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And then he said,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
"You remind me of my mother."

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:00.958
(Laughter)

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:05.958
It was pretty embarrassing, given what was going on in my mind.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
But I must say, the older I've gotten,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
the more I realize what an incredible privilege it was

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
to have spent so many hours with this aging lion of a man.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
A victor in a thousand contests,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:20.958
three great civil rights laws, Medicare, aid to education.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And yet, roundly defeated in the end by the war in Vietnam.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And because he was so sad and so vulnerable,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
he opened up to me in ways he never would have

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
had I known him at the height of his power --

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
sharing his fears, his sorrows and his worries.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
And I'd like to believe that the privilege fired within me

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
the drive to understand the inner person behind the public figure,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that I've tried to bring to each of my books since then.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
But it also brought home to me the lessons

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
which Erik Erikson had tried to instill in all of us

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
about the importance of finding balance in life.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
For on the surface, Lyndon Johnson should have had

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
everything in the world to feel good about in those last years,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
in the sense that he had been elected to the presidency;

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
he had all the money he needed to pursue

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
any leisure activity he wanted;

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
he owned a spacious ranch in the countryside, a penthouse in the city,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
sailboats, speedboats.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
He had servants to answer any whim,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
and he had a family who loved him deeply.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
And yet, years of concentration solely on work and individual success

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
meant that in his retirement he could find no solace

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
in family, in recreation, in sports or in hobbies.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
It was almost as if the hole in his heart was so large

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
that even the love of a family, without work, could not fill it.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
As his spirits sagged, his body deteriorated

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
until, I believe, he slowly brought about his own death.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
In those last years, he said he was so sad

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
watching the American people look toward a new president and forgetting him.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
He spoke with immense sadness in his voice,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
saying maybe he should have spent more time with his children,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and their children in turn.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
But it was too late.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Despite all that power, all that wealth,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
he was alone when he finally died --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
his ultimate terror realized.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
So as for that third sphere of play,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
which he never had learned to enjoy,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
I've learned over the years

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
that even this sphere requires a commitment of time and energy --

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
enough so that a hobby, a sport, a love of music,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
or art, or literature, or any form of recreation,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
can provide true pleasure, relaxation and replenishment.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
So deep, for instance, was Abraham Lincoln's love of Shakespeare,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
that he made time to spend more than a hundred nights in the theater,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
even during those dark days of the war.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
He said, when the lights went down and a Shakespeare play came on,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
for a few precious hours he could imagine himself

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
back in Prince Hal's time.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
But an even more important form of relaxation for him,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
that Lyndon Johnson never could enjoy,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
was a love of -- somehow -- humor,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
and feeling out what hilarious parts of life can produce

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
as a sidelight to the sadness.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
He once said that he laughed so he did not cry,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
that a good story, for him, was better than a drop of whiskey.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
His storytelling powers had first been recognized

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:00.958
when he was on the circuit in Illinois.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
The lawyers and the judges would travel

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
from one county courthouse to the other,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and when anyone was knowing Lincoln was in town,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
they would come from miles around to listen to him tell stories.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
He would stand with his back against a fire

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and entertain the crowd for hours with his winding tales.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
And all these stories became part of his memory bank,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
so he could call on them whenever he needed to.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
And they're not quite what you might expect from our marble monument.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
One of his favorite stories, for example,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
had to do with the Revolutionary War hero, Ethan Allen.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
And as Lincoln told the story,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Mr. Allen went to Britain after the war.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
And the British people were still upset

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:34.958
about losing the Revolution,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
so they decided to embarrass him a little bit

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
by putting a huge picture of General Washington

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
in the only outhouse, where he'd have to encounter it.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
They figured he'd be upset about the indignity

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
of George Washington being in an outhouse.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
But he came out of the outhouse not upset at all.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
And so they said, "Well, did you see George Washington in there?"

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
"Oh, yes," he said, "perfectly appropriate place for him."

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
"What do you mean?" they said.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
"Well," he said, "there's nothing to make an Englishman shit

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
faster than the sight of General George Washington."

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
(Laughter)

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:04.958
(Applause)

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
So you can imagine, if you are in the middle of a tense cabinet meeting --

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and he had hundreds of these stories --

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
you would have to relax.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
So between his nightly treks to the theater,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
his story telling, and his extraordinary sense of humor

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and his love of quoting Shakespeare and poetry,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
he found that form of play which carried him through his days.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
In my own life, I shall always be grateful

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
for having found a form of play in my irrational love of baseball.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Which allows me, from the beginning of spring training

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:36.958
to the end of the fall,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
to have something to occupy my mind and heart

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
other than my work.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
It all began when I was only six years old,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and my father taught me that mysterious art of keeping score

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
while listening to baseball games --

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
so that when he went to work in New York during the day,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
I could record for him the history of that afternoon's

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
Brooklyn Dodgers game.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:54.958
Now, when you're only six years old,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:55.958
and your father comes home every single night

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
and listens to you -- as I now realize that I, in excruciating detail,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:00.958
recounted every single play of every inning

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
of the game that had just taken place that afternoon.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
But he made me feel I was telling him a fabulous story.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
It makes you think there's something magic about history

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
to keep your father's attention.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
In fact, I'm convinced I learned the narrative art

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
from those nightly sessions with my father.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
Because at first, I'd be so excited I would blurt out,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
"The Dodgers won!" or, "The Dodgers lost!"

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Which took much of the drama of this two-hour telling away.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:22.958
(Laughter)

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
So I finally learned you had to tell a story

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:25.958
from beginning to middle to end.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
I must say, so fervent was my love

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
of the old Brooklyn Dodgers in those days

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
that I had to confess in my first confession

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
two sins that related to baseball.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
The first occurred because the Dodgers' catcher, Roy Campanella,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
came to my hometown of Rockville Centre, Long Island,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
just as I was in preparation for my first Holy Communion.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
And I was so excited --

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
first person I'd ever see outside of Ebbets Field.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
But it so happened he was speaking in a Protestant Church.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:50.958
When you are brought up as a Catholic, you think

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
that if you ever set foot in a Protestant Church,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
you'll be struck dead at the threshold.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
So I went to my father in tears, "What are we going to do?"

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
He said, "Don't worry. He's speaking in a parish hall.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
We're sitting in folding chairs. He's talking about sportsmanship.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:01.958
It's not a sin."

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
But as I left that night, I was certain that somehow

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
I'd traded the life of my everlasting soul

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
for this one night with Roy Campanella.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:09.958
(Laughter)

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
And there were no indulgences around that I could buy.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
So I had this sin on my soul when I went to my first confession.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:16.958
I told the priest right away.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
He said, "No problem. It wasn't a religious service."

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
But then, unfortunately, he said, "And what else, my child?"

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
And then came my second sin.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
I tried to sandwich it in between talking too much in church,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
wishing harm to others, being mean to my sisters.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
And he said, "To whom did you wish harm?"

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
And I had to say that I wished that various New York Yankees players

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
would break arms, legs and ankles --

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:37.958
(Laughter)

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
-- so that the Brooklyn Dodgers could win their first World Series.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:41.958
He said, "How often do you make these horrible wishes?"

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
And I had to say, every night when I said my prayers.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:45.958
(Laughter)

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:46.958
So he said, "Look, I'll tell you something.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
I love the Brooklyn Dodgers, as you do,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
but I promise you some day they will win fairly and squarely.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
You do not need to wish harm on others to make it happen."

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:54.958
"Oh yes," I said.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
But luckily, my first confession -- to a baseball-loving priest!

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:58.958
(Laughter)

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
Well, though my father died of a sudden heart attack

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:02.958
when I was still in my 20s,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:06.958
before I had gotten married and had my three sons,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
I have passed his memory -- as well as his love of baseball -- on to my boys.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
Though when the Dodgers abandoned us to come to L.A.,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.958
I lost faith in baseball until I moved to Boston

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
and became an irrational Red Socks fan.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
And I must say, even now, when I sit with my sons

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
with our season tickets,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
I can sometimes close my eyes against the sun

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:29.958
and imagine myself, a young girl once more, in the presence of my father,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
watching the players of my youth on the grassy fields below:

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.958
Jackie Robinson, Roy Campanella, Pee Wee Reese, and Duke Snider.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
I must say there is magic in these moments.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
When I open my eyes and I see my sons

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
in the place where my father once sat,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
I feel an invisible loyalty and love

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:49.958
linking my sons to the grandfather whose face they never had a chance to see,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
but whose heart and soul they have come to know

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
through all the stories I have told.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Which is why, in the end, I shall always be grateful for this curious love of history,

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:01.958
allowing me to spend a lifetime looking back into the past.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
Allowing me to learn from these large figures

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
about the struggle for meaning for life.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
Allowing me to believe that the private people

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
we have loved and lost in our families,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
and the public figures we have respected in our history,

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:15.958
just as Abraham Lincoln wanted to believe,

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
really can live on, so long as we pledge

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:22.958
to tell and to retell the stories of their lives.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
Thank you for letting me be that storyteller today.

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:25.958
(Applause)

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:28.958
Thank you.

title: The Web as a city
transcript: I want to take you back basically to my hometown, and to a picture of my hometown of the week that "Emergence" came out. And it's a picture we've seen several times. Basically, "Emergence" was published on 9/11. I live right there in the West Village, so the plume was luckily blowing west, away from us. We had a two-and-a-half-day-old baby in the house that was ours — we hadn't taken it from somebody else.(Laughter)And one of the thoughts that I had dealing with these two separate emergences of a book and a baby, and having this event happen so close — that my first thought, when I was still kind of in the apartment looking out at it all or walking out on the street and looking out on it just in front of our building, was that I'd made a terrible miscalculation in the book that I'd just written. Because so much of that book was a celebration of the power and creative potential of density, of largely urban density, of connecting people and putting them together in one place, and putting them on sidewalks together and having them share ideas and share physical space together.And it seemed to me looking at that — that tower burning and then falling, those towers burning and falling — that in fact, one of the lessons here was that density kills. And that of all the technologies that were exploited to make that carnage come into being, probably the single group of technologies that cost the most lives were those that enable 50,000 people to live in two buildings 110 stories above the ground. If they hadn't been crowded — you compare the loss of life at the Pentagon to the Twin Towers, and you can see that very powerfully. And so I started to think, well, you know, density, density — I'm not sure if, you know, this was the right call.And I kind of ruminated on that for a couple of days. And then about two days later, the wind started to change a little bit, and you could sense that the air was not healthy. And so even though there were no cars still in the West Village where we lived, my wife sent me out to buy a, you know, a large air filter at the Bed Bath and Beyond, which was located about 20 blocks away, north. And so I went out. And obviously I'm physically a very strong person, as you can tell — (Laughter) — so I wasn't worried about carrying this thing 20 blocks. And I walked out, and this really miraculous thing happened to me as I was walking north to buy this air filter, which was that the streets were completely alive with people.There was an incredible — it was, you know, a beautiful day, as it was for about a week after, and the West Village had never seemed more lively. I walked up along Hudson Street — where Jane Jacobs had lived and written her great book that so influenced what I was writing in "Emergence" — past the White Horse Tavern, that great old bar where Dylan Thomas drank himself to death, and the Bleecker Street playground was filled with kids. And all the people who lived in the neighborhood, who owned restaurants and bars in the neighborhood, were all out there — had them all open. People were out. There were no cars, so it seemed even better, in some ways. And it was a beautiful urban day, and the incredible thing about it was that the city was working. The city was there. All the things that make a great city successful and all the things that make a great city stimulating — they were all on display there on those streets.And I thought, well, this is the power of a city. I mean, the power of the city — we talked about cities as being centralized in space, but what makes them so strong most of the time is they're decentralized in function. They don't have a center executive branch that you can take out and cause the whole thing to fail. If they did, it probably was right there at Ground Zero. I mean, you know, the emergency bunker was right there, was destroyed by the attacks, and obviously the damage done to the building and the lives. But nonetheless, just 20 blocks north, two days later, the city had never looked more alive. If you'd gone into the minds of the people, well, you would have seen a lot of trauma, and you would have seen a lot of heartache, and you would have seen a lot of things that would take a long time to recover.But the system itself of this city was thriving. So I took heart in seeing that. So I wanted to talk a little bit about the reasons why that works so well, and how some of those reasons kind of map on to where the Web is going right now. The question that I found myself asking to people when I was talking about the book afterwards is — when you've talked about emergent behavior, when you've talked about collective intelligence, the best way to get people to kind of wrap their heads around that is to ask, who builds a neighborhood? Who decides that Soho should have this personality and that the Latin Quarter should have this personality? Well, there are some kind of executive decisions, but mostly the answer is — everybody and nobody. Everybody contributes a little bit. No single person is really the ultimate actor behind the personality of a neighborhood.Same thing to the question of, who was keeping the streets alive post-9/11 in my neighborhood? Well, it was the whole city. The whole system kind of working on it, and everybody contributing a small little part. And this is increasingly what we're starting to see on the Web in a bunch of interesting ways — most of which weren't around, actually, except in very experimental things, when I was writing "Emergence" and when the book came out. So it's been a very optimistic time, I think, and I want to just talk about a few of those things. I think that there is effectively a new kind of model of interactivity that's starting to emerge online right now.And the old one looked like this. This is not the future King of England, although it looks like it. It's some guy, it's a GeoCities homepage of some guy that I found online who's interested, if you look at the bottom, in soccer and Jesus and Garth Brooks and Clint Beckham and "my hometown" — those are his links. But nothing really says this model of interactivity — which was so exciting and captures the real, the Web Zeitgeist of 1995 — than "Click here for a picture of my dog." That is — you know, there's no sentence that kind of conjures up that period better than that, I think, which is that you suddenly have the power to put up a picture of your dog and link to it, and somebody reading the page has the power to click on that link or not click on that link.And, you know, I don't want to belittle that. That, in a sense — to reference what Jeff was talking about yesterday — that was, in a sense, the kind of interface electricity that powered a lot of the explosion of interest in the Web: that you could put up a link, and somebody could click on it, and it could take you anywhere you wanted to go. But it's still a very one-to-one kind of relationship. There's one person putting up the link, and there's another person on the other end trying to decide whether to click on it or not. The new model is much more like this, and we've already seen a couple of references to this. This is what happens when you search "Steven Johnson" on Google. About two months ago, I had the great breakthrough — one of my great, kind of shining achievements — which is that my website finally became a top result for "Steven Johnson." There's some theoretical physicist at MIT named Steven Johnson who has dropped two spots, I'm happy to say.(Laughter)And, you know, I mean, I'll look at a couple of things like this, but Google is obviously the greatest technology ever invented for navel gazing. It's just that there are so many other people in your navel when you gaze. Because effectively, what's happening here, what's creating this page, obviously — and we all know this, but it's worth just thinking about it — is not some person deciding that I am the number one answer for Steven Johnson, but rather somehow the entire web of people putting up pages and deciding to link to my page or not link to it, and Google just sitting there and running the numbers. So there's this collective decision-making that's going on. This page is effectively, collectively authored by the Web, and Google is just helping us kind of to put the authorship in one kind of coherent place.Now, they're more innovative — well, Google's pretty innovative — but there are some new twists on this. There's this incredibly interesting new site — Technorati — that's filled with lots of little widgets that are expanding on these. And these are looking in the blog world and the world of weblogs. He's analyzed basically all the weblogs out there that he's tracking. And he's tracking how many other weblogs linked to those weblogs, and so you have kind of an authority — a weblog that has a lot of links to it is more authoritative than a weblog that has few links to it. And so at any given time, on any given page on the Web, actually, you can say, what does the weblog community think about this page? And you can get a list. This is what they think about my site; it's ranked by blog authority. You can also rank it by the latest posts.So when I was talking in "Emergence," I talked about the limitations of the one-way linking architecture that, basically, you could link to somebody else but they wouldn't necessarily know that you were pointing to them. And that was one of the reasons why the web wasn't quite as emergent as it could be because you needed two-way linking, you needed that kind of feedback mechanism to be able to really do interesting things. Well, something like Technorati is supplying that. Now what's interesting here is that this is a quote from Dave Weinberger, where he talks about everything being purposive in the Web — there's nothing artificial. He has this line where he says, you know, you're going to put up a link there, if you see a link, somebody decided to put it there. And he says, the link to one site didn't just grow on the other page "like a tree fungus."And in fact, I think that's not entirely true anymore. I could put up a feed of all those links generated by Technorati on the right-hand side of my page, and they would change as the overall ecology of the Web changes. That little list there would change. I wouldn't really be directly in control of it. So it's much closer, in a way, to a data fungus, in a sense, wrapped around that page, than it is to a deliberate link that I've placed there. Now, what you're having here is basically a global brain that you're able to do lots of kind of experiments on to see what it's thinking. And there are all these interesting tools. Google does the Google Zeitgeist, which looks at search requests to test what's going on, what people are interested in, and they publish it with lots of fun graphs. And I'm saying a lot of nice things about Google, so I'll be I'll be saying one little critical thing.There's a problem with the Google Zeitgeist, which is it often comes back with news that a lot of people are searching for Britney Spears pictures, which is not necessarily news. The Columbia blows up, suddenly there are a lot of searches on Columbia. Well, you know, we should expect to see that. That's not necessarily something we didn't know already. So the key thing in terms of these new tools that are kind of plumbing the depths of the global brain, that are sending kind of trace dyes through that whole bloodstream — the question is, are you finding out something new?And one of the things that I experimented with is this thing called Google Share which is basically, you take an abstract term, and you search Google for that term, and then you search the results that you get back for somebody's name. So basically, the number of pages that mention this term, that also mention this page, the percentage of those pages is that person's Google Share of that term. So you can do kind of interesting contests. Like for instance, this is a Google Share of the TED Conference. So Richard Saul Wurman has about a 15 percent Google Share of the TED conference. Our good friend Chris has about a six percent — but with a bullet, I might add.(Laughter)But the interesting thing is, you can broaden the search a little bit. And it turns out, actually, that 42 percent is the Mola mola fish. I had no idea. No, that's not true. (Laughter) I made that up because I just wanted to put up a slide of the Mola mola fish.(Laughter)I also did — and I don't want to start a little fight in the next panel — but I did a Google Share analysis of evolution and natural selection. So right here — now this is a big category, you have smaller percentages, so this is 0.7 percent — Dan Dennett, who'll be speaking shortly. Right below him, 0.5 percent, Steven Pinker. So Dennett's in the lead a little bit there. But what's interesting is you can then broaden the search and actually see interesting things and get a sense of what else is out there. So Gary Bauer is not too far behind — has slightly different theories about evolution and natural selection. And right behind him is L. Ron Hubbard. So — (Laughter) you can see we're in the ascot, which is always good. And by the way, Chris, that would've been a really good panel, I think, right there.(Laughter)Hubbard apparently started to reach, but besides that, I think it would be good next year. Another quick thing — this is a slightly different thing, but this analysis some of you may have seen. It just came out. This is bursty words, looking at the historical record of State of the Union Addresses. So these are words that suddenly start to appear out of nowhere, so they're kind of, you know, memes that start taking off, that didn't have a lot of historical precedent before. So the first one is — these are the bursty words around 1860s — slaves, emancipation, slavery, rebellion, Kansas. That's Britney Spears. I mean, you know, OK, interesting. They're talking about slavery in 1860. 1935 — relief, depression, recovery banks. And OK, I didn't learn anything new there as well — that's pretty obvious. 1985, right at the center of the Reagan years — that's, we're, there's, we've, it's.(Laughter)Now, there's one way to interpret this, which is to say that "emancipation" and "depression" and "recovery" all have a lot of syllables. So you know, you can actually download — it's hard to remember those. But seriously, actually, what you can see there, in a way that would be very hard to detect otherwise, is Reagan reinventing the political language of the country and shifting to a much more intimate, much more folksy, much more telegenic — contracting all those verbs. You know, 20 years before it was still, "Ask not what you can do," but with Reagan, it's, "that's where, there's Nancy and I," that kind of language. And so something we kind of knew, but you didn't actually notice syntactically what he was doing. I'll go very quickly. The question now — and this is the really interesting question — is, what kind of higher-level shape is emerging right now in the overall Web ecosystem — and particularly in the ecosystem of the blogs because they are really kind of at the cutting edge.And I think what happens there will also happen in the wider system. Now there was a very interesting article by Clay Shirky that got a lot of attention about a month ago, and this is basically the distribution of links on the web to all these various different blogs. It follows a power law, so that there are a few extremely well-linked to, popular blogs, and a long tail of blogs with very few links. So 20 percent of the blogs get 80 percent of the links. Now this is a very interesting thing. It's caused a lot of controversy because people thought that this was the ultimate kind of one man, one modem democracy, where anybody can get out there and get their voice heard.And so the question is, "Why is this happening?" It's not being imposed by fiat from above. It's an emergent property of the blogosphere right now. Now, what's great about it is that people are working on — within seconds of Clay publishing this piece, people started working on changing the underlying rules of the system so that a different shape would start appearing. And basically, the shape appears largely because of a kind of a first-mover advantage. if you're the first site there, everybody links to you. If you're the second site there, most people link to you. And so very quickly you can accumulate a bunch of links, and it makes it more likely for newcomers to link to you in the future, and then you get this kind of shape. And so what Dave Sifry at Technorati started working on, literally as Shirky started — after he published his piece — was something that basically just gave a new kind of priority to newcomers. And he started looking at interesting newcomers that don't have a lot of links, that suddenly get a bunch of links in the last 24 hours.So in a sense, bursty weblogs coming from new voices. So he's working on a tool right there that can actually change the overall system. And it creates a kind of planned emergence. You're not totally in control, but you're changing the underlying rules in interesting ways because you have an end result which is maybe a more democratic spread of voices. So the most amazing thing about this — and I'll end on this note — is, most emergent systems, most self-organizing systems are not made up of component parts that are capable of looking at the overall pattern and changing their behavior based on whether they like the pattern or not. So the most wonderful thing, I think, about this whole debate about power laws and software that could change it is the fact that we're having the conversation. I hope it continues here. Thanks a lot.

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I want to take you back basically to my hometown,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
and to a picture of my hometown of the week

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
that "Emergence" came out.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
And it's a picture we've seen several times.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
Basically, "Emergence" was published on 9/11.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:34.958
I live right there in the West Village,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:39.958
so the plume was luckily blowing west, away from us.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:46.958
We had a two-and-a-half-day-old baby in the house that was ours --

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
we hadn't taken it from somebody else.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
(Laughter)

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:57.958
And one of the thoughts that I had dealing with these two separate emergences

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:01.958
of a book and a baby, and having this event happen so close --

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:05.958
that my first thought, when I was still kind of in the apartment looking out at it all

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
or walking out on the street and looking out on it just in front of our building,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:13.958
was that I'd made a terrible miscalculation in the book that I'd just written.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:17.958
Because so much of that book was a celebration of the power

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
and creative potential of density, of largely urban density,

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
of connecting people and putting them together in one place,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
and putting them on sidewalks together and having them share ideas

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
and share physical space together.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
And it seemed to me looking at that -- that tower burning and then falling,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
those towers burning and falling -- that in fact, one of the lessons

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
here was that density kills.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
And that of all the technologies that were exploited

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:43.958
to make that carnage come into being,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:50.958
probably the single group of technologies that cost the most lives

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:54.958
were those that enable 50,000 people to live in two buildings

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
110 stories above the ground.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
If they hadn't been crowded --

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
you compare the loss of life at the Pentagon to the Twin Towers,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
and you can see that very powerfully.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
And so I started to think, well, you know, density, density --

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
I'm not sure if, you know, this was the right call.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
And I kind of ruminated on that for a couple of days.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:17.958
And then about two days later, the wind started to change a little bit,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
and you could sense that the air was not healthy.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:24.958
And so even though there were no cars still in the West Village

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
where we lived, my wife sent me out to buy a, you know,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:31.958
a large air filter at the Bed Bath and Beyond,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
which was located about 20 blocks away, north.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
And so I went out.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
And obviously I'm physically a very strong person, as you can tell -- (Laughter) --

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
so I wasn't worried about carrying this thing 20 blocks.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
And I walked out, and this really miraculous thing happened to me

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
as I was walking north to buy this air filter,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.958
which was that the streets were completely alive with people.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
There was an incredible -- it was, you know, a beautiful day,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
as it was for about a week after,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
and the West Village had never seemed more lively.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
I walked up along Hudson Street --

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
where Jane Jacobs had lived and written her great book

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
that so influenced what I was writing in "Emergence" --

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
past the White Horse Tavern,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
that great old bar where Dylan Thomas drank himself to death,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
and the Bleecker Street playground was filled with kids.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And all the people who lived in the neighborhood,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
who owned restaurants and bars in the neighborhood,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
were all out there -- had them all open.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
People were out.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
There were no cars, so it seemed even better, in some ways.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And it was a beautiful urban day,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
and the incredible thing about it was that the city was working.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
The city was there.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
All the things that make a great city successful

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
and all the things that make a great city stimulating --

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
they were all on display there on those streets.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
And I thought, well, this is the power of a city.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
I mean, the power of the city --

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
we talked about cities as being centralized in space,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
but what makes them so strong most of the time

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
is they're decentralized in function.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
They don't have a center executive branch that you can take out

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and cause the whole thing to fail.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
If they did, it probably was right there at Ground Zero.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
I mean, you know, the emergency bunker was right there,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
was destroyed by the attacks,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
and obviously the damage done to the building and the lives.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:11.958
But nonetheless, just 20 blocks north, two days later,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
the city had never looked more alive.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
If you'd gone into the minds of the people,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
well, you would have seen a lot of trauma,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
and you would have seen a lot of heartache,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
and you would have seen a lot of things that would take a long time to recover.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
But the system itself of this city was thriving.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
So I took heart in seeing that.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:35.958
So I wanted to talk a little bit about the reasons why that works so well,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and how some of those reasons kind of map

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
on to where the Web is going right now.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
The question that I found myself asking to people

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
when I was talking about the book afterwards is --

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
when you've talked about emergent behavior,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
when you've talked about collective intelligence,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
the best way to get people to kind of wrap their heads around that

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
is to ask, who builds a neighborhood?

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Who decides that Soho should have this personality

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
and that the Latin Quarter should have this personality?

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Well, there are some kind of executive decisions,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
but mostly the answer is -- everybody and nobody.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
Everybody contributes a little bit.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
No single person is really the ultimate actor

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
behind the personality of a neighborhood.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
Same thing to the question of, who was keeping the streets alive

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
post-9/11 in my neighborhood?

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Well, it was the whole city.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
The whole system kind of working on it,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
and everybody contributing a small little part.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
And this is increasingly what we're starting to see on the Web

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
in a bunch of interesting ways --

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
most of which weren't around, actually,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
except in very experimental things,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
when I was writing "Emergence" and when the book came out.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
So it's been a very optimistic time, I think,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and I want to just talk about a few of those things.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
I think that there is effectively a new kind of model of interactivity

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
that's starting to emerge online right now.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
And the old one looked like this.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
This is not the future King of England, although it looks like it.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
It's some guy, it's a GeoCities homepage of some guy that I found online

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
who's interested, if you look at the bottom, in soccer and Jesus

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
and Garth Brooks and Clint Beckham and "my hometown" -- those are his links.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
But nothing really says

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
this model of interactivity -- which was so exciting and captures the real,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
the Web Zeitgeist of 1995 -- than

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
"Click here for a picture of my dog."

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
That is -- you know, there's no sentence

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
that kind of conjures up that period better than that, I think,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
which is that you suddenly have the power to put up a picture of your dog

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
and link to it, and somebody reading the page

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
has the power to click on that link or not click on that link.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
And, you know, I don't want to belittle that. That, in a sense --

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
to reference what Jeff was talking about yesterday --

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
that was, in a sense, the kind of interface electricity that

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
powered a lot of the explosion of interest in the Web:

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
that you could put up a link, and somebody could click on it,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
and it could take you anywhere you wanted to go.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
But it's still a very one-to-one kind of relationship.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
There's one person putting up the link, and there's another person

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
on the other end trying to decide whether to click on it or not.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
The new model is much more like this,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
and we've already seen a couple of references to this.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:58.958
This is what happens when you search "Steven Johnson" on Google.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:02.958
About two months ago, I had the great breakthrough --

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
one of my great, kind of shining achievements --

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
which is that my website finally became a top result for "Steven Johnson."

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:14.958
There's some theoretical physicist at MIT named Steven Johnson

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
who has dropped two spots, I'm happy to say.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:18.958
(Laughter)

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And, you know, I mean, I'll look at a couple of things like this,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:26.958
but Google is obviously the greatest technology ever invented for navel gazing.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
It's just that there are so many other people in your navel when you gaze.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
Because effectively, what's happening here,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
what's creating this page, obviously -- and we all know this,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
but it's worth just thinking about it --

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
is not some person deciding that I am the number one answer for Steven Johnson,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
but rather somehow the entire web of people

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
putting up pages and deciding to link to my page or not link to it,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and Google just sitting there and running the numbers.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
So there's this collective decision-making that's going on.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
This page is effectively, collectively authored by the Web,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and Google is just helping us

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
kind of to put the authorship in one kind of coherent place.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Now, they're more innovative -- well, Google's pretty innovative --

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
but there are some new twists on this.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
There's this incredibly interesting new site -- Technorati --

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
that's filled with lots of little widgets that are expanding on these.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And these are looking in the blog world and the world of weblogs.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
He's analyzed basically all the weblogs out there that he's tracking.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And he's tracking how many other weblogs linked to those weblogs,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
and so you have kind of an authority --

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
a weblog that has a lot of links to it

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
is more authoritative than a weblog that has few links to it.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
And so at any given time, on any given page on the Web, actually,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
you can say, what does the weblog community think about this page?

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
And you can get a list.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
This is what they think about my site; it's ranked by blog authority.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
You can also rank it by the latest posts.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
So when I was talking in "Emergence,"

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
I talked about the limitations of the one-way linking architecture

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
that, basically, you could link to somebody else

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
but they wouldn't necessarily know that you were pointing to them.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
And that was one of the reasons why the web

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
wasn't quite as emergent as it could be

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
because you needed two-way linking, you needed that kind of feedback mechanism

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
to be able to really do interesting things.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Well, something like Technorati is supplying that.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Now what's interesting here is that this is a quote from Dave Weinberger,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
where he talks about everything being purposive in the Web --

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
there's nothing artificial.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
He has this line where he says, you know, you're going to put up a link there,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
if you see a link, somebody decided to put it there.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
And he says, the link to one site didn't just grow on the other page "like a tree fungus."

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And in fact, I think that's not entirely true anymore.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
I could put up a feed of all those links generated by Technorati

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
on the right-hand side of my page,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
and they would change as the overall ecology of the Web changes.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
That little list there would change.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
I wouldn't really be directly in control of it.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
So it's much closer, in a way, to a data fungus, in a sense,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
wrapped around that page, than it is to a deliberate link that I've placed there.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Now, what you're having here is basically a global brain

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
that you're able to do lots of kind of experiments on to see what it's thinking.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
And there are all these interesting tools.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Google does the Google Zeitgeist,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:08.958
which looks at search requests to test what's going on, what people are interested in,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
and they publish it with lots of fun graphs.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And I'm saying a lot of nice things about Google,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:13.958
so I'll be I'll be saying one little critical thing.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
There's a problem with the Google Zeitgeist,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
which is it often comes back with news that a lot of people are searching

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
for Britney Spears pictures, which is not necessarily news.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
The Columbia blows up, suddenly there are a lot of searches on Columbia.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
Well, you know, we should expect to see that.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
That's not necessarily something we didn't know already.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
So the key thing in terms of these new tools

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
that are kind of plumbing the depths of the global brain,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
that are sending kind of trace dyes through that whole bloodstream --

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
the question is, are you finding out something new?

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
And one of the things that I experimented with is this thing called Google Share

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
which is basically, you take an abstract term,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and you search Google for that term,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and then you search the results that you get back for somebody's name.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
So basically, the number of pages that mention this term,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
that also mention this page, the percentage of those pages

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
is that person's Google Share of that term.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
So you can do kind of interesting contests.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
Like for instance, this is a Google Share of the TED Conference.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
So Richard Saul Wurman

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:17.958
has about a 15 percent Google Share of the TED conference.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Our good friend Chris has about a six percent -- but with a bullet, I might add.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
(Laughter)

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
But the interesting thing is, you can broaden the search a little bit.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
And it turns out, actually, that 42 percent is the Mola mola fish.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
I had no idea.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:33.958
No, that's not true.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
(Laughter)

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
I made that up because I just wanted to put up a slide

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
of the Mola mola fish.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
(Laughter)

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
I also did -- and I don't want to start a little fight in the next panel --

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
but I did a Google Share analysis of evolution and natural selection.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:53.958
So right here -- now this is a big category, you have smaller percentages,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:58.958
so this is 0.7 percent -- Dan Dennett, who'll be speaking shortly.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Right below him, 0.5 percent, Steven Pinker.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
So Dennett's in the lead a little bit there.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
But what's interesting is you can then broaden the search

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and actually see interesting things and get a sense of what else is out there.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
So Gary Bauer is not too far behind --

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:19.958
has slightly different theories about evolution and natural selection.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And right behind him is L. Ron Hubbard. So --

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
(Laughter)

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
you can see we're in the ascot, which is always good.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
And by the way, Chris, that would've been a really good panel,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:29.958
I think, right there.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:34.958
(Laughter)

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
Hubbard apparently started to reach, but besides that,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
I think it would be good next year.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
Another quick thing -- this is a slightly different thing,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
but this analysis some of you may have seen.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
It just came out. This is bursty words,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
looking at the historical record of State of the Union Addresses.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
So these are words that suddenly start to appear out of nowhere,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
so they're kind of, you know, memes that start taking off,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
that didn't have a lot of historical precedent before.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
So the first one is -- these are the bursty words around 1860s --

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
slaves, emancipation, slavery, rebellion, Kansas.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
That's Britney Spears. I mean, you know, OK, interesting.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
They're talking about slavery in 1860.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
1935 -- relief, depression, recovery banks.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
And OK, I didn't learn anything new there as well -- that's pretty obvious.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
1985, right at the center of the Reagan years --

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
that's, we're, there's, we've, it's.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
(Laughter)

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Now, there's one way to interpret this, which is to say that

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
"emancipation" and "depression" and "recovery" all have a lot of syllables.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
So you know, you can actually download -- it's hard to remember those.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
But seriously, actually, what you can see there,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
in a way that would be very hard to detect otherwise,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
is Reagan reinventing the political language of the country

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
and shifting to a much more intimate, much more folksy, much more telegenic --

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
contracting all those verbs.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
You know, 20 years before it was still, "Ask not what you can do,"

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:54.958
but with Reagan, it's, "that's where, there's Nancy and I," that kind of language.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And so something we kind of knew,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
but you didn't actually notice syntactically what he was doing.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
I'll go very quickly.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
The question now -- and this is the really interesting question --

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
is, what kind of higher-level shape is emerging right now

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
in the overall Web ecosystem -- and particularly in the ecosystem of the blogs

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
because they are really kind of at the cutting edge.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And I think what happens there will also happen in the wider system.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Now there was a very interesting article by Clay Shirky

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
that got a lot of attention about a month ago,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
and this is basically the distribution of links

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
on the web to all these various different blogs.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:33.958
It follows a power law, so that there are a few extremely well-linked to, popular blogs,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and a long tail of blogs with very few links.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
So 20 percent of the blogs get 80 percent of the links.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
Now this is a very interesting thing.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
It's caused a lot of controversy

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
because people thought that this was the ultimate kind of one man,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
one modem democracy, where anybody can get out there and get their voice heard.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
And so the question is, "Why is this happening?"

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
It's not being imposed by fiat from above.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
It's an emergent property of the blogosphere right now.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
Now, what's great about it is that people are working on --

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
within seconds of Clay publishing this piece, people started working on changing

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
the underlying rules of the system so that a different shape would start appearing.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
And basically, the shape appears

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
largely because of a kind of a first-mover advantage.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
if you're the first site there, everybody links to you.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
If you're the second site there, most people link to you.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
And so very quickly you can accumulate a bunch of links,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and it makes it more likely for newcomers to link to you in the future,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and then you get this kind of shape.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
And so what Dave Sifry at Technorati started working on,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
literally as Shirky started -- after he published his piece --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:35.958
was something that basically just gave a new kind of priority to newcomers.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
And he started looking at interesting newcomers that don't have a lot of links,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:42.958
that suddenly get a bunch of links in the last 24 hours.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
So in a sense, bursty weblogs coming from new voices.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:50.958
So he's working on a tool right there that can actually change the overall system.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
And it creates a kind of planned emergence.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
You're not totally in control,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
but you're changing the underlying rules in interesting ways

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
because you have an end result which is

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
maybe a more democratic spread of voices.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
So the most amazing thing about this -- and I'll end on this note --

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
is, most emergent systems, most self-organizing systems

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:10.958
are not made up of component parts that are capable of looking at the overall pattern

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
and changing their behavior based on whether they like the pattern or not.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
So the most wonderful thing, I think, about this whole debate

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
about power laws and software that could change it

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
is the fact that we're having the conversation.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
I hope it continues here.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:24.958
Thanks a lot.
