title: An 8-dimensional model of the universe
transcript: Whoa, dude.(Laughter)Check out those killer equations. Sweet. Actually, for the next 18 minutes I'm going to do the best I can to describe the beauty of particle physics without equations. It turns out there's a lot we can learn from coral. A coral is a very beautiful and unusual animal. Each coral head consists of thousands of individual polyps. These polyps are continually budding and branching into genetically identical neighbors. If we imagine this to be a hyperintelligent coral, we can single out an individual and ask him a reasonable question. We can ask how exactly he got to be in this particular location compared to his neighbors — if it was just chance, or destiny, or what?Now, after admonishing us for turning the temperature up too high, he would tell us that our question was completely stupid. These corals can be kind of mean, you see, and I have surfing scars to prove that. But this polyp would continue and tell us that his neighbors were quite clearly identical copies of him. That he was in all these other locations as well, but experiencing them as separate individuals. For a coral, branching into different copies is the most natural thing in the world.Unlike us, a hyperintelligent coral would be uniquely prepared to understand quantum mechanics. The mathematics of quantum mechanics very accurately describes how our universe works. And it tells us our reality is continually branching into different possibilities, just like a coral. It's a weird thing for us humans to wrap our minds around, since we only ever get to experience one possibility. This quantum weirdness was first described by Erwin Schrödinger and his cat. The cat likes this version better.(Laughter)In this setup, Schrödinger is in a box with a radioactive sample that, by the laws of quantum mechanics, branches into a state in which it is radiated and a state in which it is not.(Laughter)In the branch in which the sample radiates, it sets off a trigger that releases poison and Schrödinger is dead. But in the other branch of reality, he remains alive. These realities are experienced separately by each individual. As far as either can tell, the other one doesn't exist.This seems weird to us, because each of us only experiences an individual existence, and we don't get to see other branches. It's as if each of us, like Schrödinger here, are a kind of coral branching into different possibilities. The mathematics of quantum mechanics tells us this is how the world works at tiny scales. It can be summed up in a single sentence: Everything that can happen, does. That's quantum mechanics. But this does not mean everything happens. The rest of physics is about describing what can happen and what can't. What physics tells us is that everything comes down to geometry and the interactions of elementary particles. And things can happen only if these interactions are perfectly balanced.Now I'll go ahead and describe how we know about these particles, what they are and how this balance works. In this machine, a beam of protons and antiprotons are accelerated to near the speed of light and brought together in a collision, producing a burst of pure energy. This energy is immediately converted into a spray of subatomic particles, with detectors and computers used to figure out their properties. This enormous machine — the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Geneva — has a circumference of 17 miles and, when it's operating, draws five times as much power as the city of Monterey. We can't predict specifically what particles will be produced in any individual collision. Quantum mechanics tells us all possibilities are realized. But physics does tell us what particles can be produced. These particles must have just as much mass and energy as is carried in by the proton and antiproton. Any particles more massive than this energy limit aren't produced, and remain invisible to us. This is why this new particle accelerator is so exciting. It's going to push this energy limit seven times beyond what's ever been done before, so we're going to get to see some new particles very soon.But before talking about what we might see, let me describe the particles we already know of. There's a whole zoo of subatomic particles. Most of us are familiar with electrons. A lot of people in this room make a good living pushing them around.(Laughter)But the electron also has a neutral partner called the neutrino, with no electric charge and a very tiny mass. In contrast, the up and down quarks have very large masses, and combine in threes to make the protons and neutrons inside atoms. All of these matter particles come in left- and right-handed varieties, and have antiparticle partners that carry opposite charges. These familiar particles also have less familiar second and third generations, which have the same charges as the first but have much higher masses. These matter particles all interact with the various force particles. The electromagnetic force interacts with electrically charged matter via particles called photons. There is also a very weak force called, rather unimaginatively, the weak force ...(Laughter)that interacts only with left-handed matter. The strong force acts between quarks which carry a different kind of charge, called color charge, and come in three different varieties: red, green and blue. You can blame Murray Gell-Mann for these names — they're his fault. Finally, there's the force of gravity, which interacts with matter via its mass and spin.The most important thing to understand here is that there's a different kind of charge associated with each of these forces. These four different forces interact with matter according to the corresponding charges that each particle has. A particle that hasn't been seen yet, but we're pretty sure exists, is the Higgs particle, which gives masses to all these other particles. The main purpose of the Large Hadron Collider is to see this Higgs particle, and we're almost certain it will. But the greatest mystery is what else we might see. And I'm going to show you one beautiful possibility towards the end of this talk.Now, if we count up all these different particles using their various spins and charges, there are 226. That's a lot of particles to keep track of. And it seems strange that nature would have so many elementary particles. But if we plot them out according to their charges, some beautiful patterns emerge. The most familiar charge is electric charge. Electrons have an electric charge, a negative one, and quarks have electric charges in thirds. So when two up quarks and a down quark are combined to make a proton, it has a total electric charge of plus one. These particles also have antiparticles, which have opposite charges. Now, it turns out the electric charge is actually a combination of two other charges: hypercharge and weak charge. If we spread out the hypercharge and weak charge and plot the charges of particles in this two-dimensional charge space, the electric charge is where these particles sit along the vertical direction. The electromagnetic and weak forces interact with matter according to their hypercharge and weak charge, which make this pattern. This is called the unified electroweak model, and it was put together back in 1967.The reason most of us are only familiar with electric charge and not both of these is because of the Higgs particle. The Higgs, over here on the left, has a large mass and breaks the symmetry of this electroweak pattern. It makes the weak force very weak by giving the weak particles a large mass. Since this massive Higgs sits along the horizontal direction in this diagram, the photons of electromagnetism remain massless and interact with electric charge along the vertical direction in this charge space. So the electromagnetic and weak forces are described by this pattern of particle charges in two-dimensional space. We can include the strong force by spreading out its two charge directions and plotting the charges of the force particles in quarks along these directions. The charges of all known particles can be plotted in a four-dimensional charge space, and projected down to two dimensions like this so we can see them.Whenever particles interact, nature keeps things in a perfect balance along all four of these charge directions. If a particle and an antiparticle collide, it creates a burst of energy and a total charge of zero in all four charge directions. At this point, anything can be created as long as it has the same energy and maintains a total charge of zero. For example, this weak force particle and its antiparticle can be created in a collision. In further interactions, the charges must always balance. One of the weak particles could decay into an electron and an antineutrino, and these three still add to zero total charge. Nature always keeps a perfect balance. So these patterns of charges are not just pretty. They tell us what interactions are allowed to happen. And we can rotate this charge space in four dimensions to get a better look at the strong interaction, which has this nice hexagonal symmetry. In a strong interaction, a strong force particle, such as this one, interacts with a colored quark, such as this green one, to give a quark with a different color charge — this red one. And strong interactions are happening millions of times each second in every atom of our bodies, holding the atomic nuclei together.But these four charges corresponding to three forces are not the end of the story. We can also include two more charges corresponding to the gravitational force. When we include these, each matter particle has two different spin charges, spin-up and spin-down. So they all split and give a nice pattern in six-dimensional charge space. We can rotate this pattern in six dimensions and see that it's quite pretty. Right now, this pattern matches our best current knowledge of how nature is built at the tiny scales of these elementary particles. This is what we know for certain. Some of these particles are at the very limit of what we've been able to reach with experiments. From this pattern we already know the particle physics of these tiny scales — the way the universe works at these tiny scales is very beautiful.But now I'm going to discuss some new and old ideas about things we don't know yet. We want to expand this pattern using mathematics alone, and see if we can get our hands on the whole enchilada. We want to find all the particles and forces that make a complete picture of our universe. And we want to use this picture to predict new particles that we'll see when experiments reach higher energies.So there's an old idea in particle physics that this known pattern of charges, which is not very symmetric, could emerge from a more perfect pattern that gets broken — similar to how the Higgs particle breaks the electroweak pattern to give electromagnetism. In order to do this, we need to introduce new forces with new charge directions. When we introduce a new direction, we get to guess what charges the particles have along this direction, and then we can rotate it in with the others. If we guess wisely, we can construct the standard charges in six charge dimensions as a broken symmetry of this more perfect pattern in seven charge dimensions.This particular choice corresponds to a grand unified theory introduced by Pati and Salam in 1973. When we look at this new unified pattern, we can see a couple of gaps where particles seem to be missing. This is the way theories of unification work. A physicist looks for larger, more symmetric patterns that include the established pattern as a subset. The larger pattern allows us to predict the existence of particles that have never been seen. This unification model predicts the existence of these two new force particles, which should act a lot like the weak force, only weaker.Now, we can rotate this set of charges in seven dimensions and consider an odd fact about the matter particles: the second and third generations of matter have exactly the same charges in six-dimensional charge space as the first generation. These particles are not uniquely identified by their six charges. They sit on top of one another in the standard charge space. However, if we work in eight-dimensional charge space, then we can assign unique new charges to each particle. Then we can spin these in eight dimensions and see what the whole pattern looks like. Here we can see the second and third generations of matter now, related to the first generation by a symmetry called "triality."This particular pattern of charges in eight dimensions is actually part of the most beautiful geometric structure in mathematics. It's a pattern of the largest exceptional Lie group, E8. This Lie group is a smooth, curved shape with 248 dimensions. Each point in this pattern corresponds to a symmetry of this very complex and beautiful shape. One small part of this E8 shape can be used to describe the curved space-time of Einstein's general relativity, explaining gravity. Together with quantum mechanics, the geometry of this shape could describe everything about how the universe works at the tiniest scales. The pattern of this shape living in eight-dimensional charge space is exquisitely beautiful, and it summarizes thousands of possible interactions between these elementary particles, each of which is just a facet of this complicated shape.As we spin it, we can see many of the other intricate patterns contained in this one. And with a particular rotation, we can look down through this pattern in eight dimensions along a symmetry axis and see all the particles at once. It's a very beautiful object, and as with any unification, we can see some holes where new particles are required by this pattern. There are 20 gaps where new particles should be, two of which have been filled by the Pati-Salam particles. From their location in this pattern, we know that these new particles should be scalar fields like the Higgs particle, but have color charge and interact with the strong force. Filling in these new particles completes this pattern, giving us the full E8.This E8 pattern has very deep mathematical roots. It's considered by many to be the most beautiful structure in mathematics. It's a fantastic prospect that this object of great mathematical beauty could describe the truth of particle interactions at the smallest scales imaginable. And this idea that nature is described by mathematics is not at all new. In 1623, Galileo wrote this: "Nature's grand book, which stands continually open to our gaze, is written in the language of mathematics. Its characters are triangles, circles and other geometrical figures, without which it is humanly impossible to understand a single word of it; without these, one is wandering around in a dark labyrinth."I believe this to be true, and I've tried to follow Galileo's guidance in describing the mathematics of particle physics using only triangles, circles and other geometrical figures. Of course, when other physicists and I actually work on this stuff, the mathematics can resemble a dark labyrinth. But it's reassuring that at the heart of this mathematics is pure, beautiful geometry. Joined with quantum mechanics, this mathematics describes our universe as a growing E8 coral, with particles interacting at every location in all possible ways according to a beautiful pattern. And as more of the pattern comes into view using new machines like the Large Hadron Collider, we may be able to see whether nature uses this E8 pattern or a different one.This process of discovery is a wonderful adventure to be involved in. If the LHC finds particles that fit this E8 pattern, that will be very, very cool. If the LHC finds new particles, but they don't fit this pattern — well, that will be very interesting, but bad for this E8 theory. And, of course, bad for me personally.(Laughter)Now, how bad would that be? Well, pretty bad.(Laughter)But predicting how nature works is a very risky game. This theory and others like it are long shots. One does a lot of hard work knowing that most of these ideas probably won't end up being true about nature. That's what doing theoretical physics is like: there are a lot of wipeouts. In this regard, new physics theories are a lot like start-up companies. As with any large investment, it can be emotionally difficult to abandon a line of research when it isn't working out. But in science, if something isn't working, you have to toss it out and try something else.Now, the only way to maintain sanity and achieve happiness in the midst of this uncertainty is to keep balance and perspective in life. I've tried the best I can to live a balanced life.(Laughter)I try to balance my life equally between physics, love and surfing — my own three charge directions.(Laughter)This way, even if the physics I work on comes to nothing, I still know I've lived a good life. And I try to live in beautiful places. For most of the past ten years I've lived on the island of Maui, a very beautiful place. Now, it's one of the greatest mysteries in the universe to my parents how I managed to survive all that time without engaging in anything resembling full-time employment.(Laughter)I'm going to let you in on that secret. This was a view from my home office on Maui. And this is another, and another. And you may have noticed that these beautiful views are similar, but in slightly different places. That's because this used to be my home and office on Maui.(Laughter)I've chosen a very unusual life. But not worrying about rent allowed me to spend my time doing what I love. Living a nomadic existence has been hard at times, but it's allowed me to live in beautiful places and keep a balance in my life that I've been happy with. It allows me to spend a lot of my time hanging out with hyperintelligent coral. But I also greatly enjoy the company of hyperintelligent people. So I'm very happy to have been invited here to TED.Thank you very much.(Applause)Chris Anderson: Stay here one second.(Applause)I probably understood two percent of that, but I still absolutely loved it. So I'm going to sound dumb. Your theory of everything —Garrett Lisi: I'm used to coral.CA: That's right. The reason it's got a few people at least excited is because, if you're right, it brings gravity and quantum theory together. So are you saying that we should think of the universe, at its heart — that the smallest things that there are, are somehow an E8 object of possibility? I mean, is there a scale to it, at the smallest scale, or ...?GL: Well, right now the pattern I showed you that corresponds to what we know about elementary particle physics — that already corresponds to a very beautiful shape. And that's the one that I said we knew for certain. And that shape has remarkable similarities — and the way it fits into this E8 pattern, which could be the rest of the picture. And these patterns of points that I've shown for you actually represent symmetries of this high-dimensional object that would be warping and moving and dancing over the space-time that we experience. And that would be what explains all these elementary particles that we see.CA: But a string theorist, as I understand it, explains electrons in terms of much smaller strings vibrating — I know, you don't like string theory — vibrating inside it. How should we think of an electron in relation to E8?GL: Well, it would be one of the symmetries of this E8 shape. So what's happening is, as the shape is moving over space-time, it's twisting. And the direction it's twisting as it moves is what particle we see. So it would be —CA: The size of the E8 shape, how does that relate to the electron? I feel like I need that for my picture. Is it bigger? Is it smaller?GL: As far as we know, electrons are point particles, so this would be going down to the smallest possible scales. So the way these things are explained in quantum field theory is, all possibilities are expanding and developing at once. And this is why I use the analogy to coral. And — in this way, the way that E8 comes in is it will be as a shape that's attached at each point in the space-time. And, as I said, the way the shape twists — the directional along which way the shape is twisting as it moves over this curved surface — is what the elementary particles are, themselves. So through quantum field theory, they manifest themselves as points and interact that way. I don't know if I'll be able to make this any clearer.(Laughter)CA: It doesn't really matter. It's evoking a kind of sense of wonder, and I certainly want to understand more of this.But thank you so much for coming. That was absolutely fascinating.(Applause)

WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:14.598 --> 00:00:17.214
Whoa, dude.

00:00:17.238 --> 00:00:18.454
(Laughter)

00:00:18.478 --> 00:00:21.318
Check out those killer equations. Sweet.

00:00:24.198 --> 00:00:27.614
Actually, for the next 18 minutes
I'm going to do the best I can

00:00:27.638 --> 00:00:30.638
to describe the beauty
of particle physics without equations.

00:00:31.598 --> 00:00:34.278
It turns out there's a lot
we can learn from coral.

00:00:35.078 --> 00:00:37.774
A coral is a very beautiful
and unusual animal.

00:00:37.798 --> 00:00:41.334
Each coral head consists
of thousands of individual polyps.

00:00:41.358 --> 00:00:43.894
These polyps are continually
budding and branching

00:00:43.918 --> 00:00:45.798
into genetically identical neighbors.

00:00:46.758 --> 00:00:49.814
If we imagine this
to be a hyperintelligent coral,

00:00:49.838 --> 00:00:53.014
we can single out an individual
and ask him a reasonable question.

00:00:53.038 --> 00:00:56.414
We can ask how exactly
he got to be in this particular location

00:00:56.438 --> 00:00:58.134
compared to his neighbors --

00:00:58.158 --> 00:01:00.718
if it was just chance,
or destiny, or what?

00:01:01.678 --> 00:01:05.118
Now, after admonishing us
for turning the temperature up too high,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.774
he would tell us that our question
was completely stupid.

00:01:08.798 --> 00:01:10.798
These corals can be kind of mean, you see,

00:01:10.822 --> 00:01:12.680
and I have surfing scars to prove that.

00:01:13.461 --> 00:01:15.414
But this polyp would continue and tell us

00:01:15.438 --> 00:01:18.494
that his neighbors were
quite clearly identical copies of him.

00:01:18.518 --> 00:01:20.854
That he was in all
these other locations as well,

00:01:20.878 --> 00:01:23.038
but experiencing them
as separate individuals.

00:01:24.238 --> 00:01:26.574
For a coral, branching
into different copies

00:01:26.598 --> 00:01:28.456
is the most natural thing in the world.

00:01:29.278 --> 00:01:31.654
Unlike us, a hyperintelligent coral

00:01:31.678 --> 00:01:34.478
would be uniquely prepared
to understand quantum mechanics.

00:01:35.798 --> 00:01:37.534
The mathematics of quantum mechanics

00:01:37.558 --> 00:01:40.094
very accurately describes
how our universe works.

00:01:40.118 --> 00:01:43.976
And it tells us our reality is continually
branching into different possibilities,

00:01:44.000 --> 00:01:45.200
just like a coral.

00:01:46.438 --> 00:01:49.174
It's a weird thing for us humans
to wrap our minds around,

00:01:49.198 --> 00:01:52.054
since we only ever get
to experience one possibility.

00:01:52.078 --> 00:01:54.078
This quantum weirdness was first described

00:01:54.102 --> 00:01:55.854
by Erwin Schrödinger and his cat.

00:01:55.878 --> 00:01:57.574
The cat likes this version better.

00:01:57.598 --> 00:01:59.958
(Laughter)

00:02:01.398 --> 00:02:05.054
In this setup, Schrödinger is in a box
with a radioactive sample

00:02:05.078 --> 00:02:07.974
that, by the laws of quantum mechanics,
branches into a state

00:02:07.998 --> 00:02:10.838
in which it is radiated
and a state in which it is not.

00:02:11.518 --> 00:02:15.574
(Laughter)

00:02:15.598 --> 00:02:17.614
In the branch in which
the sample radiates,

00:02:17.638 --> 00:02:21.014
it sets off a trigger that releases poison
and Schrödinger is dead.

00:02:21.038 --> 00:02:23.934
But in the other branch of reality,
he remains alive.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.863
These realities are experienced
separately by each individual.

00:02:26.887 --> 00:02:29.814
As far as either can tell,
the other one doesn't exist.

00:02:29.838 --> 00:02:31.054
This seems weird to us,

00:02:31.078 --> 00:02:33.934
because each of us
only experiences an individual existence,

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.054
and we don't get to see other branches.

00:02:36.078 --> 00:02:38.374
It's as if each of us,
like Schrödinger here,

00:02:38.398 --> 00:02:41.558
are a kind of coral
branching into different possibilities.

00:02:42.838 --> 00:02:44.974
The mathematics
of quantum mechanics tells us

00:02:44.998 --> 00:02:47.294
this is how the world
works at tiny scales.

00:02:47.318 --> 00:02:49.278
It can be summed up in a single sentence:

00:02:50.278 --> 00:02:52.294
Everything that can happen, does.

00:02:52.318 --> 00:02:53.774
That's quantum mechanics.

00:02:53.798 --> 00:02:56.534
But this does not mean everything happens.

00:02:56.558 --> 00:02:59.958
The rest of physics is about describing
what can happen and what can't.

00:03:00.918 --> 00:03:04.054
What physics tells us
is that everything comes down to geometry

00:03:04.078 --> 00:03:06.198
and the interactions
of elementary particles.

00:03:06.798 --> 00:03:10.278
And things can happen only if
these interactions are perfectly balanced.

00:03:12.558 --> 00:03:15.614
Now I'll go ahead and describe
how we know about these particles,

00:03:15.638 --> 00:03:17.678
what they are and how this balance works.

00:03:19.078 --> 00:03:22.014
In this machine,
a beam of protons and antiprotons

00:03:22.038 --> 00:03:24.054
are accelerated to near the speed of light

00:03:24.078 --> 00:03:27.734
and brought together in a collision,
producing a burst of pure energy.

00:03:27.758 --> 00:03:31.654
This energy is immediately converted
into a spray of subatomic particles,

00:03:31.678 --> 00:03:34.974
with detectors and computers
used to figure out their properties.

00:03:34.998 --> 00:03:36.254
This enormous machine --

00:03:36.278 --> 00:03:38.454
the Large Hadron Collider
at CERN in Geneva --

00:03:38.478 --> 00:03:41.174
has a circumference of 17 miles
and, when it's operating,

00:03:41.198 --> 00:03:43.798
draws five times as much power
as the city of Monterey.

00:03:44.798 --> 00:03:46.654
We can't predict specifically

00:03:46.678 --> 00:03:49.614
what particles will be produced
in any individual collision.

00:03:49.638 --> 00:03:52.358
Quantum mechanics tells us
all possibilities are realized.

00:03:53.038 --> 00:03:55.678
But physics does tell us
what particles can be produced.

00:03:56.478 --> 00:03:59.014
These particles must have
just as much mass and energy

00:03:59.038 --> 00:04:01.398
as is carried in
by the proton and antiproton.

00:04:02.518 --> 00:04:05.774
Any particles more massive
than this energy limit aren't produced,

00:04:05.798 --> 00:04:07.198
and remain invisible to us.

00:04:08.798 --> 00:04:11.854
This is why this new
particle accelerator is so exciting.

00:04:11.878 --> 00:04:14.134
It's going to push
this energy limit seven times

00:04:14.158 --> 00:04:15.894
beyond what's ever been done before,

00:04:15.918 --> 00:04:18.638
so we're going to get to see
some new particles very soon.

00:04:19.318 --> 00:04:21.454
But before talking
about what we might see,

00:04:21.478 --> 00:04:23.798
let me describe the particles
we already know of.

00:04:24.358 --> 00:04:26.518
There's a whole zoo
of subatomic particles.

00:04:27.158 --> 00:04:29.054
Most of us are familiar with electrons.

00:04:29.078 --> 00:04:32.294
A lot of people in this room
make a good living pushing them around.

00:04:32.318 --> 00:04:33.494
(Laughter)

00:04:33.518 --> 00:04:36.534
But the electron also has
a neutral partner called the neutrino,

00:04:36.558 --> 00:04:38.678
with no electric charge
and a very tiny mass.

00:04:39.358 --> 00:04:42.814
In contrast, the up and down quarks
have very large masses,

00:04:42.838 --> 00:04:46.038
and combine in threes to make
the protons and neutrons inside atoms.

00:04:46.718 --> 00:04:50.054
All of these matter particles
come in left- and right-handed varieties,

00:04:50.078 --> 00:04:52.840
and have antiparticle partners
that carry opposite charges.

00:04:54.318 --> 00:04:55.574
These familiar particles

00:04:55.598 --> 00:04:58.614
also have less familiar
second and third generations,

00:04:58.638 --> 00:05:02.158
which have the same charges as the first
but have much higher masses.

00:05:03.638 --> 00:05:07.174
These matter particles all interact
with the various force particles.

00:05:07.198 --> 00:05:10.414
The electromagnetic force
interacts with electrically charged matter

00:05:10.438 --> 00:05:12.254
via particles called photons.

00:05:12.278 --> 00:05:13.814
There is also a very weak force

00:05:13.838 --> 00:05:16.571
called, rather unimaginatively,
the weak force ...

00:05:16.595 --> 00:05:17.734
(Laughter)

00:05:17.758 --> 00:05:20.166
that interacts
only with left-handed matter.

00:05:20.398 --> 00:05:22.414
The strong force acts between quarks

00:05:22.438 --> 00:05:25.574
which carry a different kind of charge,
called color charge,

00:05:25.598 --> 00:05:28.374
and come in three different varieties:
red, green and blue.

00:05:28.398 --> 00:05:31.598
You can blame Murray Gell-Mann
for these names -- they're his fault.

00:05:32.118 --> 00:05:34.214
Finally, there's the force of gravity,

00:05:34.238 --> 00:05:37.334
which interacts with matter
via its mass and spin.

00:05:37.358 --> 00:05:39.574
The most important thing
to understand here

00:05:39.598 --> 00:05:43.398
is that there's a different kind of charge
associated with each of these forces.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.214
These four different forces
interact with matter

00:05:46.238 --> 00:05:49.143
according to the corresponding charges
that each particle has.

00:05:50.598 --> 00:05:53.774
A particle that hasn't been seen yet,
but we're pretty sure exists,

00:05:53.798 --> 00:05:57.494
is the Higgs particle, which gives masses
to all these other particles.

00:05:57.518 --> 00:05:59.654
The main purpose
of the Large Hadron Collider

00:05:59.678 --> 00:06:02.718
is to see this Higgs particle,
and we're almost certain it will.

00:06:03.078 --> 00:06:05.958
But the greatest mystery
is what else we might see.

00:06:07.118 --> 00:06:09.534
And I'm going to show you
one beautiful possibility

00:06:09.558 --> 00:06:10.939
towards the end of this talk.

00:06:12.158 --> 00:06:14.494
Now, if we count up
all these different particles

00:06:14.518 --> 00:06:16.374
using their various spins and charges,

00:06:16.398 --> 00:06:17.718
there are 226.

00:06:18.358 --> 00:06:20.398
That's a lot of particles
to keep track of.

00:06:20.838 --> 00:06:22.054
And it seems strange

00:06:22.078 --> 00:06:24.638
that nature would have
so many elementary particles.

00:06:25.638 --> 00:06:28.294
But if we plot them out
according to their charges,

00:06:28.318 --> 00:06:29.958
some beautiful patterns emerge.

00:06:32.078 --> 00:06:34.358
The most familiar charge
is electric charge.

00:06:34.798 --> 00:06:36.454
Electrons have an electric charge,

00:06:36.478 --> 00:06:37.694
a negative one,

00:06:37.718 --> 00:06:39.734
and quarks have
electric charges in thirds.

00:06:39.758 --> 00:06:43.014
So when two up quarks and a down quark
are combined to make a proton,

00:06:43.038 --> 00:06:45.054
it has a total
electric charge of plus one.

00:06:45.078 --> 00:06:48.334
These particles also have antiparticles,
which have opposite charges.

00:06:48.358 --> 00:06:50.174
Now, it turns out the electric charge

00:06:50.198 --> 00:06:52.694
is actually a combination
of two other charges:

00:06:52.718 --> 00:06:54.318
hypercharge and weak charge.

00:06:55.398 --> 00:06:57.718
If we spread out
the hypercharge and weak charge

00:06:58.720 --> 00:07:02.054
and plot the charges of particles
in this two-dimensional charge space,

00:07:02.078 --> 00:07:04.334
the electric charge
is where these particles sit

00:07:04.358 --> 00:07:05.758
along the vertical direction.

00:07:06.398 --> 00:07:09.054
The electromagnetic
and weak forces interact with matter

00:07:09.078 --> 00:07:11.294
according to their hypercharge
and weak charge,

00:07:11.318 --> 00:07:12.574
which make this pattern.

00:07:12.598 --> 00:07:14.734
This is called
the unified electroweak model,

00:07:14.758 --> 00:07:16.958
and it was put together back in 1967.

00:07:17.678 --> 00:07:20.534
The reason most of us
are only familiar with electric charge

00:07:20.558 --> 00:07:23.158
and not both of these
is because of the Higgs particle.

00:07:24.358 --> 00:07:27.094
The Higgs, over here on the left,
has a large mass

00:07:27.118 --> 00:07:29.574
and breaks the symmetry
of this electroweak pattern.

00:07:29.598 --> 00:07:33.174
It makes the weak force very weak
by giving the weak particles a large mass.

00:07:33.198 --> 00:07:37.294
Since this massive Higgs sits along
the horizontal direction in this diagram,

00:07:37.318 --> 00:07:39.614
the photons of electromagnetism
remain massless

00:07:39.638 --> 00:07:42.574
and interact with electric charge
along the vertical direction

00:07:42.598 --> 00:07:43.838
in this charge space.

00:07:45.918 --> 00:07:47.774
So the electromagnetic and weak forces

00:07:47.798 --> 00:07:50.134
are described by this pattern
of particle charges

00:07:50.158 --> 00:07:51.534
in two-dimensional space.

00:07:51.558 --> 00:07:55.078
We can include the strong force
by spreading out its two charge directions

00:07:56.558 --> 00:07:59.254
and plotting the charges
of the force particles in quarks

00:07:59.278 --> 00:08:00.518
along these directions.

00:08:01.198 --> 00:08:02.854
The charges of all known particles

00:08:02.878 --> 00:08:05.254
can be plotted in
a four-dimensional charge space,

00:08:05.278 --> 00:08:08.454
and projected down to two dimensions
like this so we can see them.

00:08:08.478 --> 00:08:12.254
Whenever particles interact,
nature keeps things in a perfect balance

00:08:12.278 --> 00:08:14.438
along all four of these charge directions.

00:08:15.078 --> 00:08:17.134
If a particle and an antiparticle collide,

00:08:17.158 --> 00:08:19.814
it creates a burst of energy
and a total charge of zero

00:08:19.838 --> 00:08:21.278
in all four charge directions.

00:08:21.878 --> 00:08:23.894
At this point, anything can be created

00:08:23.918 --> 00:08:27.278
as long as it has the same energy
and maintains a total charge of zero.

00:08:28.118 --> 00:08:31.334
For example, this weak force particle
and its antiparticle

00:08:31.358 --> 00:08:33.134
can be created in a collision.

00:08:33.158 --> 00:08:36.054
In further interactions,
the charges must always balance.

00:08:36.078 --> 00:08:40.398
One of the weak particles could decay
into an electron and an antineutrino,

00:08:41.118 --> 00:08:43.774
and these three
still add to zero total charge.

00:08:43.798 --> 00:08:45.877
Nature always keeps a perfect balance.

00:08:46.757 --> 00:08:49.694
So these patterns of charges
are not just pretty.

00:08:49.718 --> 00:08:52.214
They tell us what interactions
are allowed to happen.

00:08:52.238 --> 00:08:54.853
And we can rotate this charge space
in four dimensions

00:08:54.877 --> 00:08:57.654
to get a better look
at the strong interaction,

00:08:57.678 --> 00:08:59.934
which has this nice hexagonal symmetry.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.294
In a strong interaction,
a strong force particle,

00:09:03.318 --> 00:09:04.534
such as this one,

00:09:04.558 --> 00:09:07.318
interacts with a colored quark,
such as this green one,

00:09:08.118 --> 00:09:11.023
to give a quark with a different
color charge -- this red one.

00:09:12.118 --> 00:09:14.734
And strong interactions
are happening millions of times

00:09:14.758 --> 00:09:16.894
each second in every atom of our bodies,

00:09:16.918 --> 00:09:18.598
holding the atomic nuclei together.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.814
But these four charges
corresponding to three forces

00:09:23.838 --> 00:09:25.238
are not the end of the story.

00:09:25.878 --> 00:09:29.814
We can also include two more charges
corresponding to the gravitational force.

00:09:29.838 --> 00:09:31.134
When we include these,

00:09:31.158 --> 00:09:33.814
each matter particle
has two different spin charges,

00:09:33.838 --> 00:09:35.814
spin-up and spin-down.

00:09:35.838 --> 00:09:39.894
So they all split and give a nice pattern
in six-dimensional charge space.

00:09:39.918 --> 00:09:42.894
We can rotate this pattern
in six dimensions

00:09:42.918 --> 00:09:44.438
and see that it's quite pretty.

00:09:47.158 --> 00:09:50.694
Right now, this pattern
matches our best current knowledge

00:09:50.718 --> 00:09:54.118
of how nature is built at the tiny scales
of these elementary particles.

00:09:54.998 --> 00:09:56.614
This is what we know for certain.

00:09:56.638 --> 00:09:58.774
Some of these particles
are at the very limit

00:09:58.798 --> 00:10:01.174
of what we've been able to reach
with experiments.

00:10:01.198 --> 00:10:02.414
From this pattern

00:10:02.438 --> 00:10:05.774
we already know the particle physics
of these tiny scales --

00:10:05.798 --> 00:10:09.678
the way the universe works
at these tiny scales is very beautiful.

00:10:11.078 --> 00:10:13.494
But now I'm going to discuss
some new and old ideas

00:10:13.518 --> 00:10:15.038
about things we don't know yet.

00:10:15.638 --> 00:10:18.774
We want to expand this pattern
using mathematics alone,

00:10:18.798 --> 00:10:21.414
and see if we can get our hands
on the whole enchilada.

00:10:21.438 --> 00:10:23.534
We want to find
all the particles and forces

00:10:23.558 --> 00:10:25.694
that make a complete picture
of our universe.

00:10:25.718 --> 00:10:28.374
And we want to use this picture
to predict new particles

00:10:28.398 --> 00:10:30.922
that we'll see when experiments
reach higher energies.

00:10:32.878 --> 00:10:35.134
So there's an old idea in particle physics

00:10:35.158 --> 00:10:37.894
that this known pattern of charges,

00:10:37.918 --> 00:10:39.494
which is not very symmetric,

00:10:39.518 --> 00:10:42.374
could emerge from a more perfect pattern
that gets broken --

00:10:42.398 --> 00:10:45.414
similar to how the Higgs particle
breaks the electroweak pattern

00:10:45.438 --> 00:10:47.094
to give electromagnetism.

00:10:47.118 --> 00:10:50.174
In order to do this,
we need to introduce new forces

00:10:50.198 --> 00:10:51.518
with new charge directions.

00:10:53.438 --> 00:10:55.134
When we introduce a new direction,

00:10:55.158 --> 00:10:58.574
we get to guess what charges
the particles have along this direction,

00:10:58.598 --> 00:11:00.718
and then we can rotate it
in with the others.

00:11:01.678 --> 00:11:05.174
If we guess wisely,
we can construct the standard charges

00:11:05.198 --> 00:11:07.894
in six charge dimensions
as a broken symmetry

00:11:07.918 --> 00:11:11.318
of this more perfect pattern
in seven charge dimensions.

00:11:11.998 --> 00:11:14.974
This particular choice
corresponds to a grand unified theory

00:11:14.998 --> 00:11:17.678
introduced by Pati and Salam in 1973.

00:11:18.398 --> 00:11:21.134
When we look at this new unified pattern,

00:11:21.158 --> 00:11:24.118
we can see a couple of gaps
where particles seem to be missing.

00:11:25.038 --> 00:11:27.158
This is the way
theories of unification work.

00:11:27.918 --> 00:11:30.454
A physicist looks for larger,
more symmetric patterns

00:11:30.478 --> 00:11:32.798
that include the established
pattern as a subset.

00:11:33.638 --> 00:11:36.774
The larger pattern allows us
to predict the existence of particles

00:11:36.798 --> 00:11:38.038
that have never been seen.

00:11:39.198 --> 00:11:41.454
This unification model
predicts the existence

00:11:41.478 --> 00:11:43.974
of these two new force particles,

00:11:43.998 --> 00:11:46.638
which should act a lot
like the weak force, only weaker.

00:11:48.118 --> 00:11:50.854
Now, we can rotate this set
of charges in seven dimensions

00:11:50.878 --> 00:11:53.438
and consider an odd fact
about the matter particles:

00:11:54.558 --> 00:11:56.614
the second and third generations of matter

00:11:56.638 --> 00:11:59.534
have exactly the same charges
in six-dimensional charge space

00:11:59.558 --> 00:12:00.798
as the first generation.

00:12:01.438 --> 00:12:04.518
These particles are not
uniquely identified by their six charges.

00:12:05.278 --> 00:12:08.118
They sit on top of one another
in the standard charge space.

00:12:09.358 --> 00:12:12.974
However, if we work
in eight-dimensional charge space,

00:12:12.998 --> 00:12:16.598
then we can assign
unique new charges to each particle.

00:12:17.318 --> 00:12:19.718
Then we can spin these in eight dimensions

00:12:20.398 --> 00:12:22.398
and see what the whole pattern looks like.

00:12:23.941 --> 00:12:26.894
Here we can see the second
and third generations of matter now,

00:12:26.918 --> 00:12:30.038
related to the first generation
by a symmetry called "triality."

00:12:31.478 --> 00:12:34.974
This particular pattern
of charges in eight dimensions

00:12:34.998 --> 00:12:38.518
is actually part of the most beautiful
geometric structure in mathematics.

00:12:39.718 --> 00:12:42.798
It's a pattern of the largest
exceptional Lie group, E8.

00:12:43.678 --> 00:12:47.694
This Lie group is a smooth,
curved shape with 248 dimensions.

00:12:47.718 --> 00:12:50.694
Each point in this pattern
corresponds to a symmetry

00:12:50.718 --> 00:12:52.758
of this very complex and beautiful shape.

00:12:53.718 --> 00:12:56.494
One small part of this E8 shape
can be used to describe

00:12:56.518 --> 00:12:59.134
the curved space-time
of Einstein's general relativity,

00:12:59.158 --> 00:13:00.398
explaining gravity.

00:13:01.158 --> 00:13:02.854
Together with quantum mechanics,

00:13:02.878 --> 00:13:05.334
the geometry of this shape
could describe everything

00:13:05.358 --> 00:13:07.974
about how the universe works
at the tiniest scales.

00:13:07.998 --> 00:13:12.294
The pattern of this shape living
in eight-dimensional charge space

00:13:12.318 --> 00:13:13.598
is exquisitely beautiful,

00:13:14.998 --> 00:13:17.454
and it summarizes thousands
of possible interactions

00:13:17.478 --> 00:13:19.174
between these elementary particles,

00:13:19.198 --> 00:13:21.838
each of which is just a facet
of this complicated shape.

00:13:23.438 --> 00:13:26.374
As we spin it, we can see
many of the other intricate patterns

00:13:26.398 --> 00:13:27.638
contained in this one.

00:13:29.438 --> 00:13:31.214
And with a particular rotation,

00:13:31.238 --> 00:13:35.414
we can look down through this pattern
in eight dimensions along a symmetry axis

00:13:35.438 --> 00:13:37.254
and see all the particles at once.

00:13:37.278 --> 00:13:38.854
It's a very beautiful object,

00:13:38.878 --> 00:13:41.254
and as with any unification,

00:13:41.278 --> 00:13:44.638
we can see some holes where new particles
are required by this pattern.

00:13:45.798 --> 00:13:48.534
There are 20 gaps
where new particles should be,

00:13:48.558 --> 00:13:51.294
two of which have been filled
by the Pati-Salam particles.

00:13:51.318 --> 00:13:54.574
From their location in this pattern,
we know that these new particles

00:13:54.598 --> 00:13:56.934
should be scalar fields
like the Higgs particle,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.638
but have color charge
and interact with the strong force.

00:14:00.198 --> 00:14:02.734
Filling in these new particles
completes this pattern,

00:14:02.758 --> 00:14:04.094
giving us the full E8.

00:14:04.118 --> 00:14:07.134
This E8 pattern has
very deep mathematical roots.

00:14:07.158 --> 00:14:10.638
It's considered by many to be the most
beautiful structure in mathematics.

00:14:11.238 --> 00:14:15.374
It's a fantastic prospect that this object
of great mathematical beauty

00:14:15.398 --> 00:14:17.734
could describe the truth
of particle interactions

00:14:17.758 --> 00:14:19.398
at the smallest scales imaginable.

00:14:21.678 --> 00:14:25.614
And this idea that nature is described
by mathematics is not at all new.

00:14:25.638 --> 00:14:28.358
In 1623, Galileo wrote this:

00:14:29.318 --> 00:14:33.014
"Nature's grand book,
which stands continually open to our gaze,

00:14:33.038 --> 00:14:35.534
is written in the language of mathematics.

00:14:35.558 --> 00:14:39.174
Its characters are triangles,
circles and other geometrical figures,

00:14:39.198 --> 00:14:43.054
without which it is humanly impossible
to understand a single word of it;

00:14:43.078 --> 00:14:46.358
without these, one is wandering around
in a dark labyrinth."

00:14:47.518 --> 00:14:48.758
I believe this to be true,

00:14:49.398 --> 00:14:51.414
and I've tried
to follow Galileo's guidance

00:14:51.438 --> 00:14:53.774
in describing the mathematics
of particle physics

00:14:53.798 --> 00:14:57.174
using only triangles, circles
and other geometrical figures.

00:14:57.198 --> 00:15:00.934
Of course, when other physicists
and I actually work on this stuff,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.158
the mathematics
can resemble a dark labyrinth.

00:15:04.878 --> 00:15:07.734
But it's reassuring that at the heart
of this mathematics

00:15:07.758 --> 00:15:09.678
is pure, beautiful geometry.

00:15:11.398 --> 00:15:12.854
Joined with quantum mechanics,

00:15:12.878 --> 00:15:16.814
this mathematics describes our universe
as a growing E8 coral,

00:15:16.838 --> 00:15:20.454
with particles interacting
at every location in all possible ways

00:15:20.478 --> 00:15:22.078
according to a beautiful pattern.

00:15:23.518 --> 00:15:26.414
And as more of the pattern
comes into view using new machines

00:15:26.438 --> 00:15:28.254
like the Large Hadron Collider,

00:15:28.278 --> 00:15:33.118
we may be able to see whether nature
uses this E8 pattern or a different one.

00:15:33.718 --> 00:15:36.958
This process of discovery is
a wonderful adventure to be involved in.

00:15:37.638 --> 00:15:40.934
If the LHC finds particles
that fit this E8 pattern,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.558
that will be very, very cool.

00:15:43.918 --> 00:15:47.054
If the LHC finds new particles,
but they don't fit this pattern --

00:15:47.078 --> 00:15:51.574
well, that will be very interesting,
but bad for this E8 theory.

00:15:51.598 --> 00:15:54.094
And, of course, bad for me personally.

00:15:54.118 --> 00:15:56.294
(Laughter)

00:15:56.318 --> 00:15:58.094
Now, how bad would that be?

00:15:58.118 --> 00:16:00.214
Well, pretty bad.

00:16:00.238 --> 00:16:02.478
(Laughter)

00:16:03.358 --> 00:16:06.158
But predicting how nature works
is a very risky game.

00:16:07.158 --> 00:16:10.118
This theory and others like it
are long shots.

00:16:11.038 --> 00:16:13.894
One does a lot of hard work
knowing that most of these ideas

00:16:13.918 --> 00:16:16.094
probably won't end up
being true about nature.

00:16:16.118 --> 00:16:18.294
That's what doing
theoretical physics is like:

00:16:18.318 --> 00:16:19.734
there are a lot of wipeouts.

00:16:19.758 --> 00:16:23.118
In this regard, new physics theories
are a lot like start-up companies.

00:16:25.318 --> 00:16:26.734
As with any large investment,

00:16:26.758 --> 00:16:29.654
it can be emotionally difficult
to abandon a line of research

00:16:29.678 --> 00:16:30.974
when it isn't working out.

00:16:30.998 --> 00:16:33.054
But in science,
if something isn't working,

00:16:33.078 --> 00:16:35.278
you have to toss it out
and try something else.

00:16:36.118 --> 00:16:37.854
Now, the only way to maintain sanity

00:16:37.878 --> 00:16:40.494
and achieve happiness
in the midst of this uncertainty

00:16:40.518 --> 00:16:42.558
is to keep balance
and perspective in life.

00:16:44.398 --> 00:16:46.934
I've tried the best I can
to live a balanced life.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.838
(Laughter)

00:16:49.518 --> 00:16:53.094
I try to balance my life equally
between physics, love and surfing --

00:16:53.118 --> 00:16:54.934
my own three charge directions.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.094
(Laughter)

00:16:57.118 --> 00:16:59.814
This way, even if the physics
I work on comes to nothing,

00:16:59.838 --> 00:17:01.558
I still know I've lived a good life.

00:17:02.198 --> 00:17:04.094
And I try to live in beautiful places.

00:17:04.118 --> 00:17:07.174
For most of the past ten years
I've lived on the island of Maui,

00:17:07.198 --> 00:17:08.438
a very beautiful place.

00:17:08.798 --> 00:17:12.494
Now, it's one of the greatest mysteries
in the universe to my parents

00:17:12.518 --> 00:17:14.374
how I managed to survive all that time

00:17:14.398 --> 00:17:17.293
without engaging in anything
resembling full-time employment.

00:17:17.317 --> 00:17:19.277
(Laughter)

00:17:20.918 --> 00:17:22.797
I'm going to let you in on that secret.

00:17:24.317 --> 00:17:26.478
This was a view
from my home office on Maui.

00:17:28.518 --> 00:17:29.718
And this is another,

00:17:31.678 --> 00:17:33.094
and another.

00:17:33.118 --> 00:17:36.134
And you may have noticed
that these beautiful views are similar,

00:17:36.158 --> 00:17:37.758
but in slightly different places.

00:17:38.598 --> 00:17:42.014
That's because this used to be
my home and office on Maui.

00:17:42.038 --> 00:17:43.814
(Laughter)

00:17:43.838 --> 00:17:45.478
I've chosen a very unusual life.

00:17:46.678 --> 00:17:48.014
But not worrying about rent

00:17:48.038 --> 00:17:50.198
allowed me to spend my time
doing what I love.

00:17:50.918 --> 00:17:53.454
Living a nomadic existence
has been hard at times,

00:17:53.478 --> 00:17:55.694
but it's allowed me
to live in beautiful places

00:17:55.718 --> 00:17:58.694
and keep a balance in my life
that I've been happy with.

00:17:58.718 --> 00:18:03.078
It allows me to spend a lot of my time
hanging out with hyperintelligent coral.

00:18:04.838 --> 00:18:07.974
But I also greatly enjoy
the company of hyperintelligent people.

00:18:07.998 --> 00:18:10.379
So I'm very happy
to have been invited here to TED.

00:18:11.278 --> 00:18:12.494
Thank you very much.

00:18:12.518 --> 00:18:19.134
(Applause)

00:18:19.158 --> 00:18:20.944
Chris Anderson: Stay here one second.

00:18:20.968 --> 00:18:24.550
(Applause)

00:18:24.574 --> 00:18:26.574
I probably understood two percent of that,

00:18:26.598 --> 00:18:28.198
but I still absolutely loved it.

00:18:30.198 --> 00:18:31.814
So I'm going to sound dumb.

00:18:31.838 --> 00:18:34.174
Your theory of everything --

00:18:34.198 --> 00:18:35.774
Garrett Lisi: I'm used to coral.

00:18:35.798 --> 00:18:37.054
CA: That's right.

00:18:37.078 --> 00:18:39.414
The reason it's got
a few people at least excited

00:18:39.438 --> 00:18:43.814
is because, if you're right, it brings
gravity and quantum theory together.

00:18:43.838 --> 00:18:47.654
So are you saying that we should
think of the universe, at its heart --

00:18:47.678 --> 00:18:50.374
that the smallest things that there are,

00:18:50.398 --> 00:18:56.574
are somehow an E8 object of possibility?

00:18:56.598 --> 00:18:59.614
I mean, is there a scale to it,
at the smallest scale, or ...?

00:18:59.638 --> 00:19:02.494
GL: Well, right now
the pattern I showed you

00:19:02.518 --> 00:19:07.134
that corresponds to what we know
about elementary particle physics --

00:19:07.158 --> 00:19:09.574
that already corresponds
to a very beautiful shape.

00:19:09.598 --> 00:19:12.014
And that's the one
that I said we knew for certain.

00:19:12.038 --> 00:19:15.134
And that shape
has remarkable similarities --

00:19:15.158 --> 00:19:18.998
and the way it fits into this E8 pattern,
which could be the rest of the picture.

00:19:20.078 --> 00:19:23.534
And these patterns of points
that I've shown for you

00:19:23.558 --> 00:19:27.374
actually represent symmetries
of this high-dimensional object

00:19:27.398 --> 00:19:30.174
that would be warping
and moving and dancing

00:19:30.198 --> 00:19:32.294
over the space-time that we experience.

00:19:32.318 --> 00:19:35.974
And that would be what explains all these
elementary particles that we see.

00:19:35.998 --> 00:19:39.374
CA: But a string theorist,
as I understand it,

00:19:39.398 --> 00:19:42.414
explains electrons in terms
of much smaller strings vibrating --

00:19:42.438 --> 00:19:45.734
I know, you don't like string theory --
vibrating inside it.

00:19:45.758 --> 00:19:50.574
How should we think
of an electron in relation to E8?

00:19:50.598 --> 00:19:53.998
GL: Well, it would be one
of the symmetries of this E8 shape.

00:19:54.758 --> 00:20:00.134
So what's happening is, as the shape
is moving over space-time, it's twisting.

00:20:00.158 --> 00:20:04.614
And the direction it's twisting
as it moves is what particle we see.

00:20:04.638 --> 00:20:05.854
So it would be --

00:20:05.878 --> 00:20:09.054
CA: The size of the E8 shape,
how does that relate to the electron?

00:20:09.078 --> 00:20:12.294
I feel like I need that for my picture.
Is it bigger? Is it smaller?

00:20:12.318 --> 00:20:14.795
GL: As far as we know,
electrons are point particles,

00:20:14.819 --> 00:20:17.654
so this would be going down
to the smallest possible scales.

00:20:17.678 --> 00:20:21.494
So the way these things are explained
in quantum field theory is,

00:20:21.518 --> 00:20:24.174
all possibilities are expanding
and developing at once.

00:20:24.198 --> 00:20:26.238
And this is why
I use the analogy to coral.

00:20:27.158 --> 00:20:28.358
And --

00:20:29.558 --> 00:20:33.854
in this way, the way that E8 comes in

00:20:33.878 --> 00:20:38.318
is it will be as a shape that's attached
at each point in the space-time.

00:20:39.238 --> 00:20:42.694
And, as I said,
the way the shape twists --

00:20:42.718 --> 00:20:45.214
the directional along which way
the shape is twisting

00:20:45.238 --> 00:20:47.294
as it moves over this curved surface --

00:20:47.318 --> 00:20:50.094
is what the elementary particles
are, themselves.

00:20:50.118 --> 00:20:52.774
So through quantum field theory,

00:20:52.798 --> 00:20:56.014
they manifest themselves as points
and interact that way.

00:20:56.038 --> 00:20:58.574
I don't know if I'll be able
to make this any clearer.

00:20:58.598 --> 00:21:01.534
(Laughter)

00:21:01.558 --> 00:21:02.974
CA: It doesn't really matter.

00:21:02.998 --> 00:21:05.014
It's evoking a kind of sense of wonder,

00:21:05.038 --> 00:21:09.814
and I certainly
want to understand more of this.

00:21:09.838 --> 00:21:12.974
But thank you so much for coming.
That was absolutely fascinating.

00:21:12.998 --> 00:21:14.838
(Applause)

title: Design and the Elastic Mind
transcript: I dabble in design. I'm a curator of architecture and design; I happen to be at the Museum of Modern Art. But what we're going to talk about today is really design. Really good designers are like sponges: they really are curious and absorb every kind of information that comes their way, and transform it so that it can be used by people like us. And so that gives me an opportunity, because every design show that I curate kind of looks at a different world. And it's great, because it seems like every time I change jobs.And what I'm going to do today is I'm going to give you a preview of the next exhibition that I'm working on, which is called "Design and the Elastic Mind." The world that I decided to focus on this particular time is the world of science and the world of technology. Technology always comes into play when design is involved, but science does a little less. But designers are great at taking big revolutions that happen and transforming them so that we can use them. And this is what this exhibition looks at.If you think about your life today, you go every day through many different scales, many different changes of rhythm and pace. You work over different time zones, you talk to very different people, you multitask. We all know it, and we do it kind of automatically. Some of the minds in this audience are super elastic, others are a little slower, others have a few stretch marks, but nonetheless this is a quite exceptional audience from that viewpoint. Other people are not as elastic. I can't get my father in Italy to work on the Internet. He doesn't want to put high-speed Internet at home. And that's because there's some little bit of fear, little bit of resistance or just clogged mechanisms. So designers work on this particular malaise that we have, these kinds of discomforts that we have, and try to make life easier for us. Elasticity of mind is something that we really need, you know, we really need, we really cherish and we really work on. And this exhibition is about the work of designers that help us be more elastic, and also of designers that really work on this elasticity as an opportunity. And one last thing is that it's not only designers, but it's also scientists.And before I launch into the display of some of the slides and into the preview, I would like to point out this beautiful detail about scientists and design. You can say that the relationship between science and design goes back centuries. You can of course talk about Leonardo da Vinci and many other Renaissance men and women — and there's a gigantic history behind it. But according to a really great science historian you might know, Peter Galison — he teaches at Harvard — what nanotechnology in particular and quantum physics have brought to designers is this renewed interest, this real passion for design.So basically, the idea of being able to build things bottom up, atom by atom, has made them all into tinkerers. And all of a sudden scientists are seeking designers, just like designers are seeking scientists. It's a brand-new love affair that we're trying to cultivate at MOMA. Together with Adam Bly, who is the founder of Seed magazine — that's now a multimedia company, you might know it — we founded about a year ago a monthly salon for designers and scientists, and it's quite beautiful. And Keith has come, and also Jonathan has come and many others. And it was great, because at the beginning was this apology fest — you know, scientists would tell designers, you know, I don't know what style is, I'm not really elegant. And designers would like, oh, I don't know how to do an equation, I don't understand what you're saying. And then all of a sudden they really started talking each others' language, and now we're already at the point that they collaborate.Paul Steinhardt, a physicist from New York, and Aranda/Lasch, architects, collaborated in an installation in London at the Serpentine. And it's really interesting to see how this happens. The exhibition will talk about the work of both designers and scientists, and show how they're presenting the possibilities of the future to us. I'm showing to you different sections of the show right now, just to give you a taste of it. Nanophysics and nanotechnology, for instance, have really opened the designer's mind. In this case I'm showing more the designers' work, because they're the ones that have really been stimulated. A lot of the objects in the show are concepts, not objects that exist already. But what you're looking at here is the work of some scientists from UCLA. This kind of alphabet soup is a new way to mark proteins — not only by color but literally by alphabet letters. So they construct it, and they can construct all kinds of formsat the nanoscale. This is the work of design students from the Royal College of Arts in London that have been working together with their tutor, Tony Dunne, and with a bunch of scientists around Great Britain on the possibilities of nanotechnology for design in the future. New sensing elements on the body — you can grow hairs on your nails, and therefore grab some of the particles from another person. They seem very, very obsessed with finding out more about the ideal mate. So they're working on enhancing everything: touch, smell — everything they can, in order to find the perfect mate.Very interesting. This is a typeface designer from Israel who has designed — he calls them "typosperma." He's thinking — of course it's all a concept — of injecting typefaces into spermatozoa, I don't know how to say it in English — spermatazoi — in order to make them become — to almost have a song or a whole poem written with every ejaculation. (Laughter) I tell you, designers are quite fantastic, you know.So, tissue design. In this case too, you have a mixture of scientists and designers. This here is part of the same lab at the Royal College of Arts. The RCA is really quite an amazing school from that viewpoint. One of the assignments for a year was to work with in-vitro meat. You know that already you can grow meat in vitro. In Australia they did it — this research company, called SymbioticA. But the problem is that it's a really ugly patty. And so, the assignment to the students was, how should the steak of tomorrow be? When you don't have to kill cows and it can have any shape, what should it be like? So this particular student, James King, went around the beautiful English countryside, picked the best, best cow that he could see, and then put her in the MRI machine. Then, he took the scans of the best organs and made the meat — of course, this is done with a Japanese resins food maker, but you know, in the future it could be made better — which reproduces the best MRI scan of the best cow he could find.Instead, this element here is much more banal. Something that you know can be done already is to grow bone tissue, so that you can make a wedding ring out of the bone tissue of your loved one — literally. So, this is indeed made of human bone tissue.This is SymbioticA, and they've been working — they were the first ones to do this in-vitro meat — and now they've also done an in-vitro coat, a leather coat. It's miniscule, but it's a real coat. It's shaped like one. So, we'll be able to really not have any excuse to be wearing everything leather in the future.One of the most important topics of the show — you know, as anything in our life today, we can look at it from many, many different viewpoints, and at different levels. One of the most interesting and most important concepts is the idea of scale. We change scale very often: we change resolution of screens, and we're not really fazed by it, we do it very comfortably. So you go, even in the exhibition, from the idea of nanotechnology and the nanoscale to the manipulation of really great amounts of data — the mapping and tagging of the universe and of the world. In this particular case a section will be devoted to information design. You see here the work of Ben Fry. This is "Human vs. Chimps" — the few chromosomes that distinguish us from chimps. It was a beautiful visualization that he did for Seed magazine. And here's the whole code of Pac-Man, visualized with all the go-to, go-back-to, also made into a beautiful choreography.And then also graphs by scientists, this beautiful diagraph of protein homology. Scientists are starting to also consider aesthetics. We were discussing with Keith Shrubb* this morning the fact that many scientists tend not to use anything beautiful in their presentations, otherwise they're afraid of being considered dumb blondes. So they pick the worst background from any kind of PowerPoint presentation, the worst typeface. It's only recently that this kind of marriage between design and science is producing some of the first "pretty" — if we can say so — scientific presentations. Another aspect of contemporary design that I think is mind-opening, promising and will really be the future of design, is the idea of collective design. You know, the whole XO laptop, from One Laptop per Child, is based on the idea of collaboration and mash and networking. So, the more the merrier. The more computers, the stronger the signal, and children work on the interface so that it's all based on doing things together, tasks together. So the idea of collective design is something that will become even bigger in the future, and this is chosen as an example.Related to the idea of collective design and to the new balance between the individual and the collectiveness, collectivity is the idea of existence maximum. That's a term that I coined a few years ago while I was thinking of how pressed we are together, and at the same time how these small objects, like the Walkman first and then the iPod, create bubbles of space around us that enable us to have a metaphysical space that is much bigger than our physical space. You can be in the subway and you can be completely isolated and have your own room in your iPod.And this is the work of several designers that really enhance the idea of solitude and expansion by means of various techniques. This is a spa telephone. The idea is that it's become so difficult to have a private conversation anywhere that you go to the spa, you have a massage, you have a facial, maybe a rub, and then you have this beautiful pool with this perfect temperature, and you can have this isolation tank phone conversation with whomever you've been wanting to talk with for a long time. And same thing here, Social Tele-presence. It's actually already used by the military a little bit, but it's the idea of being able to be somewhere else with your senses while you're removed from it physically. And this is called Blind Date. It's a [unclear], so if you're too shy to be really at the date, you can stay at a distance with your flowers and somebody else reenacts the date for you.Rapid manufacturing is another big area in which technology and design are, I think, bound to change the world. You've heard about it before many times. Rapid manufacturing is a computer file sent directly from the computer to the manufacturing machine. It used to be called rapid prototyping, rapid modeling. It started out in the '80s, but at the beginning it was machines carving out of a foam block a model that was very, very fragile, and could not have any real use. Slowly but surely, the materials became better — better resins. Techniques became better — not only carving but also stereolithography and laser — solidifying all kinds of resins, whether in powder or in liquid form. And the vats became bigger, to the point that now we can have actual chairs made by rapid manufacturing. It takes seven days today to manufacture a chair, but you know what? One day it will take seven hours. And then the dream is that you'll be able to, from home, customize your chair. You know, companies and designers will be designing the matrix or the margins that respect both solidity and brand, and design identity. And then you can send it to the Kinko's store at the cornerand go get your chair. Now, the implications of this are enormous, not only regarding the participation of the final buyer in the design process, but also no tracking, no warehousing, no wasted materials. Also, I can imagine many design manufacturers will have to retool their own business plans and maybe invest in this Kinko's store. But it really is a big change. And here I'm showing a picture that was in Wired Magazine — you know, the Artifacts of the Future section that I love so much — that shows you can have your desktop 3D printer and print your own basketball. But here instead are examples, you can already 3D-print textiles, which is very interesting. This is just a really nice touch — it's called slow prototyping. It's a designer that put 10,000 bees at work and they built this vase. They had a particular shape that they had to stay in.Mapping and tagging. As the capacity of computers becomes really, really big, and the capacity of our mind not that much bigger, we find that we need to tag as much as we can what we do in order to then retrace our path. Also, we do it in order to share with other people. Again, this communal sense of experience that seems to be so important today. So, various ways to map and tag are also the work of many designers nowadays. Also, the senses — designers and scientists all work on trying to expand our senses capabilities so that we can achieve more. And also animal senses in a way.This particular object that many people love so much is actually based on kind of a scientific experiment — the fact that bees have a very strong olfactory sense, and so — much like dogs that can smell certain kinds of skin cancer — bees can be trained by Pavlovian reflex to detect one type of cancer, and also pregnancy. And so this student at the RCA designed this beautiful blown-glass object where the bees move from one chamber to the other if they detect that particular smell that signifies, in this case, pregnancy. Another shape is made for cancer.Design for Debate is a very interesting new endeavor that designers have really shaped for themselves. Some designers don't design objects, products, things that we're going to actually use, but rather, they design scenarios that are object-based. They're still very useful. They help companies and other designers think better about the future. And usually they are accompanied by videos. This is quite beautiful. It's Dunne and Raby, "All the Robots." Those are a series of robots that are meant to be taken care of. We always think that robots will take care of us, and instead they designed these robots that are very, very needy. You need to take one in your arms and look at it in the eyes for about five minutes before it does something. Another one gets really, really nervous if you get in to the room, and starts shaking, so you have to calm it down. So it's really a way to make us think more about what robots mean to us. Noam Toran and "Accessories for Lonely Men": the idea is that when you lose your loved one or you go through a bad breakup, what you miss the most are those annoying things that you used to hate when you were with the other person. So he designed all these series of accessories. This one is something that takes away the sheets from you at night. Then there's another one that breathes on your neck. There's another one that throws plates and breaks them. So it's just this idea of what we really miss in life.Elio Caccavale: he took the idea of those dolls that explain leukemia. He's working on dolls that explain xenotransplantation, and also the spider gene into the goat, from a few years ago. He's working for the exhibition on a whole series of dolls that explain to children where babies come from today. Because it's not anymore Mom, Dad, the flowers and the bees, and then there's the baby. No, it can be two moms, three dads, in-vitro — there's the whole idea of how babies can be made today that has changed. So it's a series of dolls that he's working on right now.One of the most beautiful things is that designers really work on life, even though they take technology into account. And many designers have been working recently on the idea of death and mourning, and what we can do about it today with new technologies. Or how we should behave about it with new technologies. These three objects over there are hard drives with a Bluetooth connection. But they're in reality very, very beautiful sculpted artifacts that contain the whole desktop and computer memory of somebody who passed away. So instead of having only the pictures, you will be able to put this object next to the computer and all of a sudden have, you know, Gertrude's whole life and all of her files and her address book come alive.And this is even better. This is Auger-Loizeau, "AfterLife." It's the idea that some people don't believe in an afterlife. So to give them something tangible that shows that there is something after death, they take the gastric juices of people who passed away and concentrate them, and put them into a battery that can actually be used to power flashlights. They also go — you know, sex toys, whatever. It's quite amazing how these things can make you smile, can make you laugh, can make you cry sometimes. But I'm hoping that this particular exhibition will be able to trace a new portrait of where design is going — which is always, hopefully, a portrait a few years in advance of where the world is going. Thank you very much.

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I dabble in design. I'm a curator of architecture and design;

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
I happen to be at the Museum of Modern Art.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
But what we're going to talk about today

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
is really design. Really good designers are like sponges:

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
they really are curious

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
and absorb every kind of information that comes their way,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
and transform it so that it can be used by people like us.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
And so that gives me an opportunity,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
because every design show that I curate

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
kind of looks at a different world. And it's great,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
because it seems like every time I change jobs.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
And what I'm going to do today is I'm going to give you a preview

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
of the next exhibition that I'm working on, which is called

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:48.958
"Design and the Elastic Mind."

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:53.958
The world that I decided to focus on this particular time

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
is the world of science and the world of technology.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
Technology always comes into play when design is involved,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
but science does a little less.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:05.958
But designers are great at taking big revolutions that happen

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
and transforming them so that we can use them.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
And this is what this exhibition looks at.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
If you think about your life today,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
you go every day through many different scales,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
many different changes of rhythm and pace.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:23.958
You work over different time zones, you talk to very different people,

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:27.958
you multitask. We all know it, and we do it kind of automatically.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
Some of the minds in this audience are super elastic,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
others are a little slower,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
others have a few stretch marks, but nonetheless

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:39.958
this is a quite exceptional audience from that viewpoint.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
Other people are not as elastic.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
I can't get my father in Italy to work on the Internet.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
He doesn't want to put high-speed Internet at home.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
And that's because there's some little bit of fear,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
little bit of resistance or just clogged mechanisms.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:56.958
So designers work on this particular malaise that we have,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
these kinds of discomforts that we have,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
and try to make life easier for us.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
Elasticity of mind is something that we really need, you know,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
we really need, we really cherish and we really work on.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
And this exhibition is about the work of designers

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
that help us be more elastic,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:18.958
and also of designers that really work on this elasticity

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
as an opportunity. And one last thing is that

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
it's not only designers, but it's also scientists.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:28.958
And before I launch into the display of some of the slides

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
and into the preview, I would like to point out

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
this beautiful detail about scientists and design.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
You can say that the relationship between science and design

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
goes back centuries. You can of course talk about

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
Leonardo da Vinci and many other Renaissance men and women --

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
and there's a gigantic history behind it.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
But according to a really great science historian you might know,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
Peter Galison -- he teaches at Harvard --

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:56.958
what nanotechnology in particular and quantum physics

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
have brought to designers is this renewed interest,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
this real passion for design.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
So basically, the idea of being able to build things bottom up,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
atom by atom, has made them all into tinkerers.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
And all of a sudden scientists are seeking designers,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
just like designers are seeking scientists.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
It's a brand-new love affair that we're trying to cultivate

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
at MOMA. Together with Adam Bly, who is the founder of Seed magazine --

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
that's now a multimedia company, you might know it --

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
we founded about a year ago a monthly salon

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
for designers and scientists, and it's quite beautiful.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And Keith has come, and also Jonathan has come and many others.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
And it was great, because at the beginning was this apology fest --

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
you know, scientists would tell designers,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
you know, I don't know what style is, I'm not really elegant.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And designers would like, oh, I don't know how to do an equation,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
I don't understand what you're saying. And then all of a sudden

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
they really started talking each others' language,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
and now we're already at the point that they collaborate.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
Paul Steinhardt, a physicist from New York,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
and Aranda/Lasch, architects, collaborated in an installation

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:03.958
in London at the Serpentine.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And it's really interesting to see how this happens.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
The exhibition will talk about the work

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
of both designers and scientists,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.958
and show how they're presenting the possibilities of the future to us.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:18.958
I'm showing to you

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
different sections of the show right now,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:21.958
just to give you a taste of it.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
Nanophysics and nanotechnology, for instance,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
have really opened the designer's mind.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
In this case I'm showing more the designers' work,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
because they're the ones that have really been stimulated.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
A lot of the objects in the show are concepts,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
not objects that exist already. But what you're looking at here
