00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:48.958
Now,

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
I am not a scientist.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
I have never built an atomic pile.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
Although, I might argue that, technically,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
every pile is atomic.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
(Laughter)

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
However, with respect, I might point out two possibilities

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
that Enrico Fermi perhaps did not consider.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
One is that the aliens might be

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
very far away.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
Perhaps, I dare say,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
even on other planets.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
The other possibility --

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
(Laughter) --

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
is, perhaps, Enrico Fermi himself

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
was an alien.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
(Laughter)

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
Think about it.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
Isn't it a little convenient

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
that in the midst of the World War, out of nowhere,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
suddenly an Italian scientist showed up

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
with an amazing new technology

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
that would transform everything in the world

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:44.958
and darken the history of the human species forever after?

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
And isn't it a little strange

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
that he required no payment for this?

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
That he asked for only one thing --

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
a gift of two healthy sperm whales?

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
That's -- that's not true.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
But it is strange.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
(Laughter)

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
And if Enrico Fermi were indeed a space alien,

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
wouldn't he be the first to have tried to convince

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
his fellow scientists

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:13.958
that the space aliens are not already here?

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
For it is given in certain UFO-ology

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
or UFOlogy circles,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
that the aliens are already here and have been for millennia;

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
that they have walked among us in disguise,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
observing us, guiding our evolution

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
from ape to man --

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
if you believe in that sort of thing --

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and, occasionally, kidnapping us in their flying saucers

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
and taking us away to have sex with us in pyramids.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
(Laughter)

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
It's a difficult theory to discount,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
I think you'll agree.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
(Laughter)

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
For even in my own life,

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
there are memories I have

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
that are difficult to explain --

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
happenings that are so odd and unaccountably weird,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
that it is difficult to imagine

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
they were not the result

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
of prolonged and frequent contact with aliens throughout my life.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
For how else will you explain

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
the amazing and absolutely true

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
close encounters that I had

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
and will describe to you now?

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
Encounter one: Ocean City, New Jersey, 1980.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
This was the summer when the special edition of

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
"Close Encounters of the Third Kind" was released.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And I went on vacation with my parents to the Jersey shore.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Within 12 hours, I was horribly sunburned,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
just like Richard Dreyfuss in the movie.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:24.958
(Laughter)

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And so I spent the rest of the vacation

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
largely sitting outside our little rental house at night,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
the sidewalk still warm from the sun,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
watching the skies for UFOs.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
What did I see? Stars, satellites,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
blinking airplanes -- typical sky junk.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:41.958
Occasionally, kids would come and

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
join me and watch,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
but their necks soon got sore, and they would go off to the boardwalk

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
to play video games and mingle with humans.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
I was pretty good at the video games. I was not very good at the other part,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
so I stayed alone with the cosmos.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:56.958
And that's when it happened.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
An elderly couple came walking down the street.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
I would say they were in their late seventies,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
and I would say that they were on a date,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
because he was wearing a very neat little suit

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
with a yellow tie -- a brown suit.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
And she was wearing a cardigan, because it was now fully night

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
and a chill was coming in off the ocean.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
I remember, for some reason,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
that they were exactly the same height.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And then they stopped, and the man turned to me

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
and said,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
"What are you looking for,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
flying saucers?"

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
(Laughter)

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
You have to admit, that's a pretty boss piece of detective work

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
for an old man on a date.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
But what was stranger still --

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
and even I realized it at the time,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
as a nine-year-old child --

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
was that they stopped at all.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
That this old man would interrupt his moonlight stroll

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
with his sweetheart with the precise reason

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
of making fun of a child.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
"Oh," he said,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
"little green men."

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And then his girlfriend joined in, too.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
"There's no such thing as space men," she said.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
"There's no such thing."

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
And then they both laughed. "Ha, ha, ha."

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
I looked around.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
The street was entirely empty.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
I had stopped hearing the sound of the ocean.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
It was as though time had stopped.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
I did not know why they were teasing me.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
I looked into their strangely angry faces,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and I remember wondering,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
are they wearing rubber masks?

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
(Laughter)

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
And what would be behind those rubber masks, if they were?

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
Giant, almond-shaped, unblinking eyes?

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Slits for mouths?

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
The old man crooked his finger as though he were firing a gun,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
and then he made laser sounds.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
"Kew, kew, kew --

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
watch out."

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
And they turned at once and walked away.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
The old man reached out

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
his knobbly claw

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
for the woman's hand,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and found it, and left me alone.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Now, you could describe this as a simple misunderstanding --

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
a strange encounter among humans.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
Maybe it was swamp gas, but --

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
(Laughter) --

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
I know what I saw.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
Close encounter two: Brookline, Massachusetts, 1984.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
I went to see the movie "Dune,"

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
and a girl talked to me. Now, on its face --

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
(Laughter) --

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
this is impossible on its face, I realize --

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
but it is absolutely true.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
It was opening night, naturally.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I went with my friend Tim McGonigal, who sat on my left.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
On my right was the girl in question.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
She had long, curly black hair, a blue jean jacket.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
I remember, she had some sort of injury to her ankle,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
an Ace bandage, and she had crutches.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
She was very tall, I would say.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
I was starting high school at the time. I would say she was a junior,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
but I had never seen her before. She didn't go to my school.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
I didn't know her name, and I never will.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
She was sitting with someone who I presume was her mother,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
and they were talking about the novel, "Dune."

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
They were both big fans, mother and daughter --

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
very unusual.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
They were talking about how their favorite characters

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
were the giant sandworms.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
And then it got stranger.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
That's when she turned to me and said,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
"Are you looking forward to seeing the movie?"

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
(Laughter)

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:09.958
First of all, I was embarrassed

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
because I had not read the novel "Dune" at that time.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
I was merely a connoisseur of movies

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
featuring desert planets, as I still am.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
(Laughter)

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
But it was also the tone of how she asked the question:

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
apropos of nothing, like she didn't even care about the answer,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
as though she just wanted to talk to me.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
I did not know what to say. I said, "Yes."

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
I did not even turn my head.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
The movie began.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
I need not remind you that this was David Lynch's version of "Dune,"

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
in which all of the characters

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
were sexy and deformed at the same time.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
(Laughter)

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
There was a character called the Third-Stage Guild Navigator,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
which was a kind of giant, floating fetus-creature

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
that lived in a giant tank with this orange mist

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
of psychedelic spice

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
swirling around him,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
allowing him to bend space and time.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
He could never leave the tank

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
or interact with the outside world.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
He had become, in his isolation,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
so deformed and so sexy,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
that he had to talk through a kind of old-timey radio

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
to the outside world, and could never touch them.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
I mean, I liked him a lot better than the sandworms.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
The sandworms were fine, but your favorite character?

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
Please.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
When the movie ended,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
everyone seemed very happy

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
to get up and get out of the theatre as soon as possible.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
Except for the girl.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
As I walked out, her pace slowed.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
Perhaps it was the crutches,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
but it seemed --

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
(Laughter) --

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
it seemed as though she might want to talk to me again.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
When I say it out loud, it sounds so ridiculous,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
but I can only come to the conclusion

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
that it was what, in the alien abductee community,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
they call a "screen memory":

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
a ridiculous false recollection designed by their brain

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
to cover up some trauma -- say, of being kidnapped

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
and flown off to a sex pyramid.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
(Laughter)

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And so I sure am glad

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
I did not slow down to talk to her.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
I sure am glad I never saw her again.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
Close encounter three: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
1989.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
In the mid-to-late '80s,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
the novelist Whitley Strieber wrote a book called "Communion,"

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
in which he described his own lifelong experiences

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
being abducted by aliens.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
And he also described the phenomenon known in this community

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
as "lost time,"

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
where Whitley Strieber would suddenly become aware

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
that he could not remember the previous ten minutes,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
or the previous ten hours, or the previous ten days.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And would come to the conclusion that that was when the aliens

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
were taking him and giving him rectal probes.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
(Laughter)

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
This book became, naturally, an enormous best-seller.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
This image by Ted Joseph was from that book,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and was his, sort of, police sketch

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
of what the creatures looked like

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
that Whitley Strieber had described to him.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
And it was so successful that they made it into a movie.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
And in 1989, the way I remember it,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
I was in Philadelphia

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
visiting my girlfriend, and we decided,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
apropos of nothing, to go see this movie.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
And the way I remember it, the movie featured these details.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
One: Whitley Strieber

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
was played by Christopher Walken.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
Two: the alien was played by a rubber puppet.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
(Laughter)

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
Three: there was a surprisingly long

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
sequence of the film in which the rubber puppet

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
gives Christopher Walken a rectal probe.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Four: this was being shown

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
in a regular movie theater in Center City, Philadelphia.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
Five: all of which is to say,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
they made a movie out of the book, "Communion,"

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
and it starred Christopher Walken.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Does something seem strange about this to you?

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Something odd? Something off? Something wrong with this picture?

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Think about it. Yes. The answer is:

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
I had a girlfriend. What?

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
(Laughter)

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
How did this happen? When did this happen?

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
I remember walking out of the theater

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
and becoming suddenly aware of this fact,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
as we walked hand in hand,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
and pondering these very same questions.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And to this day, I have no answer for you.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Close encounter four: the Algarve,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Portugal, 1991.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Some years later, I and this woman --

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
we'll call her "Catherine Fletcher" --

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
(Laughter) --

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
went traveling through the south of Portugal together.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
We stayed in old, crumbling, walled cities,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:31.958
in tiny little hotels,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and we would climb up to the roof and drink Vinho Verde

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
and watch the sun set and play checkers.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
What? Did we do this? Really? Does anyone do this?

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
We went to some topless beaches.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
Excuse me? No, not in my life.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
For what it's worth, we went to Sagres,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
which was considered, at the time, to be the end of the world.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
And there I was chased by a pack of feral dogs on the dock,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and the lead dog bit me on the ass,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
requiring me to go to a strange Portuguese clinic

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
and receive an ass shot.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
Make of that what you will.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:03.958
(Laughter)

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Our last day in Portugal,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
we were in the district capital of Faro,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and Catherine decided that she wanted to go to the beach

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
one last time.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
Now, Faro is a bustling little city,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and to get to the beach, she explained, you would have to take

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
a bus and then a boat.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And did I want to come with?

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
But I was exhausted and dog-bitten, and so I said, "No."

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
I remember what she looked like before she left.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
The freckles had grown

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
and multiplied on her face and shoulders,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
clustering into a kind of a tan.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
A tan, we were both tan --

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
is this true?

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Her eyes were extra bright and extra blue, as a result.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
She was smiling.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
She was a single woman about to go alone into a country,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
not even speaking the language,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
to travel alone by bus and boat

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
to go to a beach she did not know

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
or had never seen.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
I loved her, and then she went out

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
into that strange, alien land.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
It took me some time to come to my senses.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:05.958
I had my own "lost time" moment,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
where I woke up and suddenly realized

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
it was very late in the day, almost dinnertime,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
and she had not come back.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Nervous, I went down to the street to look for her.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Now, I did not speak Portuguese.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
I did not know where the beach was.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
I could not call her on a cell phone because this was 1991,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
and the aliens had not given us that technology yet.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
(Laughter)

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
I realized that the day would only have

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
two possible outcomes:

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
either Catherine would come back to the hotel,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
or she would never come back to the hotel.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
And so I sat down to wait.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
I did not watch the skies, but the very end of the street

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
where the buses and cars and pedestrians

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and little scooters were moving along.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
And I watched those constellations shift,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
hoping that they would part and I would see her face.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
It was at that moment,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
in that very small town of 30,000 or so,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
that I truly appreciated the vastness of the universe

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and the searching we might do in it.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And that's when the Liberians came along.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
Five young men -- all laughing, happy, traveling together,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
coming back to this hotel where they were staying.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
One of them was named Joseph, and he asked me

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
what was I doing, and I explained.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
And he said, "Don't worry." He was sure that Catherine would be safe.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
But he did not seem so very sure,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
for he sat down to wait with me.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And for the next two hours, they all waited with me:

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
taking turns, going up to their room, coming back,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:28.958
telling me jokes, distracting me.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
Two hours, they gave me a message.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
We are not alone.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
And then, in the middle of a sentence, at the very birth of twilight,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
I turned and looked down the street.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
The stars aligned, and she came back.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
She was smiling. She did not understand why I was so worried.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Neither did the Liberians,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
although there was a huge amount of relief in their laughter

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
as they clapped us on the back, and went back up to their room

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
and left us alone in the street, holding hands.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
An event like this leaves a scar on the memory,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
much like a piece of alien technology

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
that has been inserted into your buttocks

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
by a "Portuguese doctor."

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
(Laughter)

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
And even now, a decade and a half later,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
even now that we are married,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
I look for her still, whenever she is not in the room.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And even though, I think you'll agree, it is probable

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
that during the time she was away,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
she was kidnapped and replaced by an alien clone,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
I love her and wait for her still.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
Thank you for your kind attention.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
(Applause)

title: Nature vs. humans
transcript: You hear that this is the era of environment — or biology, or information technology ... Well, it's the era of a lot of different things that we're in right now. But one thing for sure: it's the era of change. There's more change going on than ever has occurred in the history of human life on earth. And you all sort of know it, but it's hard to get it so that you really understand it. And I've tried to put together something that's a good start for this. I've tried to show in this — though the color doesn't come out — that what I'm concerned with is the little 50-year time bubble that you are in. You tend to be interested in a generation past, a generation future — your parents, your kids, things you can change over the next few decades — and this 50-year time bubble you kind of move along in. And in that 50 years, if you look at the population curve, you find the population of humans on the earth more than doubles and we're up three-and-a-half times since I was born. When you have a new baby, by the time that kid gets out of high school more people will be added than existed on earth when I was born. This is unprecedented, and it's big. Where it goes in the future is questioned. So that's the human part.Now, the human part related to animals: look at the left side of that. What I call the human portion — humans and their livestock and pets — versus the natural portion — all the other wild animals and just — these are vertebrates and all the birds, etc., in the land and air, not in the water. How does it balance? Certainly, 10,000 years ago, the civilization's beginning, the human portion was less than one tenth of one percent. Let's look at it now. You follow this curve and you see the whiter spot in the middle — that's your 50-year time bubble. Humans, livestock and pets are now 97 percent of that integrated total mass on earth and all wild nature is three percent. We have won. The next generation doesn't even have to worry about this game — it is over. And the biggest problem came in the last 25 years: it went from 25 percent up to that 97 percent. And this really is a sobering picture upon realizing that we, humans, are in charge of life on earth; we're like the capricious Gods of old Greek myths, kind of playing with life — and not a great deal of wisdom injected into it.Now, the third curve is information technology. This is Moore's Law plotted here, which relates to density of information, but it has been pretty good for showing a lot of other things about information technology — computers, their use, Internet, etc. And what's important is it just goes straight up through the top of the curve, and has no real limits to it. Now try and contrast these. This is the size of the earth going through that same — (Laughter) — frame. And to make it really clear, I've put all four on one graph. There's no need to see the little detailed words on it. That first one is humans-versus-nature; we've won, there's no more gain. Human population. And so if you're looking for growth industries to get into, that's not a good one — protecting natural creatures. Human population is going up; it's going to continue for quite a while. Good business in obstetricians, morticians, and farming, housing, etc. — they all deal with human bodies, which require being fed, transported, housed and so on. And the information technology, which connects to our brains, has no limit — now, that is a wonderful field to be in. You're looking for growth opportunity? It's just going up through the roof. And then, the size of the Earth. Somehow making these all compatible with the Earth looks like a pretty bad industry to be involved with.So, that's the stage out of all this. I find, for reasons I don't understand, I really do have a goal. And the goal is that the world be desirable and sustainable when my kids reach my age — and I think that's — in other words, the next generation. I think that's a goal that we probably all share. I think it's a hopeless goal. Technologically, it's achievable; economically, it's achievable; politically, it means sort of the habits, institutions of people — it's impossible. The institutions of the past with all their inertia are just irrelevant for the future, except they're there and we have to deal with them. I spend about 15 percent of my time trying to save the world, the other 85 percent, the usual — and whatever else we devote ourselves to. And in that 15 percent, the main focus is on human mind, thinking skills, somehow trying to unleash kids from the straightjacket of school, which is putting information and dogma into them, get them so they really think, ask tough questions, argue about serious subjects, don't believe everything that's in the book, think broadly or creative. They can be. Our school systems are very flawed and do not reward you for the things that are important in life or for the survival of civilization; they reward you for a lot of learning and sopping up stuff. We can't go into that today because there isn't time — it's a broad subject. One thing for sure, in the future there is an essential feature — necessary, but not sufficient — which is doing more with less. We've got to be doing things with more efficiency using less energy, less material. Your great-great grandparents got by on muscle power, and yet we all think there's this huge power that's essential for our lifestyle. And with all the wonderful technology we have we can do things that are much more efficient: conserve, recycle, etc.Let me just rush very quickly through things that we've done. Human-powered airplane — Gossamer Condor sort of started me in this direction in 1976 and 77, winning the Kremer prize in aviation history, followed by the Albatross. And we began making various odd planes and creatures. Here's a giant flying replica of a pterosaur that has no tail. Trying to have it fly straight is like trying to shoot an arrow with the feathered end forward. It was a tough job, and boy it made me have a lot of respect for nature. This was the full size of the original creature. We did things on land, in the air, on water — vehicles of all different kinds, usually with some electronics or electric power systems in them. I find they're all the same, whether its land, air or water. I'll be focusing on the air here. This is a solar-powered airplane — 165 miles carrying a person from France to England as a symbol that solar power is going to be an important part of our future. Then we did the solar car for General Motors — the Sunracer — that won the race in Australia. We got a lot of people thinking about electric cars, what you could do with them. A few years later, when we suggested to GM that now is the time and we could do a thing called the Impact, they sponsored it, and here's the Impact that we developed with them on their programs. This is the demonstrator. And they put huge effort into turning it into a commercial product.With that preamble, let's show the first two-minute videotape, which shows a little airplane for surveillance and moving to a giant airplane. Narrator: A tiny airplane, the AV Pointer serves for surveillance — in effect, a pair of roving eyeglasses. A cutting-edge example of where miniaturization can lead if the operator is remote from the vehicle. It is convenient to carry, assemble and launch by hand. Battery-powered, it is silent and rarely noticed. It sends high-resolution video pictures back to the operator. With onboard GPS, it can navigate autonomously, and it is rugged enough to self-land without damage. The modern sailplane is superbly efficient. Some can glide as flat as 60 feet forward for every foot of descent. They are powered only by the energy they can extract from the atmosphere — an atmosphere nature stirs up by solar energy. Humans and soaring birds have found nature to be generous in providing replenishable energy. Sailplanes have flown over 1,000 miles, and the altitude record is over 50,000 feet. (Music) The Solar Challenger was made to serve as a symbol that photovoltaic cells can produce real power and will be part of the world's energy future. In 1981, it flew 163 miles from Paris to England, solely on the power of sunbeams, and established a basis for the Pathfinder. (Music) The message from all these vehicles is that ideas and technology can be harnessed to produce remarkable gains in doing more with less — gains that can help us attain a desirable balance between technology and nature. The stakes are high as we speed toward a challenging future. Buckminster Fuller said it clearly: "there are no passengers on spaceship Earth, only crew. We, the crew, can and must do more with less — much less."Paul MacCready: If we could have the second video, the one-minute, put in as quickly as you can, which — this will show the Pathfinder airplane in some flights this past year in Hawaii, and will show a sequence of some of the beauty behind it after it had just flown to 71,530 feet — higher than any propeller airplane has ever flown. It's amazing: just on the puny power of the sun — by having a super lightweight plane, you're able to get it up there. It's part of a long-term program NASA sponsored. And we worked very closely with the whole thing being a team effort, and with wonderful results like that flight. And we're working on a bigger plane — 220-foot span — and an intermediate-size, one with a regenerative fuel cell that can store excess energy during the day, feed it back at night, and stay up 65,000 feet for months at a time. (Music) Ray Morgan's voice will come in here. There he's the project manager. Anything they do is certainly a team effort. He ran this program. Here's ... some things he showed as a celebration at the very end. Ray Morgan: We'd just ended a seven-month deployment of Hawaii. For those who live on the mainland, it was tough being away from home. The friendly support, the quiet confidence, congenial hospitality shown by our Hawaiian and military hosts — (Music) this is starting — made the experience enjoyable and unforgettable. PM: We have real-time IR scans going out through the Internet while the plane is flying. And it's exploring without polluting the stratosphere. That's its goal: the stratosphere, the blanket that really controls the radiation of the earth and permits life on earth to be the success that it is — probing that is very important. And also we consider it as a sort of poor man's stationary satellite, because it can stay right overhead for months at a time, 2,000 times closer than the real GFC synchronous satellite. We couldn't bring one here to fly it and show you.But now let's look at the other end. In the video you saw that nine-pound or eight-pound Pointer airplane surveillance drone that Keenan has developed and just done a remarkable job. Where some have servos that have gotten down to, oh, 18 or 25 grams, his weigh one-third of a gram. And what he's going to bring out here is a surveillance drone that weighs about 2 ounces — that includes the video camera, the batteries that run it, the telemetry, the receiver and so on. And we'll fly it, we hope, with the same success that we had last night when we did the practice. So Matt Keenan, just any time you're — all right — ready to let her go. But first, we're going to make sure that it's appearing on the screen, so you see what it sees. You can imagine yourself being a mouse or fly inside of it, looking out of its camera. Matt Keenan: It's switched on. PM: But now we're trying to get the video. There we go. MK: Can you bring up the house lights? PM: Yeah, the house lights and we'll see you all better and be able to fly the plane better. MK: All right, we'll try to do a few laps around and bring it back in. Here we go. (Applause) PM: The video worked right for the first few and I don't know why it — there it goes. Oh, that was only a minute, but I think you'd be safe to have that near the end of the flight, perhaps. We get to do the classic. All right. If this hits you, it will not hurt you. (Laughter) OK. (Applause) Thank you very much. Thank you. (Applause)But now, as they say in infomercials, we have something much better for you, which we're working on: planes that are only six inches — 15 centimeters — in size. And Matt's plane was on the cover of Popular Science last month, showing what this can lead to. And in a while, something this size will have GPS and a video camera in it. We've had one of these fly nine miles through the air at 35 miles an hour with just a little battery in it. But there's a lot of technology going. There are just milestones along the way of some remarkable things. This one doesn't have the video in it, but you get a little feel from what it can do. OK, here we go. (Laughter) MK: Sorry. OK. (Applause) PM: If you can pass it down when you're done. Yeah, I think — I lost a little orientation; I looked up into this light. It hit the building. And the building was poorly placed, actually. (Laughter) But you're beginning to see what can be done. We're working on projects now — even wing-flapping things the size of hawk moths — DARPA contracts, working with Caltech, UCLA.Where all this leads, I don't know. Is it practical? I don't know. But like any basic research, when you're really forced to do things that are way beyond existing technology, you can get there with micro-technology, nanotechnology. You can do amazing things when you realize what nature has been doing all along. As you get to these small scales, you realize we have a lot to learn from nature — not with 747s — but when you get down to the nature's realm, nature has 200 million years of experience. It never makes a mistake. Because if you make a mistake, you don't leave any progeny. We should have nothing but success stories from nature, for you or for birds, and we're learning a lot from its fascinating subjects.In concluding, I want to get back to the big picture and I have just two final slides to try and put it in perspective. The first I'll just read. At last, I put in three sentences and had it say what I wanted. Over billions of years on a unique sphere, chance has painted a thin covering of life — complex, improbable, wonderful and fragile. Suddenly, we humans — a recently arrived species, no longer subject to the checks and balances inherent in nature — have grown in population, technology and intelligence to a position of terrible power. We now wield the paintbrush. And that's serious: we're not very bright. We're short on wisdom; we're high on technology. Where's it going to lead?Well, inspired by the sentences, I decided to wield the paintbrush. Every 25 years I do a picture. Here's the one — tries to show that the world isn't getting any bigger. Sort of a timeline, very non-linear scale, nature rates and trilobites and dinosaurs, and eventually we saw some humans with caves ... Birds were flying overhead, after pterosaurs. And then we get to the civilization above the little TV set with a gun on it. Then traffic jams, and power systems, and some dots for digital. Where it's going to lead — I have no idea. And so I just put robotic and natural cockroaches out there, but you can fill in whatever you want. This is not a forecast. This is a warning, and we have to think seriously about it. And that time when this is happening is not 100 years or 500 years. Things are going on this decade, next decade; it's a very short time that we have to decide what we are going to do. And if we can get some agreement on where we want the world to be — desirable, sustainable when your kids reach your age — I think we actually can reach it. Now, I said this was a warning, not a forecast. That was before — I painted this before we started in on making robotic versions of hawk moths and cockroaches, and now I'm beginning to wonder seriously — was this more of a forecast than I wanted? I personally think the surviving intelligent life form on earth is not going to be carbon-based; it's going to be silicon-based. And so where it all goes, I don't know.The one final bit of sparkle we'll put in at the very end here is an utterly impractical flight vehicle, which is a little ornithopter wing-flapping device that — rubber-band powered — that we'll show you. MK: 32 gram. Sorry, one gram. PM: Last night we gave it a few too many turns and it tried to bash the roof out also. It's about a gram. The tube there's hollow, about paper-thin. And if this lands on you, I assure you it will not hurt you. But if you reach out to grab it or hold it, you will destroy it. So, be gentle, just act like a wooden Indian or something. And when it comes down — and we'll see how it goes. We consider this to be sort of the spirit of TED. (Applause) And you wonder, is it practical? And it turns out if I had not been — (Laughter) (Applause) Unfortunately, we have some light bulb changes. We can probably get it down, but it's possible it's gone up to a greater destiny up there — (Laughter) — than it ever had. And I wanted to make — (Applause) just — (Applause)But I want to make just two points. One is, you think it's frivolous; there's nothing to it. And yet if I had not been making ornithopters like that, a little bit cruder, in 1939 — a long, long time ago — there wouldn't have been a Gossamer Condor, there wouldn't have been an Albatross, a Solar Challenger, there wouldn't be an Impact car, there wouldn't be a mandate on zero-emission vehicles in California. A lot of these things — or similar — would have happened some time, probably a decade later. I didn't realize at the time I was doing inquiry-based, hands-on things with teams, like they're trying to get in education systems. So I think that, as a symbol, it's important. And I believe that also is important. You can think of it as a sort of a symbol for learning and TED that somehow gets you thinking of technology and nature, and puts it all together in things that are — that make this conference, I think, more important than any that's taken place in this country in this decade. Thank you. (Applause)

Good business in obstetricians, morticians, and farming, housing, etc. --

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:55.958
they all deal with human bodies, which require being fed,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:04:00.958
transported, housed and so on. And the information technology,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
which connects to our brains, has no limit -- now, that is a wonderful

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
field to be in. You're looking for growth opportunity?

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
It's just going up through the roof.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And then, the size of the Earth. Somehow making these all compatible

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
with the Earth looks like a pretty bad industry to be involved with.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
So, that's the stage out of all this. I find,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
for reasons I don't understand, I really do have a goal.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:28.958
And the goal is that the world be desirable and sustainable

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
when my kids reach my age -- and I think that's -- in other words,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
the next generation. I think that's a goal that we probably all share.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
I think it's a hopeless goal. Technologically, it's achievable;

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
economically, it's achievable; politically,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
it means sort of the habits, institutions of people -- it's impossible.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
The institutions of the past with all their inertia

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
are just irrelevant for the future, except they're there

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:58.958
and we have to deal with them. I spend about 15 percent of my time

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
trying to save the world, the other 85 percent, the usual --

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
and whatever else we devote ourselves to.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:09.958
And in that 15 percent, the main focus is on human mind, thinking skills,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
somehow trying to unleash kids from the straightjacket of school,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
which is putting information and dogma into them,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
get them so they really think, ask tough questions, argue

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
about serious subjects, don't believe everything that's in the book,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
think broadly or creative. They can be.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Our school systems are very flawed and do not reward you

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
for the things that are important in life

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
or for the survival of civilization; they reward you

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
for a lot of learning and sopping up stuff.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
We can't go into that today because there isn't time --

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
it's a broad subject. One thing for sure, in the future

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:53.958
there is an essential feature -- necessary, but not sufficient --

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
which is doing more with less. We've got to be doing things

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
with more efficiency using less energy, less material.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
Your great-great grandparents got by on muscle power,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and yet we all think there's this huge power that's essential

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
for our lifestyle. And with all the wonderful technology we have

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:18.958
we can do things that are much more efficient: conserve, recycle, etc.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Let me just rush very quickly through things that we've done.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
Human-powered airplane -- Gossamer Condor sort of started me

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:30.958
in this direction in 1976 and 77,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:32.958
winning the Kremer prize in aviation history,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
followed by the Albatross. And we began

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
making various odd planes and creatures.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Here's a giant flying replica of a pterosaur that has no tail.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
Trying to have it fly straight is like trying to shoot an arrow

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
with the feathered end forward. It was a tough job,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and boy it made me have a lot of respect for nature.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
This was the full size of the original creature.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
We did things on land, in the air, on water --

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
vehicles of all different kinds, usually with some electronics

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
or electric power systems in them. I find they're all the same,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
whether its land, air or water.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
I'll be focusing on the air here. This is a solar-powered airplane --

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
165 miles carrying a person from France to England

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
as a symbol that solar power is going to be an important part

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
of our future. Then we did the solar car for General Motors --

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
the Sunracer -- that won the race in Australia.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
We got a lot of people thinking about electric cars,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
what you could do with them. A few years later, when we suggested to GM that

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
now is the time and we could do a thing called the Impact,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
they sponsored it, and here's the Impact that we developed with them

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
on their programs. This is the demonstrator. And they put huge effort

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
into turning it into a commercial product.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:52.958
With that preamble, let's show the first two-minute videotape,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
which shows a little airplane for surveillance

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
and moving to a giant airplane.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Narrator: A tiny airplane, the AV Pointer serves for surveillance --

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:07.958
in effect, a pair of roving eyeglasses. A cutting-edge example

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
of where miniaturization can lead if the operator is remote

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
from the vehicle. It is convenient to carry, assemble

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and launch by hand. Battery-powered, it is silent and rarely noticed.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
It sends high-resolution video pictures back to the operator.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
With onboard GPS, it can navigate autonomously,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
and it is rugged enough to self-land without damage.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
The modern sailplane is superbly efficient.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
Some can glide as flat as 60 feet forward for every foot of descent.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:40.958
They are powered only by the energy

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
they can extract from the atmosphere --

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
an atmosphere nature stirs up by solar energy.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
Humans and soaring birds have found nature to be generous

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:53.958
in providing replenishable energy. Sailplanes have flown

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
over 1,000 miles, and the altitude record is over 50,000 feet.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:02.958
(Music)

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
The Solar Challenger was made to serve as a symbol

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
that photovoltaic cells can produce real power

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and will be part of the world's energy future.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
In 1981, it flew 163 miles from Paris to England,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
solely on the power of sunbeams,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and established a basis for the Pathfinder.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
(Music)

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
The message from all these vehicles is that ideas and technology

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
can be harnessed to produce remarkable gains in doing more with less --

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
gains that can help us attain a desirable balance

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
between technology and nature. The stakes are high

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
as we speed toward a challenging future.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Buckminster Fuller said it clearly: "there are no passengers

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:49.958
on spaceship Earth, only crew. We, the crew,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
can and must do more with less -- much less."

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Paul MacCready: If we could have the second video, the one-minute,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
put in as quickly as you can, which -- this will show

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:11.958
the Pathfinder airplane in some flights this past year in Hawaii,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and will show a sequence of some of the beauty behind it

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
after it had just flown to 71,530 feet --

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
higher than any propeller airplane has ever flown.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
It's amazing: just on the puny power of the sun --

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
by having a super lightweight plane, you're able to get it up there.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
It's part of a long-term program NASA sponsored.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And we worked very closely with the whole thing being a team effort,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and with wonderful results like that flight.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And we're working on a bigger plane -- 220-foot span --

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and an intermediate-size, one with a regenerative fuel cell

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
that can store excess energy during the day, feed it back at night,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and stay up 65,000 feet for months at a time.

shown by our Hawaiian and military hosts --

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
without polluting the stratosphere. That's its goal: the stratosphere,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
the blanket that really controls the radiation of the earth

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and permits life on earth to be the success that it is --

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
probing that is very important. And also we consider it

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
as a sort of poor man's stationary satellite,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
because it can stay right overhead for months at a time,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:17.958
2,000 times closer than the real GFC synchronous satellite.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
we have something much better for you, which we're working on:

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
planes that are only six inches -- 15 centimeters -- in size.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:16.958
And Matt's plane was on the cover of Popular Science last month,

showing what this can lead to. And in a while, something this size

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:21.958

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
We're working on projects now -- even wing-flapping things

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:28.958
the size of hawk moths -- DARPA contracts, working with Caltech, UCLA.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
Where all this leads, I don't know. Is it practical? I don't know.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
But like any basic research, when you're really forced to do things

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
that are way beyond existing technology,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
you can get there with micro-technology, nanotechnology.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
You can do amazing things when you realize

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
what nature has been doing all along. As you get to these small scales,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
you realize we have a lot to learn from nature -- not with 747s --

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
but when you get down to the nature's realm,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
nature has 200 million years of experience.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
It never makes a mistake. Because if you make a mistake,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:01.958
you don't leave any progeny.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
We should have nothing but success stories from nature,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
for you or for birds, and we're learning a lot

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
from its fascinating subjects.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:17.958
In concluding, I want to get back to the big picture

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:23.958
and I have just two final slides to try and put it in perspective.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
The first I'll just read. At last, I put in three sentences

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
and had it say what I wanted.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Over billions of years on a unique sphere, chance has painted

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:37.958
a thin covering of life -- complex, improbable, wonderful

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
and fragile. Suddenly, we humans -- a recently arrived species,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
no longer subject to the checks and balances inherent in nature --

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
have grown in population, technology and intelligence

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
to a position of terrible power. We now wield the paintbrush.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:56.958
And that's serious: we're not very bright. We're short on wisdom;

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.958
we're high on technology. Where's it going to lead?

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:04.958
Well, inspired by the sentences, I decided to wield the paintbrush.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
Every 25 years I do a picture. Here's the one --

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
tries to show that the world isn't getting any bigger.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:14.958
Sort of a timeline, very non-linear scale, nature rates

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
and trilobites and dinosaurs, and eventually we saw some humans

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:22.958
with caves ... Birds were flying overhead, after pterosaurs.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:26.958
And then we get to the civilization above the little TV set

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:30.958
with a gun on it. Then traffic jams, and power systems,

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:34.958
and some dots for digital. Where it's going to lead -- I have no idea.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:39.958
And so I just put robotic and natural cockroaches out there,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
but you can fill in whatever you want. This is not a forecast.

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:46.958
This is a warning, and we have to think seriously about it.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:50.958
And that time when this is happening is not 100 years or 500 years.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:55.958
Things are going on this decade, next decade;

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
it's a very short time that we have to decide what we are going to do.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
And if we can get some agreement on where we want the world to be --

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
desirable, sustainable when your kids reach your age --

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:12.958
I think we actually can reach it. Now, I said this was a warning,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
not a forecast. That was before --

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:18.958
I painted this before we started in on making robotic versions

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
of hawk moths and cockroaches, and now I'm beginning to wonder

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
seriously -- was this more of a forecast than I wanted?

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
I personally think the surviving intelligent life form on earth

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:31.958
is not going to be carbon-based; it's going to be silicon-based.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:37.958
And so where it all goes, I don't know.

The one final bit of sparkle we'll put in at the very end here

title: Flow, the secret to happiness
transcript: I grew up in Europe, and World War II caught me when I was between seven and 10 years old. And I realized how few of the grown-ups that I knew were able to withstand the tragedies that the war visited on them — how few of them could even resemble a normal, contented, satisfied, happy life once their job, their home, their security was destroyed by the war. So I became interested in understanding what contributed to a life that was worth living. And I tried, as a child, as a teenager, to read philosophy and to get involved in art and religion and many other ways that I could see as a possible answer to that question. And finally I ended up encountering psychology by chance.I was at a ski resort in Switzerland without any money to actually enjoy myself, because the snow had melted and I didn't have money to go to a movie. But I found that on the — I read in the newspapers that there was to be a presentation by someone in a place that I'd seen in the center of Zurich, and it was about flying saucers [that] he was going to talk. And I thought, well, since I can't go to the movies, at least I will go for free to listen to flying saucers. And the man who talked at that evening lecture was very interesting. Instead of talking about little green men, he talked about how the psyche of the Europeans had been traumatized by the war, and now they're projecting flying saucers into the sky. He talked about how the mandalas of ancient Hindu religion were kind of projected into the sky as an attempt to regain some sense of order after the chaos of war. And this seemed very interesting to me. And I started reading his books after that lecture. And that was Carl Jung, whose name or work I had no idea about.Then I came to this country to study psychology and I started trying to understand the roots of happiness. This is a typical result that many people have presented, and there are many variations on it. But this, for instance, shows that about 30 percent of the people surveyed in the United States since 1956 say that their life is very happy. And that hasn't changed at all. Whereas the personal income, on a scale that has been held constant to accommodate for inflation, has more than doubled, almost tripled, in that period. But you find essentially the same results, namely, that after a certain basic point — which corresponds more or less to just a few 1,000 dollars above the minimum poverty level — increases in material well-being don't seem to affect how happy people are. In fact, you can find that the lack of basic resources, material resources, contributes to unhappiness, but the increase in material resources does not increase happiness.So my research has been focused more on — after finding out these things that actually corresponded to my own experience, I tried to understand: where — in everyday life, in our normal experience — do we feel really happy? And to start those studies about 40 years ago, I began to look at creative people — first artists and scientists, and so forth — trying to understand what made them feel that it was worth essentially spending their life doing things for which many of them didn't expect either fame or fortune, but which made their life meaningful and worth doing.This was one of the leading composers of American music back in the '70s. And the interview was 40 pages long. But this little excerpt is a very good summary of what he was saying during the interview. And it describes how he feels when composing is going well. And he says by describing it as an ecstatic state.Now, "ecstasy" in Greek meant simply to stand to the side of something. And then it became essentially an analogy for a mental state where you feel that you are not doing your ordinary everyday routines. So ecstasy is essentially a stepping into an alternative reality. And it's interesting, if you think about it, how, when we think about the civilizations that we look up to as having been pinnacles of human achievement — whether it's China, Greece, the Hindu civilization, or the Mayas, or Egyptians — what we know about them is really about their ecstasies, not about their everyday life. We know the temples they built, where people could come to experience a different reality. We know about the circuses, the arenas, the theaters. These are the remains of civilizations and they are the places that people went to experience life in a more concentrated, more ordered form.Now, this man doesn't need to go to a place like this, which is also — this place, this arena, which is built like a Greek amphitheatre, is a place for ecstasy also. We are participating in a reality that is different from that of the everyday life that we're used to. But this man doesn't need to go there. He needs just a piece of paper where he can put down little marks, and as he does that, he can imagine sounds that had not existed before in that particular combination. So once he gets to that point of beginning to create, like Jennifer did in her improvisation, a new reality — that is, a moment of ecstasy — he enters that different reality. Now he says also that this is so intense an experience that it feels almost as if he didn't exist. And that sounds like a kind of a romantic exaggeration. But actually, our nervous system is incapable of processing more than about 110 bits of information per second. And in order to hear me and understand what I'm saying, you need to process about 60 bits per second. That's why you can't hear more than two people. You can't understand more than two people talking to you.Well, when you are really involved in this completely engaging process of creating something new, as this man is, he doesn't have enough attention left over to monitor how his body feels, or his problems at home. He can't feel even that he's hungry or tired. His body disappears, his identity disappears from his consciousness, because he doesn't have enough attention, like none of us do, to really do well something that requires a lot of concentration, and at the same time to feel that he exists. So existence is temporarily suspended. And he says that his hand seems to be moving by itself. Now, I could look at my hand for two weeks, and I wouldn't feel any awe or wonder, because I can't compose. (Laughter)So what it's telling you here is that obviously this automatic, spontaneous process that he's describing can only happen to someone who is very well trained and who has developed technique. And it has become a kind of a truism in the study of creativity that you can't be creating anything with less than 10 years of technical-knowledge immersion in a particular field. Whether it's mathematics or music, it takes that long to be able to begin to change something in a way that it's better than what was there before. Now, when that happens, he says the music just flows out. And because all of these people I started interviewing — this was an interview which is over 30 years old — so many of the people described this as a spontaneous flow that I called this type of experience the "flow experience." And it happens in different realms.For instance, a poet describes it in this form. This is by a student of mine who interviewed some of the leading writers and poets in the United States. And it describes the same effortless, spontaneous feeling that you get when you enter into this ecstatic state. This poet describes it as opening a door that floats in the sky — a very similar description to what Albert Einstein gave as to how he imagined the forces of relativity, when he was struggling with trying to understand how it worked. But it happens in other activities. For instance, this is another student of mine, Susan Jackson from Australia, who did work with some of the leading athletes in the world. And you see here in this description of an Olympic skater, the same essential description of the phenomenology of the inner state of the person. You don't think; it goes automatically, if you merge yourself with the music, and so forth.It happens also, actually, in the most recent book I wrote, called "Good Business," where I interviewed some of the CEOs who had been nominated by their peers as being both very successful and very ethical, very socially responsible. You see that these people define success as something that helps others and at the same time makes you feel happy as you are working at it. And like all of these successful and responsible CEOs say, you can't have just one of these things be successful if you want a meaningful and successful job. Anita Roddick is another one of these CEOs we interviewed. She is the founder of Body Shop, the natural cosmetics king. It's kind of a passion that comes from doing the best and having flow while you're working.This is an interesting little quote from Masaru Ibuka, who was at that time starting out Sony without any money, without a product — they didn't have a product, they didn't have anything, but they had an idea. And the idea he had was to establish a place of work where engineers can feel the joy of technological innovation, be aware of their mission to society and work to their heart's content. I couldn't improve on this as a good example of how flow enters the workplace.Now, when we do studies — we have, with other colleagues around the world, done over 8,000 interviews of people — from Dominican monks, to blind nuns, to Himalayan climbers, to Navajo shepherds — who enjoy their work. And regardless of the culture, regardless of education or whatever, there are these seven conditions that seem to be there when a person is in flow. There's this focus that, once it becomes intense, leads to a sense of ecstasy, a sense of clarity: you know exactly what you want to do from one moment to the other; you get immediate feedback. You know that what you need to do is possible to do, even though difficult, and sense of time disappears, you forget yourself, you feel part of something larger. And once the conditions are present, what you are doing becomes worth doing for its own sake.In our studies, we represent the everyday life of people in this simple scheme. And we can measure this very precisely, actually, because we give people electronic pagers that go off 10 times a day, and whenever they go off you say what you're doing, how you feel, where you are, what you're thinking about. And two things that we measure is the amount of challenge people experience at that moment and the amount of skill that they feel they have at that moment. So for each person we can establish an average, which is the center of the diagram. That would be your mean level of challenge and skill, which will be different from that of anybody else. But you have a kind of a set point there, which would be in the middle.If we know what that set point is, we can predict fairly accurately when you will be in flow, and it will be when your challenges are higher than average and skills are higher than average. And you may be doing things very differently from other people, but for everyone that flow channel, that area there, will be when you are doing what you really like to do — play the piano, be with your best friend, perhaps work, if work is what provides flow for you. And then the other areas become less and less positive.Arousal is still good because you are over-challenged there. Your skills are not quite as high as they should be, but you can move into flow fairly easily by just developing a little more skill. So, arousal is the area where most people learn from, because that's where they're pushed beyond their comfort zone and to enter that — going back to flow — then they develop higher skills. Control is also a good place to be, because there you feel comfortable, but not very excited. It's not very challenging any more. And if you want to enter flow from control, you have to increase the challenges. So those two are ideal and complementary areas from which flow is easy to go into.The other combinations of challenge and skill become progressively less optimal. Relaxation is fine — you still feel OK. Boredom begins to be very aversive and apathy becomes very negative: you don't feel that you're doing anything, you don't use your skills, there's no challenge. Unfortunately, a lot of people's experience is in apathy. The largest single contributor to that experience is watching television; the next one is being in the bathroom, sitting. Even though sometimes watching television about seven to eight percent of the time is in flow, but that's when you choose a program you really want to watch and you get feedback from it.So the question we are trying to address — and I'm way over time — is how to put more and more of everyday life in that flow channel. And that is the kind of challenge that we're trying to understand. And some of you obviously know how to do that spontaneously without any advice, but unfortunately a lot of people don't. And that's what our mandate is, in a way, to do.Thank you.(Applause)
